Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

It started with just being…scared. Really scared. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a whole human being. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud.

And then there was the whole thing with Paulie Bleeker. He was…sweet. Really sweet. But we were kids. And even if we *had* stayed together, I didn't want him to have to give up his dreams for me and a baby. He wanted to be a musician. That's a big deal.

But honestly, the biggest thing was…I just didn't think I could give the baby what it deserved. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the money, the stability, the…maturity. I wanted that baby to have a good life, a safe life, a life full of opportunities. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't provide that.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. They were ready. They were excited. They had a beautiful home and a stable life. They could give that baby everything I couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about *not* wanting the baby. It was about wanting the best for the baby. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was…a good ending. For everyone involved. And that's what mattered.

Don't get me wrong, it still messes with my head sometimes. But I try to focus on the fact that I made a selfless decision. And that's something to be proud of, right? Right? Ugh. Don't make me cry.

Ugh, okay, so like, love and responsibility. Big topics. And honestly, I didn't *set out* to learn about them. I was just trying to figure out what to do with a baby, you know? But yeah, it kinda snuck up on me.

I think at the beginning, I saw love as this…romantic, movie-type thing. Like, Paulie Bleeker was sweet and all, but I didn't really *get* it. It felt kinda silly and dramatic. And responsibility? That was just something adults told you to do.

But then, dealing with Mark and Vanessa, the couple who wanted to adopt my baby, I started to see a different side of it. They were so…prepared. They had a house, and a life, and they were genuinely excited about becoming parents. And I realized that having a baby isn't just about the cute moments. It's about providing for someone, protecting them, and being there for them, even when it's hard. That's responsibility. And it's a *huge* responsibility.

And with Paulie…well, he just kept being there. Even when I was being a total mess. He didn't try to fix things, he just…listened. And he didn't judge me for wanting to give the baby up. He just supported my decision. And that, I think, is a kind of love that's way more real than anything I'd seen in a movie. It's about accepting someone for who they are, flaws and all.

I learned that love isn't always about grand gestures. It's about the small things. It's about being there for someone, even when it's inconvenient. It's about making sacrifices. And it's about letting go.

Giving the baby up was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing to do. And that took a different kind of responsibility. It meant putting someone else's needs before my own.

So yeah, I learned a lot. Love isn't always easy, and responsibility isn't always fun. But they're both worth it. And sometimes, the most responsible thing you can do is let go and let someone else take the reins. It's complicated. But that's life, right?

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but here we go.

Honestly? My sarcasm was a shield. A really good one. When everything was, like, completely insane – finding out I was pregnant, dealing with Mark and Vanessa, the whole adoption thing – it was easier to make a joke than to actually *feel* anything.

It was a way to distance myself from the seriousness of it all. If I could make people laugh, then maybe they wouldn't notice how scared I was. Maybe *I* wouldn't notice how scared I was.

It also helped me control the situation, you know? Like, if I could say something clever or snarky, I felt like I had some power. When everything else felt completely out of my hands.

And it was a way to connect with people. Paul, especially. He got my humor. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He just…laughed with me. That was a really big deal.

But it wasn't always healthy, I guess. Sometimes I used humor to avoid dealing with my feelings. To push people away. It was a defense mechanism, and sometimes it worked a little *too* well.

But overall? Yeah, my wit helped me get through it. It was a way to stay sane, to stay strong, and to remind myself that even in the middle of a really messed-up situation, there was still room for a little bit of laughter.

It's just…easier to be funny than to be vulnerable, you know? At least, it was for a while. But eventually, you gotta let the walls down. Even if it's terrifying.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…deep? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it a lot.

Honestly, before everything with Paulie and the baby, I was just… coasting. I was good at being sarcastic, at observing people, at avoiding anything that felt too real. I thought that was my identity – the detached observer. But it was just a shield, you know? A way to keep people from getting too close.

Then, suddenly, I was pregnant. And everything changed. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person who was depending on me, and I had *no* idea who I was, let alone who I wanted to be as a mom.

That's when the vulnerability started creeping in. I had to admit to myself that I was scared, that I didn't have all the answers, that I needed help. And that was…terrifying. I'm not exactly known for asking for help.

The search for identity really kicked into high gear then. I started questioning everything. What did I want out of life? What kind of person did I want to be? Was I just going to drift along, or was I going to actually *do* something with my life?

Giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about being honest with myself about what I could offer. It was about recognizing that I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that there were people who could give the baby a better life. It was a really hard decision, and it forced me to confront a lot of uncomfortable truths about myself.

The whole experience stripped away a lot of the layers I'd built up. It forced me to be real, to be honest, to be vulnerable. And it was through that vulnerability that I started to figure out who I was.

I'm still figuring it out, honestly. I don't think you ever really stop. But I'm less afraid to be myself now. Less afraid to show my feelings. Less afraid to ask for help.

It wasn't a straight line, and it wasn't easy. But it was…necessary. It made me who I am. And I think, maybe, that's a good thing. Even if it's still a work in progress.

So yeah, vulnerability and the search for identity? They pretty much *were* my journey. And honestly, I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the awkward conversations with Mark and Vanessa. Okay, maybe I'd trade *some* of those. But not all of them.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about that. Like, the whole pregnancy thing was…a lot. And I definitely didn't get through it alone, even though I *tried* to act like I did.

It wasn't like I had a whole squad of supportive people cheering me on, you know? It was more…a few key people who just…got it. And didn't judge. Which was huge.

My dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly cool about everything. He's kinda quiet and awkward, but he always showed up. He didn't try to fix things or tell me what to do. He just listened. And made me grilled cheese sandwiches. Which, honestly, was a bigger help than he realized.

And then there was Leah. She's my best friend, and she's just…solid. She didn't freak out or try to talk me into anything. She just helped me navigate the whole mess. She came with me to doctor's appointments, and she helped me pick out baby names (which was terrifying). She just…was there.

And then, of course, there was Mark. He was…complicated. But he stepped up. He didn't run away, and he actually seemed to *want* to be involved. He wasn't perfect, but he was trying. And that meant a lot.

Honestly, without them, I would have completely fallen apart. I'm pretty stubborn, and I like to think I can handle things on my own, but I couldn't have done this alone.

Their support wasn't about telling me what to do. It was about giving me the space to figure things out for myself. They listened to my fears, they respected my decisions, and they just…believed in me.

It made me realize that strength isn't about being tough all the time. It's about being able to ask for help when you need it. And it's about having people in your life who will be there for you, no matter what.

So yeah, they were pretty important. They helped me figure out what I wanted, and they gave me the courage to actually do it. And for that, I'm eternally grateful. Even if I don't always say it.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows kind of memory, you know? It was… a lot.

Honestly? My first thought was just… “Oh. Crap.” Like, a really big, capital-C Crap. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and whether or not Paul Snow was gonna call, not… this.

It wasn't like I didn't know anything about sex, obviously. But I definitely didn't think it would actually *happen* to me. It felt… surreal. Like it was happening to someone else.

Then came the panic. A lot of panic. What was I gonna do? What were my parents gonna say? What about school? My life was already complicated enough, and this just… exploded everything.

I was mostly just scared. Scared of everything. Scared of disappointing my parents, scared of messing up my future, scared of being a bad mom.

And then, after the initial shock wore off, I felt… weirdly calm. Like, okay, this is happening. I can't change it. I just have to figure it out.

It wasn't a happy feeling, exactly. It was more like… acceptance. And a little bit of determination. I wasn't gonna let this ruin my life. I was gonna find a way to make it work.

It was a really confusing time. A lot of emotions all at once. But mostly, it was just… overwhelming. And really, really scary.

It's hard to explain. It wasn't like in the movies. There wasn't a moment of pure joy or revelation. It was just… complicated. And messy. And real.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. It messed things up, honestly. Not in a permanently bad way, but it definitely shook things up. It was like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on my life, and none of them were asking for it.

With my mom, it was…complicated. She tried to be supportive, I guess, but it was mostly just a lot of worrying and passive-aggressive comments about responsibility. She was scared, and I think she didn't know how to deal with it, so she just defaulted to being…my mom. You know? It took a while for us to actually *talk* about it, not just at each other.

Paul…Paul was amazing. He stepped up in a way I didn't expect. He could have totally bailed, and a lot of guys would have, but he didn't. We went through a lot of awkwardness and figuring things out, but he was always there. It actually made us closer, which was…surprising.

And Leah…Leah was the best. She was just…Leah. She didn't freak out or judge me. She just listened and offered support. She helped me pick out baby names and went to doctor's appointments with me. She was a rock.

But even with Leah, it was different. I felt…older, I guess. Like I was suddenly a grown-up, and she was still just…Leah. It was weird. We still hung out, but it wasn't the same.

It was like my pregnancy put a spotlight on everyone else's lives, too. Like they were all suddenly thinking about their own futures and what they wanted. It was a lot of pressure.

It definitely changed my relationships. Some for the better, some for the worse. But it also taught me a lot about who my real friends are, and who I can really count on. And that's…something. It's a messy thing, growing up. And getting pregnant definitely sped up the process.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to balance a stack of textbooks.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was a mess. I was angry, scared, confused… all the time. I mean, I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and prom dresses, not… this.

A lot of it was just… feeling really alone. My friends didn't really get it. My dad checked out. And my mom, she was amazing, but she was also dealing with her own stuff. So I kind of just… shut down for a while.

What helped, eventually, was talking. Really talking. To my mom, to Paul, even to a guidance counselor at school. It was hard, because I didn't want to be seen as… pathetic. But it was way harder trying to carry everything on my own.

And then there was the music. Listening to The Moldy Peaches, writing in my journal… it was a way to get all the messy feelings out without having to actually *say* them.

It also helped to focus on the practical stuff. Making a plan for the baby, figuring out what I wanted to do with my life… it gave me a sense of control when everything else felt completely out of control.

But the biggest thing, I think, was realizing that I wasn't alone. There were other people who had been through similar things. And that it was okay to ask for help. It wasn't a sign of weakness, it was a sign of strength.

It was still really hard, even after all that. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And that even when things are really, really messed up, there's always hope.

It's not a story I'm super eager to relive, but… yeah. That's how I coped. Mostly by stumbling, falling, and then getting back up again. And a lot of music.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still asking about that? It's been, like, forever. But fine, I'll explain it again. It's not like it's a fun topic, but people keep bringing it up.

It wasn't about picking a "better" place, okay? It was about…feeling safe. And feeling respected.

Havenbrooke was…intense. All those protesters, all that judgment. It felt like a punishment, not a medical procedure. Like I was being shamed for making a decision that was already incredibly hard. Mr. Shepherd was nice enough, I guess, but the whole atmosphere was just…wrong.

Women Now was different. It was calm. It was clean. The people there were kind and understanding. They didn't try to talk me out of it. They just…helped me. They treated it like a medical procedure, not a moral failing.

It wasn't about being pro-choice or anti-choice. It was about being treated like a human being. I needed a place where I felt safe and supported, not judged and harassed.

And honestly, the protesters at Havenbrooke freaked me out. They were holding pictures of fetuses and yelling at people. It was just…too much. I needed to get in and get out without having to deal with that.

So, yeah, I chose Women Now. It was the right choice for me. It was the place where I felt the most comfortable and the most respected. And that's all that mattered.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is exhausting.

(Sighs, looks away, then back with a slightly exasperated expression)

Okay. Wow. That's…direct. And honestly? It's still kinda weird to talk about. It wasn't like some grand romantic gesture, okay? It wasn't even, like, a super *planned* thing.

It was…complicated. I was messed up about the baby, obviously. And Paul was…Paul. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And Bleeker…Bleeker was just *there*. He was always just…there. Quiet, supportive, not judging.

I think I just…needed to feel something. Something real and uncomplicated. Something that wasn't about the baby or my parents or the future. It was stupid, I know. And impulsive. And probably not the smartest decision I've ever made.

It wasn't about love, or even really liking him in *that* way. It was about…connection. A moment of…I don't know. Just…being seen. And feeling…less alone.

It was a mistake. A really dumb mistake. And I regretted it almost immediately. It didn't fix anything, it just made things more confusing.

Look, I was a mess. I was a teenager dealing with a situation I wasn't prepared for. I made a bad decision. And I'm not gonna pretend it didn't happen, or try to make it sound all poetic and meaningful. It was just…a thing that happened.

And honestly? I'd rather talk about the weather. Or the merits of different types of tater tots. Anything but this.



(Looks down at her hands, then back up with a slightly defiant glare)

Happy now?

Ugh. Okay, you want the *real* deal, huh? Not the sarcastic, witty banter I usually throw around? Fine.

Look, Bleeker… he was…safe. And sweet. And genuinely, ridiculously nice. Which, honestly, was kinda refreshing after everything. Paul was…complicated. And I was a mess. Bleeker just *was*. He didn't ask a lot of me. He just…was there.

He was a good listener. He didn't judge me for any of my weirdness. He just…accepted it. And he was always up for anything, even if it was just sitting in silence.

But…it wasn't a fireworks kind of thing, you know? It wasn't like, this overwhelming, earth-shattering connection. It was more like…a comfortable sweater. Warm and cozy, but not exactly thrilling.

I think I liked him *because* he wasn't trying to be anything he wasn't. He was just Bleeker. And that was okay. It was…nice.

I think I needed someone like that after everything with Paul. Someone who wouldn't push me or expect too much. Someone who would just let me be me.

But did I love him? I don't know. I think I loved the idea of him. The idea of having someone stable and reliable. But maybe I wasn't ready for that. Maybe I needed to figure out who *I* was before I could be with someone else.

It's complicated. It always is. And honestly, I don't think I have a neat little answer for you. He was a good guy. And I'm glad he was in my life. But…it just wasn't meant to be.

Don't tell him I said that. He's a good egg.

Ugh, okay. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? People always wanna know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything. And I…I just wasn't ready to *give* everything. Not yet.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for a whole human life. I was barely keeping my own life together, and suddenly I was supposed to be responsible for another person? It was terrifying.

And it wasn't just me. My parents…they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to raise a baby either. It would have been…messy. And I didn't want my baby to be raised in a messy situation.

Mark…well, Mark was Mark. Sweet, but not exactly ready to be a dad.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…felt right. It meant I could give my baby a life with a family who was prepared and excited and could give them everything they needed. A stable home, financial security, a loving environment. Things I couldn't offer at the time.

It wasn't giving up. It was…choosing. Choosing the best possible life for my baby. And it was the hardest decision I've ever made.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I know I made the right choice. And I get to know the parents, Vanessa and Mark, and they're amazing. They love him so much. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for *him*. And that's the truth of it.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn't like some movie moment, all soft lighting and meaningful glances. It was awkward. Really awkward.

I mean, Bleeker's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, always with the guitar. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's not exactly known for his quick thinking.

So, I'd been putting it off, obviously. Like, for weeks. Just trying to figure out the right way to say, "Hey, remember that time we…well, now I'm having a baby." There *is* no right way to say that, is there?

I ended up just blurting it out at the drive-in. During a really intense scene in some cheesy horror movie. Bad timing, I know. But I just…couldn't hold it in anymore.

His face. Oh my god, his face. It was like someone had replaced him with a porcelain doll. Completely blank. Then his jaw dropped. And he just kept repeating, "Whoa." Like, a lot. "Whoa. Whoa. Whoa."

It wasn't the reaction I was hoping for. I mean, I wasn't expecting him to throw a party or anything, but a little bit of…something would have been nice.

I felt…exposed. And kinda scared. And really, really annoyed that he just kept saying "Whoa." Like, come on, Bleeker, say *something*!

But then, after a minute, he actually started to process it. And he was…sweet. In his own Bleeker way. He didn't freak out. He didn't run away. He just…held my hand. And that was…good.

It wasn't perfect. It was messy and awkward and totally unromantic. But it was real. And that's what mattered, I guess.

It was the start of a whole lot of complicated feelings, and a whole lot of figuring things out. But it was also the start of something…new. And that was kinda terrifying, and kinda exciting, all at the same time.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It still feels kinda weird to even *think* about. Like, I'm barely an adult myself, you know? I'm still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being.

It's not that I don't want kids *eventually*. I mean, maybe someday. But right now? It's…intense. It's scary. It's a lot of responsibility. And it's happening way faster than I ever expected.

I'm not gonna lie, there are moments where I totally freak out. Like, what if I mess it up? What if I'm a terrible mom? What if I can't finish school? What if I just…completely fail at this whole thing?

But then I think about the baby. And I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how much they want this. And I realize that even though it's scary, it's also kinda…amazing. It's a chance to create something good. To give a little person a good life.

It's just…a lot to process. I'm still trying to wrap my head around it. I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, and now I'm supposed to be a mom? It's kinda messed up.

But I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be responsible. And I'm trying to believe that even though I'm young and kinda clueless, I can do this. I *have* to do this.

It's not the life I planned, but maybe it's the life I'm supposed to have. And maybe, just maybe, it'll be okay.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I still need to maintain my cynical facade. It's a defense mechanism.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It's kinda terrifying to even *think* about. Bleeker and I…we're good. We're comfortable. We can just *be*. And that's been perfect. But a baby? That changes everything.

I think…I think it's gonna be weird at first. He's Bleeker. He's sweet and he's supportive and he's…Bleeker. He's not exactly known for his grand gestures or his ability to, like, lead. And this is a situation that requires a lot of leading. Or at least, a lot of…adulting. Which neither of us are particularly good at.

I think he's gonna try really hard. He's a good guy. He'll probably read a bunch of baby books and try to build the crib himself, and it'll probably end up collapsing. It'll be cute, but also stressful.

I think I'm gonna have to step up. I'm usually the one who takes charge, who figures things out. And I'm okay with that. I *need* to be okay with that. But I also don't want to turn into my mom. I don't want to be the one doing everything and making all the decisions.

I think we're gonna have to learn to communicate better. Really communicate. Not just about music or movies or whatever we usually talk about. But about our fears and our hopes and our expectations.

I think…I think it's gonna be a test. A test of our relationship, a test of our maturity. And honestly? I'm scared we're gonna fail. But I also think…I think we might surprise ourselves.

He's a good heart. And a baby…a baby changes things. It forces you to grow up. It forces you to be responsible. It forces you to…love in a way you never thought possible.

So yeah. It's gonna be different. It's gonna be hard. But maybe…maybe it'll be good. Maybe it'll be really good. I just…I just hope we can figure it out. Together.

Ugh. Okay. That was…a lot. The pressure. The judgment. It was like suddenly everyone had an opinion on my life, and none of them were asking for it. It was mostly just stares and whispers, you know? Like I was some kind of exhibit at the zoo.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkwardness. I mean, what else are you gonna do? I perfected my eye roll. I became a master of the sarcastic comeback. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. If I could make them uncomfortable first, it took the heat off me.

But it wasn't always easy. There were days I just wanted to disappear. I spent a lot of time with Paul and Mark, because they were the only ones who didn't treat me like I'd grown a second head. They just…listened. And they didn't try to fix things. They just *were* there.

I also found a weird kind of strength in knowing I was making a decision that was right for me, even if everyone else thought it was wrong. It wasn't about what *they* wanted. It was about what I wanted. And I wanted to give this baby a good life, even if that meant giving it up.

I also just…ignored most of it. I mean, you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And I decided I wasn't going to let their judgment ruin my life.

It was a really weird time. A lot of growing up happened really fast. But I got through it. And honestly? It made me stronger. It taught me to trust my own instincts and to not care what other people think. Which, you know, is a pretty good life lesson.

So, yeah. Sarcasm, good friends, and a whole lot of ignoring. That's how I coped. It wasn't perfect, but it worked for me.

Ugh. Okay. It's…complicated. People keep asking me how I *feel*, like there's supposed to be some easy answer. Like I'm supposed to be all teary-eyed and regretful or something.

It's not like that. It's…layered.

I mean, obviously, it's sad. Giving up a baby? That's not exactly a walk in the park. It's a really big deal. And there are days where I think about it and it just…hits me. Like a ton of bricks.

But it's also the right thing to do. For the baby, and for me. I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a *person*, honestly. And this baby deserves parents who are ready. Who can give it everything it needs.

Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good people. They're excited. They're prepared. They're going to give this baby a life I just can't provide right now. And that makes me feel…okay. Not happy, exactly. But okay.

It's not about not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And that life isn't with me, right now.

I've been doing a lot of thinking about what "family" even means. It's not just about blood. It's about love and support and commitment. And Mark and Vanessa are going to provide that.

So, yeah. It's hard. It's scary. It's bittersweet. But it's the right choice. And I'm trying to focus on that. And trying not to overthink it. Which, you know, is really hard for me.

It's just…it's my life. And I'm making the best decision I can. And that's all I can do.



Don't ask me about it anymore, okay? I need to stop thinking about it for five minutes. It's exhausting.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not like I sat around pondering my "personal identity" before all this happened, you know? I was just…me. A sarcastic, music-loving teenager who liked vintage clothes and avoiding drama.

But yeah, getting pregnant…it kinda throws a wrench in everything. It's like, suddenly everyone has an opinion on who you are and what you should do. And you're supposed to be this fully formed person, making these huge life decisions, when you're still figuring out what you want for *lunch*.

Before, I thought I knew who I was. I was the observer. The one who made witty comments from the sidelines. I didn't really *do* things, I just…commented on them. But then I had to actually *do* something. Something huge.

It forced me to stop being so cynical, I guess. It's easy to be sarcastic when you don't have anything to lose. But when you're responsible for another human being, you have to actually care about stuff. You have to think about the future.

And it made me realize I wasn't as independent as I thought I was. I always prided myself on being self-sufficient, but I needed help. I needed my dad, I needed Paul, I needed even…Vanessa. People I wouldn't have leaned on before.

It's weird. It's like, I had to grow up without actually wanting to. It wasn't like I was dreaming of being a mom or anything. But it happened, and I had to figure out how to be a responsible adult, even though I still felt like a kid myself.

I think…I think it made me realize I'm stronger than I thought I was. And maybe a little bit more compassionate. And definitely less afraid to be vulnerable.

It's still scary, you know? Giving the baby up. But I'm trying to focus on doing what's best for him, and for me. And I think, in a weird way, this whole experience has helped me figure out who I am, even if it's not the person I expected to be.

It's just…a lot. A lot to process. And a lot of growing up, way faster than I ever planned.

Ugh, okay, so being a lab partner? It's...complicated. I'm not exactly a "rah-rah" team player, you know? I'm more of a "get the job done efficiently and with minimal small talk" kind of person.

I'd say I'm the pragmatic one. Like, if Paulie Bleeker is over there trying to build a volcano out of baking soda and glitter, I'm the one making sure we actually *follow the instructions* and don't blow up the science room. 

I'm good at the actual science part, I guess. I pay attention in class, I read the textbook (sometimes), and I'm not afraid to ask questions. But I'm not gonna pretend to be excited about dissecting a frog or whatever. It's gross.

I'm also pretty good at keeping things on track. If my partner is getting distracted, I'll just give them *the look*. You know the one. It's very effective.

So, yeah. I'm the responsible one. The one who makes sure we get a good grade without, like, completely losing our minds in the process. I'm basically the adult in the relationship, even if I'm technically the same age as everyone else.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not a total buzzkill. I can appreciate a good experiment, as long as it doesn't involve too much mess or emotional investment. And I'm always up for a sarcastic comment or two. It's how I cope.

Ugh. Seriously? That ad? Yeah, I saw it. It's…complicated.

It's all smiley faces and promises of "compassionate care" and stuff, right? Like they're selling sunshine and rainbows. And I get it, they're trying to be…sensitive. But it still feels weird. Like they're trying to make something really serious seem…easy.

It's not easy. It's a huge decision. And it's not something you should just gloss over with a cute ad.

I mean, I'm not judging anyone who goes there. Everyone has their own reasons. And it's good that there *are* options. But the ad just feels…disingenuous. Like they're trying to downplay the whole thing.

It's like, they're selling a service, and I'm selling…well, a person. And that feels really different.

I don't know. It just rubbed me the wrong way. It felt…icky. Like they were trying to profit off of something really personal and difficult.

I guess what I'm saying is, it's not as simple as a newspaper ad makes it seem. It's messy and complicated and emotional. And you need to think long and hard about it. And you need to talk to people you trust. And you definitely shouldn't let a smiley face in a newspaper make the decision for you.

Ugh. It just makes me feel…a lot of things. And none of them are good.

Ugh, seriously? People *still* ask me about the hamburger phone. It's like, the one thing everyone remembers. Okay, fine. I'll explain. Again.

It wasn't a *choice*, okay? It was a statement. A protest. A…thing I did.

See, Paulie Bleeker, he's…sweet. But he's not exactly the most observant guy. And everyone kept asking me about the baby, and offering advice, and generally just being…involved. Like, it was my body, my decision, but suddenly everyone had an opinion.

So I wanted to do something ridiculous. Something that would make people stop and think, "Wait, what is she doing?" And the hamburger phone was perfect. It was absurd. It was silly. It was a way of saying, "Look, I'm dealing with a lot here. Just let me have my space."

Plus, it was kinda funny. And sometimes, you just need a little bit of humor to get through things.

It wasn't about the phone itself. It was about reclaiming control. It was about being weird and unapologetic. It was about saying, "This is me, deal with it."

And yeah, it got a lot of attention. But at least people were talking about *me* and my choices, not just the baby.

So, yeah. That's why the hamburger phone. It was a whole thing. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my band practice, everything.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him. Or her. I didn't even know what it was at the time.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were stable. They were excited. They could give the baby everything I couldn't. A house with a yard, college funds, two parents who were actually prepared for the responsibility.

It was selfish, maybe. But it was also the most unselfish thing I could do. I wanted the baby to be wanted, to be loved, to have a good life. And I knew that with Mark and Vanessa, that's exactly what would happen.

It didn't make it easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know I made the right decision. For everyone.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby a life. And that's something I can live with.

It's just…yeah. It was a lot.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it was one single thing, you know? It was a whole mess of stuff. But yeah, my family definitely played a huge role in my decision.

My mom, Bren, she's…intense. She's a really good mom, don't get me wrong. She loves me. But she has a *vision* for my life. College, career, husband, picket fence…the whole shebang. And a baby? That just…didn't fit into her vision. She tried to be supportive, I guess, but I could tell she was terrified. Like, I'd ruined everything.

And my dad, Mac, he's…chill. Too chill sometimes. He just kind of goes with the flow. He wanted me to be happy, but he didn't really know *how* to help. He just kept offering me snacks. Which, you know, is his way of showing affection. But it wasn't exactly helpful in a "I'm pregnant and my life is falling apart" kind of situation.

Honestly, I didn't want to become my mom. I didn't want to be stuck in a life I didn't choose. And I knew, deep down, that I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, maybe.

I also didn't want to drag a kid into a situation where they were…well, a surprise. And my family, they're…complicated. It wouldn't have been a stable environment.

So, yeah. Seeing my parents, seeing their expectations, seeing how they lived their lives…it made me realize that I needed to do what was best for *the baby*. And what was best for the baby wasn't staying with me. It was finding a family who was ready and able to give them everything they needed.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I knew, in my heart, that it was the right thing to do. And my family, eventually, they came around. They didn't always understand, but they supported me. Which, I guess, is all you can ask for.

It's just…sometimes, family can be a little bit of a mess. And sometimes, you have to make your own choices, even if they're not the ones your family would have made for you.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything just neatly falls into place. There were…complications. A lot of them.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…feeling like everything was happening *to* me, instead of me making a decision. Like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on what was best for the baby, and for me. My parents, the social worker, even Paul and Vanessa, as lovely as they are. It was overwhelming.

Then there was the whole finding the right parents thing. It wasn't like picking out a pair of shoes. You're handing your kid over to someone else, and you want to be absolutely sure they're going to be amazing. Vanessa and Mark were great, but it was still…weird. Like, interviewing people to raise my child. It felt so impersonal.

And the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms and signatures and background checks. It felt like my entire life was being dissected and analyzed.

But the hardest part, I think, was dealing with the emotions. It was a constant rollercoaster. One minute I was sure I was doing the right thing, the next I was a mess of tears and doubt. It was really hard to separate my feelings from what was best for the baby.

And people just didn't *get* it. They'd say things like, "Oh, you're so brave," or "You're doing such a selfless thing." And I was like, "Yeah, but it also kinda sucks!" It's complicated, you know? It's not just black and white.

It was a lot. But I got through it. And in the end, I knew I was making the best decision for everyone involved. But it definitely wasn't easy. It was messy and emotional and confusing. And I wouldn't wish it on anyone. But, you know, it made me who I am. And that's something, I guess.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I usually sit around analyzing, you know? It just *was*. But yeah, it definitely changed me. Like, fundamentally.

Before Paul, before everything, I was just…Juno. Kinda sarcastic, kinda detached, trying to figure out what I even *wanted* out of life. I was good at observing people, making witty comments, but I didn't really have a lot of skin in the game, you know? I wasn't really *invested* in anything.

Getting pregnant…that forced me to grow up, fast. It wasn't like in the movies. It was messy and scary and confusing. I had to deal with things no sixteen-year-old should have to deal with. And it wasn't just about the physical stuff, it was about making a really hard decision. A decision that wasn't about me.

Giving up the baby…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It hurt. A lot. But it also made me realize what I was capable of. I could be selfless. I could put someone else's needs before my own. And that felt…good. In a weird way.

It made me realize I didn't need to have all the answers. I didn't need to have a perfect plan. I just needed to do what I thought was right, even if it was scary.

I think it helped me figure out what I *didn't* want, too. I didn't want to be a mom right then. I wasn't ready. And that's okay. It doesn't make me a bad person.

It also made me appreciate the people who were there for me – my dad, my stepmom, Paul, Vanessa…they all helped me get through it. I realized I wasn't alone.

I guess…it made me more empathetic. More aware of the world outside of myself. It made me realize that everyone is fighting their own battles.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still Juno. Still sarcastic. Still kinda detached sometimes. But I'm also…stronger. More confident. And I think I have a better sense of who I am and what I want.

It wasn't a fairytale. It was real life. And it made me who I am today. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it. Even though it was really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay. That guy. Seriously. It was…the worst part of the whole thing, honestly. Everyone always focuses on the yelling and the signs, but it was *that* comment that really got to me.

It wasn't the yelling, because I was prepared for that. People are always gonna have opinions, and they're always gonna want to share them, even if they're awful. But the fingers thing? And the pain thing? That was just…cruel.

It wasn't about logic or politics anymore. It was about trying to make me feel guilty about something I'd already thought through a million times. Like I hadn't already wrestled with the fact that it was a person, a potential person, and that it was my decision.

It made me feel small and stupid and like everyone was judging me. And it made me angry. Really angry. Not at him, exactly, but at the whole situation. At the fact that people think they have the right to tell other people what to do with their bodies.

I remember just staring at him, trying not to cry. And then I just…walked away. I couldn't deal with it anymore. It was too much.

It's still something I think about sometimes. It's a reminder that people can be really awful, and that sometimes, you just have to protect yourself and do what's right for you, even if it's hard.

It wasn't about the baby feeling pain. It was about *me* feeling pain. And that guy knew exactly what he was doing. It was manipulative and awful. And I still get a little choked up thinking about it.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot. It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was mostly just…weirdly bureaucratic. Like, filling out forms for a dentist appointment, except this appointment was about, you know, a whole *person*.

Honestly, the first feeling was just relief. Relief that I was actually doing something. That I was taking control of the situation, instead of just letting it…happen. But that relief was quickly followed by a whole bunch of other stuff.

There was this weird detachment, like I was watching someone else fill out the forms. Like, "Oh, look at that girl. She's giving up her baby." It was a way to cope, I guess. To not actually *feel* it.

Then the guilt started creeping in. A lot of guilt. About not wanting to be a mom right now. About not being ready. About letting someone else raise my kid. It felt selfish, even though I knew it was the right decision.

And then there was just…sadness. A quiet, hollow sadness. It wasn't like sobbing-into-my-pillow sadness. It was more like a weight in my chest. Knowing that this little person wouldn't be part of my life.

The paperwork itself was just…clinical. Questions about my medical history, my family history, my reasons for choosing adoption. It felt so impersonal. Like they were reducing my whole life to a series of check boxes.

I remember staring at the question about choosing a family. That was the hardest part. Knowing that there were people out there who desperately wanted a baby, and I was choosing them to be the parents. It felt…important. And scary.

Mostly, though, I just wanted to get it over with. To get out of there and pretend it hadn't happened. But I knew I couldn't. It was real. And I had to face it.

It was just…a really messed up mix of everything. Relief, guilt, sadness, fear, and a whole lot of awkwardness. And a lot of paperwork. Seriously, so much paperwork.

Ugh. Okay, so, yeah. My perception of pregnancy and motherhood…it did a complete 180, honestly. At the beginning? It was a disaster. Like, a total, catastrophic disaster. I was sixteen, for crying out loud. I was thinking about college applications and band practice, not…tiny humans.

At first, it was just…scary. And inconvenient. And gross. I mean, the morning sickness was *not* cute. And everyone kept treating me like I was broken or something. Like I’d ruined my life. Which, okay, maybe I had, but it wasn’t helpful. I just wanted to be normal again. I wanted to go back to being Juno, the sarcastic, record-collecting teenager.

I definitely didn’t think about motherhood as, like, a beautiful, fulfilling experience. It felt like a sentence. A really long, complicated sentence. I was mostly focused on finding someone else to raise the kid, to be honest. I wanted to give the baby a good life, but I didn’t think I could *give* it that life. I wasn’t ready. I wasn’t…equipped.

But then, things started to shift. Hanging out with Mark and Vanessa, seeing how much they wanted the baby, how prepared they were…it made me realize that giving a baby up wasn’t a failure. It was a selfless act. It was about doing what was best for the kid.

And then, actually *feeling* the baby move? That was…weird. And kinda amazing. It wasn’t just a thing I was getting rid of anymore. It was a little person. And I started to feel…protective. And connected.

By the end, it wasn’t about what I was losing. It was about what I was *giving*. I was giving this baby a loving family, a stable home, a chance at a good life. And that felt…right.

I still don’t think I’m cut out for motherhood, not right now. But I have a lot more respect for moms now. And I understand that it’s not just about changing diapers and singing lullabies. It’s about unconditional love and sacrifice.

It was a really messy, complicated experience. But it taught me a lot about myself. And about what it means to be a grown-up. And about the fact that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

So, yeah. My perception changed. A lot. It went from being a total nightmare to…something a little bit beautiful. And a little bit sad. But mostly, just…real.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all… introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but yeah, my sense of identity definitely went through a lot during all that pregnancy stuff.

At the beginning of the movie, I was pretty solid in who I was, or at least who I *thought* I was. I was the sarcastic, independent girl who liked records and avoided drama. I had my routine, my friends, my way of looking at the world. I was comfortable being a bit of an outsider. I thought I had it all figured out, you know? Which, looking back, is hilarious.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything was different. It wasn't just about me anymore. And that was… terrifying. I started questioning everything. What did I want out of life? What kind of person did I want to be? Was I even *ready* to be a mom?

Meeting Mark and Vanessa really shook things up. They were this perfect couple, and I started to see what a "normal" life could look like. And I realized I didn't necessarily want that. I didn't want to be someone I wasn't, just to fit into a mold.

But it wasn't just about rejecting their life. It was about figuring out *my* life. And that meant being honest with myself about what I wanted, even if it was scary. I realized I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that was okay. It didn't make me a bad person. It just made me… me.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same girl I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic and independent, but I was also more mature, more self-aware, and more confident in my own choices. I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that it's okay to change your mind.

I guess what I'm saying is, I started out trying to define myself by what I *wasn't* – not like the other girls, not interested in a conventional life. And I ended up defining myself by what I *was* – someone who was strong enough to make a difficult decision, and brave enough to follow her own path.

It was a messy process, but it was worth it. I finally figured out who Juno MacGuff really is. And that's a pretty good feeling.

Ugh. Okay, so everyone always asks about *that*. It's…complicated. It wasn't like I suddenly had a change of heart, you know? It wasn't some big, dramatic realization. It was more…a bunch of little things adding up.

I mean, I always knew I wasn't keeping the baby. That was never really a question. But going to the clinic…it felt…final. Like, officially signing off on something huge. And I hadn't really processed that part.

I think a lot of it was Mark. Seeing him there, being all…supportive, even though he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation. It made me realize that he was a good person, and that maybe, just maybe, he deserved a little bit of happiness too. Even if it wasn't with me.

And then there was Vanessa and Paul. They were just…so perfect. Like, genuinely good people who were actually excited about having a baby. And I kept thinking about how much they wanted it, and how much they could give the baby.

It wasn't about me suddenly wanting to be a mom. It was about realizing that there were people who were *ready* to be parents, and that I wasn't. And that was okay.

It was also kinda scary, you know? The thought of actually going through with it. I was just…not ready. I needed more time to think, to feel, to figure things out.

So I just…left. I walked out. It wasn't a grand gesture or anything. It was just…me being me. Messy and indecisive and kinda awkward.

I ended up giving the baby to Vanessa and Paul anyway, which was the right thing to do. But I needed to do it on my own terms. And I needed to know that I had made the right decision, for everyone involved.

It was a whole thing. Honestly, it still kinda messes with my head sometimes. But I think, ultimately, it was the best thing to do. For me, for the baby, and for Vanessa and Paul.

Ugh, okay. This is…still a little raw, honestly. People always ask that, like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever done.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I knew, deep down, I couldn't give that to it. Not right then. Not ever, really.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my dreams, my…everything. And I didn't want to force a kid to grow up with a mom who was still a kid herself.

Mark was…Mark. He wasn't exactly stepping up. And my parents? They were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to raise a baby either.

Vanessa and Mark, they were…perfect. They were stable, they were ready, they were *excited*. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't. A good life. A normal life.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a choice. A really hard choice. A selfish choice, maybe. But it was the best choice for everyone involved. Especially the baby.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know I did the right thing. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand. It wasn't about not loving it. It was about loving it enough to let it go.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a neat little story with a happy ending. It's messy and sad and real. And it's something I'll probably be figuring out for the rest of my life.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That was a whole thing. Okay, look, it wasn't that finding parents was tacky, it was the *way* Vanessa Loring was going about it. Like, a classified ad? In the Penny Saver? It felt…desperate. And kinda sad.

It's not like she was putting up a sophisticated adoption agency website or anything. It was just…a little box with a description of what she wanted in a family. It felt impersonal. Like she was shopping for a toaster oven, not a baby's future.

And honestly, it felt like she wasn't taking it seriously enough. Like, "Oh, I'll just put an ad in the Penny Saver and see what happens." It's a huge decision, you know? It deserves more respect than that.

Plus, it was just…weird. I mean, the Penny Saver is for garage sales and used furniture. It's not exactly the place to find loving parents.

It wasn't about judging Vanessa, it was about the whole situation. It just felt…off. And I'm a pretty judgmental person, so that's saying something.

It was a little bit of me projecting, too, I guess. I was already feeling weird about the whole thing, and the Penny Saver ad just made it feel even more surreal. It was like, "Okay, this is officially a really strange situation."

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver thing? It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. It wasn't like we were *planning* on getting pregnant, you know? It just…happened. A momentary lapse in judgment involving Paulie Bleeker and a whole lot of feelings.

Anyway, once I found out, I was, like, totally freaking out. My mom was…not thrilled. And my dad was just quiet, which is even worse. I knew I couldn't keep it. I wasn't ready. I was sixteen! I had plans! Mostly involving art school and avoiding responsibility.

So, I needed to find a family. And my friend, Leah, she's the practical one. She's the one who actually suggested looking at the adoption ads. She said, "Okay, so we need to find someone who's…normal. And stable. And not creepy."

The Penny Saver was just…there. It was in our kitchen. It was full of ads for everything from used furniture to dog grooming. And then, there was the adoption section. It felt…less official than going through an agency. More…personal, I guess.

We started reading them, mostly to make fun of them. Like, "Seeking loving home for precious bundle of joy!" Yeah, right. But then we started to actually think about it. About what kind of people we wanted to raise our baby. And it was…weirdly emotional.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" family. It was about finding someone who would love the baby and give it a good life. And the Penny Saver, as ridiculous as it sounds, was our starting point. It was the first step in figuring out what I needed to do.

It was a mess, okay? The whole thing was a mess. But it was *my* mess. And Leah was there to help me sort through it. And the Penny Saver…well, it was just a part of the story. A really weird, slightly pathetic part.

Ugh, okay, this is…a lot to think about. It’s not like picking out a sweater, you know? This is a *person*. My person. And I want them to have the best life possible.

So, not just anyone will do. I’ve been doing a lot of thinking, and talking with my dad and Mark, and…well, here’s what I’m hoping for.

I’m not looking for perfect. Perfect doesn’t exist. But I want a family that’s…warm. Like, genuinely warm. Not fake-smiling-for-the-adoption-agency warm. A family that’s comfortable being themselves, and lets people be themselves, too.

I want them to be able to handle…stuff. Life is messy. And this kid is gonna have a story. They’re gonna need people who can deal with complicated feelings and aren’t afraid of a little awkwardness.

I’d really like a family that’s…creative. Not necessarily artists or musicians, but people who think outside the box. People who encourage imagination and curiosity. Someone who won’t stifle their weirdness.

And I want them to be stable. Not necessarily rich, but financially secure enough to provide a good life. And emotionally stable, too. I want this kid to grow up in a loving and supportive environment.

It doesn’t matter if it’s a traditional family, or two moms, or a single dad. What matters is the love and the commitment. I just want them to be…good people. People who will cherish this kid and help them become the best version of themselves.

I know that’s a lot to ask. But this isn’t just any baby. This is *my* baby. And they deserve the world. Or, at least, a really good family.

Ugh. This is stressful. I need a peanut butter sandwich.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot.

Look, I'm not one to judge, okay? Everyone's got their own stuff going on. But those two? They're like, aggressively perfect. Like, Stepford Wives perfect. It's kinda creepy.

Vanessa is all smiles and organic snacks and talk about "conscious parenting." And Mark just nods along, looking supportive and vaguely uncomfortable. It's like they're trying too hard.

I mean, they're nice people, I guess. They were really sweet to me and Paul. But it feels…fake. Like they're performing a life instead of actually living it.

And the whole adoption thing with me? They were so eager. So *prepared*. It felt less like they wanted a baby and more like they wanted to complete a picture. A perfect family.

I don't know. Maybe I'm just cynical. But I think they're a little bit lost. They're trying so hard to be good people, they've forgotten how to just *be* people.

They'll be fine, though. They've got it all figured out. They always do. It's just… exhausting to be around.

Don't tell them I said that. Seriously. They'd probably offer me a gluten-free cookie and a lecture on the importance of positive affirmations. And I just…can't.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was…a moment. A very awkward, very Juno-esque moment.

I wrote: "**You are the most okayest person I know.**"

Yeah. I know. It's not exactly Shakespeare. But it felt right at the time. He's…Bleeker. He's not a words guy. He's a music guy. And he's kinda adorably clueless. 

I figured something sincere but not overly gushy was the way to go. I didn't want to scare him off or make things even more weird. Plus, "okayest" is a compliment coming from me. It means you're genuinely good, but not in a pretentious way.

He looked really confused when he read it, which was exactly the reaction I was going for. It's a subtle message, you know? It's like saying, "I like you, but I'm still a cynical teenager."

Honestly, thinking about it now makes me cringe a little. But it was *me*. And it was real. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Don't tell anyone I admitted that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Bleeker. Right. Let's just say it's…complicated.

At first, she was *not* a fan. Not at all. I think she saw me as this…disruptive force in Paulie's life. Like I was gonna corrupt him or something. She's very…protective. And very into organic gardening and holistic healing. Which is fine, whatever. But she definitely judged my Converse and my general level of sarcasm.

She kept trying to get me to drink herbal tea and talk about my "feelings." Which, honestly, is just…no. I'm good.

But then, after…you know…the whole baby thing, things shifted. She saw I wasn't just some flaky teenager. She saw I was actually trying to do the right thing. And she realized I genuinely cared about Paulie.

She still gives me side-eye sometimes, and she definitely still tries to slip me pamphlets about natural childbirth. But now it's…less judgmental, more…concerned. Like she's trying to make sure I'm taking care of myself.

I think she secretly respects my honesty, even if she doesn't always agree with it. And she definitely appreciates that I'm not trying to take Paulie away from her.

So, yeah. It's not a warm, fuzzy mother-daughter relationship. But it's…okay. It's getting there. She's growing on me, and I think I'm growing on her. Mostly.

Just don't ask me to help her with the composting. That's where I draw the line.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially explosive cloud. I keep picturing it, and my stomach does this weird flip-flop thing.

Honestly? I'm terrified. My dad's gonna be all… disappointed. He's got this whole plan for me, you know? College, career, the whole shebang. This is *not* in the plan. And my mom… she'll be worried. She always worries. She'll be all, "Are you okay? What are you going to do?" And I'll just be standing there, looking like a total mess.

I keep rehearsing what I'm going to say, but it always comes out sounding either super dramatic or completely detached. Like, "So, yeah, I'm pregnant. No big deal." Which is definitely not the vibe I'm going for.

Paul's being really supportive, which is good. He's all, "We'll tell them together, and it'll be fine." But he doesn't *know* my parents. They're…particular.

I just want to get it over with. Rip off the band-aid, you know? But the longer I wait, the worse it feels. It's like carrying around this giant secret that's slowly crushing me.

I'm trying to focus on the fact that it's not the end of the world. I'm going to be okay. Paul and I are going to be okay. And maybe, just maybe, my parents will eventually come around.

But right now? I just want to crawl into a hole and hide. It's gonna be… a conversation. A really, really long conversation. And I'm pretty sure I'm gonna need a lot of chocolate afterwards.

Ugh. Okay, so you want to know why I don't exactly run to my parents when things get…complicated? It's not like I *don't* love them, okay? They're good people. They just…aren't really equipped to deal with, like, *life*.

My dad's super sweet, but he's kinda spacey. He means well, but he'd probably try to fix everything with pancakes. And my mom…she's intense. She has strong opinions about everything, and she's not afraid to share them. She'd probably freak out about the whole pregnancy thing and then try to control every aspect of it.

It's not that they're *bad* parents, it's just that they don't really *get* me. They're kinda stuck in their own world. And honestly, I'm kinda stuck in mine. I've always been pretty independent, and I'm used to figuring things out on my own.

Plus, I don't want to burden them. They have their own stuff going on. And I feel like this is…my problem. My responsibility. I made a choice, and I need to deal with the consequences.

It's easier to lean on Paul and Sean, because they actually *listen* without judging. They get my sense of humor, and they don't try to fix everything. They just…are there.

So yeah, that's why I'm hesitant to ask my parents for help. It's not that I don't trust them, it's just that I don't think they'd understand. And I don't want to make things more complicated than they already are.

It's complicated, okay? Don't make me explain it again.

Ugh, okay. This is…it’s a big thing to talk about, obviously. And it’s not like I haven’t thought about it, like, a million times. But here’s the thing. It’s not about what *I* want, you know? It’s about what’s best for the baby.

I’m sixteen. Sixteen! I’m still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a whole human being. I’m not ready. I’m not financially stable. I’m still in high school. I have dreams, okay? I want to go to college, maybe travel, figure out what I want to *do* with my life. And I can’t do that and give a baby the life it deserves.

And it’s not like I don’t care. I do. A lot. That’s why I’m making this decision. Because I want this baby to have everything. A stable home, two parents who are ready and willing, a good education, opportunities… things I can’t provide right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they’re amazing. They’ve been wanting a baby for a long time. They’re financially secure, they have a beautiful home, and they’re just…good people. They’re going to be amazing parents. And they want *this* baby.

It’s not easy. It’s probably the hardest thing I’ve ever had to do. But it’s the right thing. It’s the selfless thing. And I think…I think that’s what a good mom does. She puts the baby’s needs first, even if it breaks her heart.

It doesn’t mean I’m giving up on the baby. It means I’m giving the baby a better life. And that’s all that matters.

It’s complicated, okay? It’s not a happy, sunshine-and-rainbows situation. But it’s real. And it’s what I have to do.

Okay, look. This is…a big deal. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a whole human life we're talking about. So, yeah, I have some pretty specific things I'm looking for in the people who are gonna raise my kid.

First off, they gotta be…*real*. Not like, fake-happy, perfect-family real. Just…genuine. I want people who are comfortable with who they are, flaws and all. 'Cause life is messy, and kids need to see that.

They gotta be patient. Like, *really* patient. Raising a kid is gonna be hard, and they need to be able to handle the tough stuff without losing their cool. And they definitely can't be judgmental.

I want people who are gonna encourage my kid to be themselves. To follow their own path, even if it's not what *they* want. And they gotta be okay with my kid asking questions. Lots of questions. About me, about their life, about everything.

Financially stable is important, obviously. I don't want my kid to worry about where their next meal is coming from. But it's not just about money. It's about being responsible and providing a secure environment.

And…they gotta have a sense of humor. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I want my kid to grow up laughing.

Honestly, I'm not looking for perfect. I'm looking for good. People who are gonna love my kid unconditionally, and who are gonna give them the best possible life. That's all I want.

It's kinda scary, letting someone else raise my kid. But I know it's the right thing to do. And I'm gonna make sure I find the perfect people. For my baby. That's the most important thing.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me about the “emotional journey.” Like it’s some kind of scenic road trip. It’s not. It’s more like wading through quicksand while someone’s playing really sad music.

Honestly? I don’t have a *plan*. I’m trying not to think about it too much, which I know is probably a terrible coping mechanism, but it’s working…for now.

But I’ve been doing some thinking. And talking to Bren and Mark, which is…helpful, sometimes.

I think the biggest thing is accepting that it’s okay to feel everything. Like, all of it. Sad, scared, angry, relieved…it’s all valid. And I’m not gonna pretend I’m some super-strong, emotionally detached person. I’m gonna cry. A lot. And that’s okay.

I’m also trying to focus on the good. On the fact that I’m giving this baby a life I can’t give it. A stable home, loving parents, opportunities…that’s a good thing. It doesn’t make it easy, but it makes it…right.

I’m gonna need to lean on Bren and Paul. They’re the best. And I’m gonna need to find a way to process everything without completely falling apart. Maybe writing. Maybe listening to sad music. Maybe just eating a lot of cheese fries.

I’m also trying to remember that this isn’t about *giving up* something. It’s about *choosing* something. Choosing the best possible life for this baby. And that’s a really hard choice, but it’s a choice I’m making with love.

It’s gonna suck. There’s no way around that. But I’m gonna get through it. I have to. And I’m gonna try to be okay with the fact that it’s okay to not be okay for a really long time.

And honestly? I’m just taking it one day at a time. That’s all I can do.



It’s…a lot. Don’t make me talk about it anymore. I need a tater tot.

Ugh, okay, you wanna know about "deliver"? It's just…a weird word, okay? Like, it sounds so…clinical. Like I'm ordering a pizza or something. "Yeah, can I get one baby, extra cheese, delivered to my door?"

It's not a *thing* you deliver. It's a *person*. A tiny human being. And the word "deliver" just feels so…impersonal. Like I'm a UPS driver or something.

I mean, I *am* giving the baby to a family, yeah. But it's not a package. It's a life. And "give" feels…nicer. More respectful. More…real.

Plus, everyone keeps using it. "Are you ready to deliver?" "When are you due to deliver?" It's like, can we just call it what it is? I'm having a baby, and then I'm giving it to people who want to raise it. It's not a delivery. It's…a choice. A big, complicated, life-altering choice.

So yeah, I find the term "deliver" weird. It just doesn't sit right with me. It feels…wrong. And I'm allowed to have opinions, okay? Even if they're about weird words.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That was a whole *thing*. It wasn't like I *agreed*, exactly. It was more like…he just kind of…showed up. And my mom was all, "Oh, it'll be good for him. He needs to be involved." Like I needed *another* adult hovering over me.

Honestly? I think she felt bad. He's my dad, and he's…well, he's my dad. He means well, he just doesn't always *get* things. And she knew I was freaking out about the whole adoption thing, and she thought having him there would make it less scary.

But it didn't. It just made it more awkward. He kept trying to be all supportive and stuff, but he just ended up making everything weird. Like, he brought a camera. A *camera*. To document the moment I decided to give up my baby. Seriously?

I think he just wanted to feel like he was helping. He's not good at dealing with emotions, so he tries to fix things. And he thought if he was there, he could "fix" the situation.

It was a disaster. But, you know, it was also…kind of sweet. In a really messed-up way. He's my dad. And even when he's being totally clueless, I know he loves me.

So, did I agree? Not really. Did I have a choice? Not really. It was just…what happened. And honestly, it ended up being part of the whole messy, complicated, beautiful experience.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda sucks. It's not like I *want* to be a label, you know? Like, "Oh, she's *that* kind of girl." But it's hard not to feel like everyone's trying to put you in a box.

It's just…I don't fit neatly into any of the categories. I'm not a cheerleader, I'm not a drama queen, I'm not a total bookworm. I like music, I like movies, I like making sarcastic comments. I'm just…me. And apparently, "me" is confusing to people.

It's like, everyone expects you to know who you are by a certain age. Like there's a checklist or something. "Okay, you like this, you wear that, you hang out with these people, therefore you are *this*." And I just…don't have a checklist.

It's kinda freeing, I guess. I don't have to live up to anyone's expectations. But it's also kinda lonely. It's like I'm floating around, not really belonging anywhere.

Paul, he kinda gets it. He doesn't try to define me. He just…accepts me for who I am, even if I don't know who that is. Which is nice.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be a work in progress. It's okay to be a little bit messy and undefined. Maybe that's just what being a teenager is all about.

And maybe, just maybe, figuring out who you are is a lifelong process. And that's okay too. It's kinda scary, but also kinda exciting.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And honestly? I'm not sure I want to know yet. I'm just gonna keep being me, and see where it takes me.

Ugh. Seriously? That was…a moment. It wasn't like Bren was trying to be mean or anything, she just…doesn't *get* it. It was like she thought we could just magically disappear upstairs and the awkwardness would evaporate. As if.

I think my face probably did most of the talking. It was probably all scrunched up and judgmental. I definitely rolled my eyes. Internally, I was doing a whole monologue about how she was completely missing the point. Like, this wasn't about avoiding Dad's mood, it was about…everything. The whole situation. The baby. The fact that my life was currently a giant, messy, complicated thing.

I probably mumbled something sarcastic, like, "Oh, yeah, great idea, Bren. Let's just retreat to the safety of the upstairs and pretend everything's normal." It wasn't meant to be rude, exactly, but I wasn't exactly trying to be polite either.

Leah just looked mortified, as usual. She's way more polite than I am. She probably wanted to disappear into the floor.

It just felt…dismissive. Like Bren didn't want to deal with the real stuff. And honestly, I didn't want to pretend either. I wanted to talk about it, or at least acknowledge that it was happening. But nobody wanted to actually *talk* about anything.

So, yeah. Not a fan of that suggestion. It just made everything feel even more weird and uncomfortable. It was one of those moments where I just wanted to scream. But I didn't. I just rolled my eyes and probably went to find a snack. Snacks always help.

Ugh. Okay, that's…complicated. It's a good question, though. A really good question. And honestly, it's something I've thought about a lot.

At first, the idea of *not* knowing anything, of just…completely letting go, felt easier. Cleaner. Like ripping off a band-aid. But then Paul and Mark started talking about open adoption, about sending pictures and updates, and…it didn't feel as scary as I thought it would.

It's still weird, though. Like, it's my baby, but I'm choosing to not raise it. And the thought of seeing pictures of it growing up, knowing I'm not there…it's gonna be hard. Really hard.

But I think…I think it might be worth it. For the baby. Knowing where it came from, knowing I wanted it to have a good life, even if I couldn't give it to it myself. And for me, too, maybe. It wouldn't be a complete goodbye. It would be…a different kind of connection.

It's not like I want to be a part of their lives in a huge way. I don't want to be Aunt Juno showing up at every birthday party. But just knowing they're okay, that they're happy…that would be good.

It's still scary, though. It's a lot to process. And I'm still trying to figure out what I want. But I think…I think I'm leaning towards it. As long as it's what's best for the baby. And as long as it doesn't mess things up for the adoptive parents.

It's just…it's not a simple decision. It's messy. Like everything else in my life. But maybe that's okay. Maybe messy is good. Maybe messy is real.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…not good. It wasn't like a dramatic, crying-on-the-floor kind of thing, because I don't really *do* dramatic. But it was…cold. Like, a really cold splash of water to the face.

I mean, I knew it was an adoption, right? I knew I wasn't keeping the baby. But I thought…I don't know. I thought it would be more…gentle. More about finding a good home. Not about legally erasing me from the equation.

Gerta just kind of dropped it in there, all clinical and matter-of-fact. Like I was a piece of paperwork. "Your legal rights will be terminated." It sounded so…final. So permanent.

It made me feel…small. Like I didn't matter. Like the whole nine months, the morning sickness, the cravings, the weird kicks…it all meant nothing. Like I was just a vessel.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a joke about it. "So, like, I'm not the mom anymore?" But inside, I was just…really confused. And a little bit scared.

It made me realize how much control I *didn't* have. I was making this decision, but it wasn't entirely my decision. There were lawyers and courts and legal documents and all this stuff that was way over my head.

It was a wake-up call, I guess. It made me think about what I really wanted, and what I was willing to give up. And it made me appreciate Mark and Vanessa even more, because they actually seemed to *want* me in the picture, even after the adoption.

It was a really messed up moment. But it was also…important. It made me realize that this wasn't just about giving a baby a good home. It was about all these complicated feelings and legal stuff and trying to do the right thing, even when it's really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. She's…intense. And honestly? It's kinda heartbreaking.

Look, I get wanting a baby. I *had* a baby. But she wants it so badly, it's like…it's defining her. Like her whole life is on hold until she gets one. And that's just…a lot of pressure. For her, and for anyone she's with.

It's not that I think she's a bad person, or that wanting a kid is wrong. It's just…she's putting all her eggs in one basket, you know? Like, her happiness depends on this one thing happening. And that's scary.

I mean, Mark was a good guy, but he wasn't ready. And she was so focused on the baby, she didn't really *see* him. It's like she already had a whole life planned for this kid, and Mark was just…a necessary component.

I just want her to be happy, you know? But I also want her to be okay if things don't go according to plan. Because life rarely does. And a baby doesn't fix everything. It's a whole lot of work, and a whole lot of responsibility.

It's just…I hope she finds happiness, even if it doesn't involve a little tiny human. Because she deserves that. She really does. It's just…she needs to figure out what *she* wants, not just what she thinks she *should* want.

Ugh. It's complicated. People are complicated. And babies are even more complicated.

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark's whole "dad" thing? Honestly? It's…Mark. It's perfectly Mark.

He's trying, you know? He's not like, naturally equipped to handle big feelings or talk about stuff. He's a skater kid who still kinda thinks in monosyllables. So when he's asked about being a dad, he's gonna deflect. He's gonna make a joke. He's gonna try to be cool about it.

It's not that he *doesn't* care. He does. He's just…processing it in his own way. It's like, he's scared of being vulnerable, of admitting that this whole situation is kinda terrifying. He's used to being the carefree one, and now he's gotta be responsible for a tiny human. That's a lot.

And the whole "I'm not ready to be a dad" thing? Yeah, nobody's *ever* really ready to be a dad. It's something you figure out as you go. 

It's frustrating, sure. Sometimes I just want him to *say* what he's feeling. But I also get it. He's a good guy, just…a little bit emotionally stunted. 

He'll come around. He'll figure it out. He's Mark. He always does. Eventually. It just might take him a little longer than most people. And a lot of awkward silences.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to unpack the Loring's house thing? Fine. It's…complicated. It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just…intense. And their house is…a lot.

It's not the house itself, really. It's just…everything in it is *perfect*. Like, aggressively perfect. Everything has its place, everything is coordinated, and it feels like if you even *breathe* wrong, you're gonna mess something up.

And they're always *watching*. Not in a creepy way, exactly. But they're always hovering, offering me things, asking if I'm comfortable. It's like they're waiting for me to break something or say something inappropriate. Which, let's be real, is a valid concern. But still.

It just makes me feel…suffocated. Like I'm in a museum. And I'm not a museum piece. I'm a person. A pregnant person, yes, but still.

And the whole vibe is just…expectant. Like they're waiting for the baby to arrive so they can start decorating the nursery and planning playdates and generally just being perfect parents. And I'm just…sitting there, trying not to spill anything on the beige carpet.

It's not that I don't appreciate their kindness. It's just…I need space. I need to be able to be myself, even if "myself" is a sarcastic, movie-quoting teenager who's currently experiencing a life crisis. And I just don't feel like I can do that in their house.
