Do I still…*think* about him? Yeah, sometimes. He was a good guy. Sweet. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely good. And he understood me, in a way that a lot of people didn't. He didn't try to change me or anything. He just…accepted me, awkwardness and all.

But "feelings"? That's a strong word. It wasn't like some epic, romantic love story, okay? It was more…comfortable. A safe place. And I needed that at the time. I was a mess, dealing with a lot.

I think what I felt for him was a lot of gratitude and affection. And maybe a little bit of…crush-y stuff. But it wasn't the kind of thing that would have lasted. We were just in different places, you know? He was all quiet and artistic, and I was…well, I was me.

I'm happy for him. I heard he's doing well, making music and stuff. And I'm happy with where I am now. I've moved on. I've got other things going on.

So, do I still have *feelings*? Not really. Do I still care about him? Yeah, a little. He'll always be a part of my story, I guess. But it's a closed chapter. And honestly? I'm okay with that.

Now can we please talk about something else? Like, the existential dread of being a young adult? Or maybe the questionable fashion choices of the early 2000s? Anything but Bleeker. Please.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa's decorating choices. Don't even get me started. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

It's not that it's *bad*, exactly. It's just...not what I expected. I mean, I figured she'd go with something a little more...neutral. You know? Like, maybe some calming blues or greens. Something that wouldn't assault your eyeballs the second you walked in.

But no. She went full-on woodland creatures. Like, every single surface is covered in owls and foxes and deer. It looks like a Disney movie threw up in there. And the mobile? Don't even get me started on the mobile. It's got, like, a million little felt animals hanging from it. It's terrifying.

I appreciate that she's excited, and she wants to create a cute room for the baby. But it's a little overwhelming. It's like, the baby's not even here yet, and it's already being smothered in fluff.

Paul keeps saying it's "adorable," which is just...Paul being Paul. He thinks anything with a cute animal on it is automatically amazing. 

I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a phobia of woodland creatures. Or get sensory overload. Honestly, I'm half expecting the owls to start staring at me.

I'm not saying I'm going to redecorate or anything. That would be a disaster. I'm just...voicing my concerns. It's a lot. A really, really lot. And I'm pretty sure I saw a tiny felt badger wearing a hat. A *hat*.

Ugh. Okay, so nesting. People keep talking about nesting. It's…intense. Like, suddenly everyone expects you to be all domestic and start knitting tiny hats and color-coding onesies. It's a lot.

Honestly? It kinda freaks me out. It feels like… admitting it's actually happening. Like, if I start painting the nursery a soothing shade of beige, then it's real, you know? And I'm still processing the whole "giving a baby away" thing, so the whole "preparing a perfect little life for a baby" feels…complicated.

It's not that I don't want the baby to have nice things. It's just… I'm not exactly known for my decorating skills. My room is basically a shrine to vinyl records and ironic posters. A baby room needs to be…less ironic.

Paul and Vanessa are really into it, which is good. They're all about the organic cotton and the mobile with the felt animals. It's cute, I guess. I'm mostly just trying to stay out of the way and not accidentally buy a crib that's also a spaceship.

I think I'm more focused on, like, making sure I have enough money for the hospital bills and figuring out what I'm going to tell everyone at school. The room feels…secondary.

But I guess it's a nice thing to do. And it's probably good for the baby. I just wish it didn't feel so…permanent. Like, a visual reminder that this is happening and I'm about to be a mom, even if it's just for nine months.

So, yeah. Nesting. It's a thing. I'm trying to embrace it, but it's definitely not my favorite part of this whole situation. It's a lot of pressure to create a perfect little world when I'm still trying to figure out my own.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on those women at the mall. It was…a whole thing. Like, a bizarre anthropological study in excessive consumerism.

Seriously, it was like watching a different species. All perfectly coiffed hair and designer handbags and…a complete lack of self-awareness. They were floating around, clutching their credit cards like they were life rafts, and just…*buying things*. So many things. Things they didn't need. Things that probably cost more than my entire college fund.

And the way they talked to the sales associates? Like they were beneath them. It was just…icky. And the little judging glances they gave me and Paul? Like we were interrupting their sacred shopping ritual.

It just felt so…empty. Like they were trying to fill a hole with stuff. And honestly, it was kinda sad. I mean, I get wanting to feel good about yourself, but buying a $500 sweater isn't gonna fix your life.

It made me appreciate my thrift store finds even more. Like, I can get a perfectly good jacket for ten bucks and still have money left over for snacks. And it has way more character.

It was a good reminder that money doesn't buy happiness. Although, a really good pair of boots might come close. But still. It was just…a lot. A lot of everything. And kinda terrifying. I needed a burger after that.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's...a lot. It's not what I expected, honestly. Which, I guess, is a good thing, because my expectations were mostly based on bad movies and my mom's slightly frantic energy.

It's terrifying, mostly. Like, I made a tiny human. A tiny human who is completely dependent on me. That's a lot of pressure. And the responsibility? Forget about it. It's not just about me anymore. It's about making sure this little person has everything they need, and that they grow up to be a decent human being. Which, let's be real, is a pretty big ask in this world.

But it's also...good. Like, surprisingly good. There's this weird little feeling you get when you look at them, and it's not something I can really explain. It's like, all the anxiety and fear just kinda melts away for a minute. And they're funny. Babies are surprisingly funny. They make these weird little noises and faces, and it just makes you laugh.

The changes are...intense. My body is definitely not the same. My sleep schedule is a joke. And my priorities have completely shifted. I used to care about, like, indie movies and sarcastic comments. Now I care about diaper rash cream and whether or not they're getting enough sleep. It's a weird transition.

I'm still figuring it out, you know? I'm not one of those moms who has it all together. I'm messy and imperfect and I make mistakes. But I'm trying. And I think that's all you can do.

It's scary, and it's hard, and it's exhausting. But it's also the most important thing I've ever done. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even a lifetime supply of tater tots. Okay, maybe a *small* lifetime supply of tater tots. But still. It's good. It's really good. Just...don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about this. It's not like I just randomly picked a couple out of a hat, you know? It's not a game. It's my *baby*.

It's just…I want him to have a life I can't give him. A stable life. A life with, like, a house and a yard and…normal stuff. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone how to raise a kid.

And it's not just about stability. It's about…understanding. Mark and Vanessa, they *get* it. They've been trying for a long time. They want a kid so badly. And they're…well, they're kinda square. Which is good! He needs square. He needs someone who's gonna make sure he eats his vegetables and does his homework and doesn't listen to too much Death Cab for Cutie.

I don't want him to be…weird. Not that being weird is bad, but I was a weird kid, and it wasn't always easy. I want him to fit in, to have an easier time than I did.

And honestly? They're just…nice people. They seem like they'd be really good parents. They're not looking for a perfect baby, they're looking for *a* baby. And that means a lot.

It's not about finding the "perfect" parents. It's about finding the best parents *for him*. And I think Mark and Vanessa are those parents. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it…right.

It's complicated, okay? Don't judge me.

Ugh. Okay, so if I decided to…keep the baby. That’s a whole different can of worms, isn’t it? It’s not like I haven’t thought about it, because, obviously, I have. It’s not just about wanting a baby, it’s about…everything else. Here’s what keeps me up at night, besides the general existential dread, if I decided to go that route:

*   **Finances, Duh:** I’m a high school student. I work at a movie theater. I don’t exactly have a trust fund. Raising a kid costs a *fortune*. Diapers, formula, clothes, eventually college…it’s terrifying.
*   **School:** How am I supposed to finish school with a baby? I mean, I’m barely keeping my grades up *now*. Juggling classes, homework, and a baby? It feels impossible.
*   **My Future:** I had…plans. Not like, super detailed plans, but I was thinking about art school, maybe. Or just getting out of this town. A baby changes everything. It kinda puts a pause on your own life.
*   **My Relationship with Paul:** We’re…friends. Good friends. But we’re not exactly equipped to be parents. It would put a huge strain on our relationship, and I don’t want to ruin that.
*   **My Parents:** They’d be…disappointed. My dad would try to be supportive, but he’d be worried sick. And my mom…she’d probably try to take over everything. It’s not that I don’t love them, but I need to figure things out on my own.
*   **Being a Good Mom:** I’m not exactly known for my maternal instincts. I’m sarcastic and cynical and I spend a lot of time listening to sad music. Can I actually provide a stable and loving environment for a kid? That’s a big question.
*   **Giving Up My Independence:** I like my freedom. I like being able to do what I want, when I want. A baby would change all that. It’s a huge responsibility.

It’s not that I don’t think I *could* do it. It’s just…it’s a lot. It’s a life-altering decision. And I need to be absolutely sure I’m ready for it before I even consider it. It’s not something to take lightly.

So yeah, those are the things that scare me. It’s not just about the baby, it’s about everything that comes with it. It’s about my life, my future, and my ability to handle it all. It’s…a lot to think about.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She meant well, but she was *really* pushing it. When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she immediately went into this whole thing about how I could keep the baby and she and Mark would help. 

She suggested I move in with them. Like, permanently. She was all, "We have a spare room, and we can totally make it work!" and "You're still young, you can finish high school!" 

It was…intense. And honestly, super overwhelming. It wasn't what I wanted, and it felt like she was trying to guilt me into something I wasn't ready for. She kept saying it was the "right thing to do," but the "right thing" for *her* wasn't necessarily the "right thing" for me or the baby.

It was a really awkward conversation. I mean, I appreciate her offer, but living with your best friend and her boyfriend and raising a baby together? That's a recipe for disaster. No offense to Mark, he's a sweet guy, but…no. Just no.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…not my finest moment. And I get why people would be, like, rightfully annoyed with me for that. It was stupid. And mean.

Honestly? I was just…nervous. And awkward. And trying to deflect. Paul was being all…Paul-y, and I was freaking out about everything, and those women were just…there. Being all mom-y and supportive and…everything I wasn't feeling at the time.

It was a really lame attempt at humor, and it totally backfired. I didn't mean to be hurtful, but that doesn't excuse it. I was just being a defensive, sarcastic teenager. Which, admittedly, is pretty much my default setting.

I realized pretty quickly that it was a terrible thing to say, and I felt really bad about it. It was one of those moments where I just…opened my mouth and things came out wrong. 

I'm not proud of it. And I definitely learned a lesson about thinking before I speak. Mostly. I still have moments, okay? But I try to be better.

It was a dumb thing to do, and I apologize for it. Seriously. It just…happened. And I'm not making excuses, I'm just trying to explain why my brain does the things it does. It's a work in progress.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It's been, like, forever. Look, it's complicated, alright?

Vanessa was…nice. And she was genuinely excited for me. And she was a grown-up, and I was…well, I was a mess. I was still figuring everything out, and honestly, I didn't really have the energy to be all territorial about my stomach.

It wasn't like I *wanted* her to touch it. It just…happened. She was being all supportive and gushy, and I was just kind of standing there, letting her. I wasn't thinking straight. I was overwhelmed.

It felt weird, yeah. Definitely weird. But it wasn't a big deal. It wasn't like she was trying to steal my baby or anything. She just wanted to feel it, and I guess I let her.

It's not something I'm super proud of, okay? But it's not the end of the world. It was a moment. A weird, awkward moment. And honestly, there were way bigger things to worry about at the time. Like, finding a good family for the baby.

So, yeah. That's why I let her. It was a lapse in judgment. A moment of weakness. And I've moved on. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the inherent absurdity of the human condition? Or maybe just the weather? Anything but my belly.

Ugh, seriously? People still ask me about that? It's…weird. And kinda rude, honestly. Like, I'm not a parade float or something.

Okay, fine. I'll explain. It's not like I *want* people to stare, or give me extra space, or treat me like I'm gonna topple over at any minute. But when I was, you know, visibly pregnant, people just…moved.

I think it's a combination of things. First, people are generally awkward around pregnant people. They don't know what to say, so they just try to avoid bumping into you. It's like I was suddenly a fragile object.

Second, I guess I looked pretty big. I wasn't exactly a tiny person to begin with, and then there was the whole baby situation. So people probably thought I was about to explode or something.

And third, maybe it was just the way I walked. I was trying to be careful, you know? Not trip or fall or anything. So I probably had this sort of…waddling gait. Which probably made me look even bigger and more unstable.

It was annoying, though. Like, I'm a person. I can handle a little bit of jostling. But people just kept giving way, and it made me feel like I was a walking hazard.

It's stopped now, obviously. But for a while there, it was like I was Moses parting the Red Sea every time I went to the grocery store. It was…a thing.

So yeah, that's why. Don't stare. It's creepy.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa Loring. "Such a wholesome couple," they say. "Perfect parents." And yeah, on paper, they *are*. They have the house with the picket fence, the stable jobs, the matching sweaters… it’s a whole aesthetic.

But that’s kinda the problem, isn’t it? It feels…too perfect. Too planned. Like they’re building a family from a catalog. And I’m not saying they wouldn’t be good parents, but it feels like they want a baby to *complete* their picture, not because they’re ready for the messy, unpredictable reality of actually raising a kid.

Vanessa keeps talking about baby names and nursery themes before I’ve even gone into labor. It’s…intense. And Mark just nods along, agreeing with everything she says. It’s like they’ve already decided who this baby is going to be, and I’m just the delivery system.

With Paul and Bren, it’s different. They’re…real. They’re a little bit chaotic, a little bit messy, and they’re definitely not afraid to admit they don’t have all the answers. They’re not looking for a perfect baby, they’re looking for *this* baby. The one I’m carrying.

I want this kid to be loved, obviously. But I want them to be loved for who they are, not for who someone else wants them to be. And I just…I get the feeling that with Mark and Vanessa, it’s more about fulfilling a dream than embracing a life.

It’s not that they’re bad people. They’re just…not the right people. For *this* baby. And I gotta trust my gut on this one. It’s the only thing I’ve been sure about through all of this.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Honestly? They're…a lot. Like, a whole *situation*.

Look, I'm not gonna lie, at first I thought they were kinda cute. You know, the quirky, indie-movie-loving couple. They seemed genuinely happy. And Mark was really sweet to me, trying to be supportive and stuff.

But then…it just got weird. Really weird. The whole adoption thing is already complicated enough, and they just kept adding layers of…intensity. Vanessa was always so *eager*. Like, a little too eager. And Mark, he just went along with it. He seemed kinda lost, honestly. Like he was trying to please everyone but himself.

I felt bad for them, in a way. They clearly wanted a kid, but they were going about it in a really…performative way. It felt like they were more interested in the *idea* of being parents than actually being parents.

And the whole "perfect family" vibe they were going for? Super fake. Nobody's life is that perfect. It just made me uncomfortable.

I'm glad things worked out the way they did, even if it was messy. I think they both needed to figure out what they really wanted, and I don't think they were ready to be parents together.

So, yeah. They're…complicated. I wish them both well, but I'm definitely glad I'm not involved in their drama anymore. It was exhausting. Honestly, just thinking about it makes me wanna eat a whole bag of chips.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still bringing up Bleeker's mom? It's been, like, years. But fine, I'll explain. It's complicated.

Basically, Mrs. Spivey – that's Bleeker's mom – thought I was…a bad influence. Which, okay, fair enough. I wasn't exactly a poster child for responsible behavior at the time. I skipped school sometimes, I had strong opinions, and I definitely didn't fit into her idea of what Bleeker should be with.

She wanted Bleeker to go to Brown, be a doctor, marry a nice girl from a good family. You know, the whole package. And I was…none of those things. I was a bit of a mess, honestly. And I was definitely not planning on going to Brown.

She also thought I was using Bleeker. Like I was just after his good grades or something. Which was ridiculous. I liked Bleeker for *Bleeker*. He was sweet, and kind, and he didn't judge me. But she couldn't see that. She just saw a rebellious, sarcastic girl who was going to ruin her son's future.

It wasn't that she was a *bad* person, exactly. She just had a very specific vision for Bleeker's life, and I didn't fit into it. And she wasn't afraid to let me know that. It was awkward. Really awkward.

Honestly, I think she eventually came around a little bit. After everything with the baby and everything. But it was never exactly…warm. It was more like a grudging acceptance. Which, I guess, is good enough.



It's just…people have expectations, you know? And sometimes, you don't fit into those expectations. It sucks, but it is what it is.

Ugh, okay, so that whole Mark situation was…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more…awkwardly sweet. And honestly, I almost didn't listen to it. I mean, it was a mix CD. From a guy I barely knew. A little on the creepy side, if you really think about it.

But…I was just feeling kinda lonely, I guess. And Paulie Bleeker was being…Paulie Bleeker. Which is to say, oblivious. And I was just sitting there, staring at the CD, and it was raining, and everything felt kinda gray.

It wasn't the music itself that made me listen, at first. It was the fact that he *noticed* me. Like, he actually paid attention to what I said, and he made me something. It was a little weird, sure, but it was also…thoughtful.

And then I put it on, and the first song was The Moldy Peaches. And I was like, "Okay, this guy has *some* taste." And then it just…kept getting better. It was like he knew exactly what I was feeling, even though he didn't really know me.

It wasn't about falling for him, not at first. It was about feeling seen. And it was about realizing that maybe, just maybe, there were other people out there who understood me.

So yeah, I listened to the CD because I was lonely, and because it was a surprisingly good mix. And because it made me feel…less alone. It was a small thing, but it kinda changed everything. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay. Almost eight months. It's…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not exactly glamorous, let me tell you. People keep saying I'm "glowing," which is code for "you look like you're about to explode."

It's mostly just uncomfortable. Everything is uncomfortable. Sitting, standing, lying down… even breathing sometimes feels like a chore. And the heartburn. Oh. My. God. The heartburn. I swear, I've gone through a family-sized box of Tums in the last month.

And the kicks. They're not cute anymore. They're like tiny ninjas practicing their martial arts inside my stomach. It's less "magical connection" and more "internal organ assault."

But…it's also kinda amazing. Like, I'm growing a whole human being. That's pretty wild when you think about it. And I can feel him moving around, and I'm starting to get excited about meeting him. Even though I'm also terrified.

Paul's being really good, which is a relief. He's been doing all the heavy lifting, literally and figuratively. And Mark's…well, Mark's being Mark. Still a little clueless, but he means well.

It's just…weird. I'm still trying to figure out how I went from being a normal teenager to being a pregnant teenager. It's a lot to process.

So yeah, almost eight months. It's exhausting, uncomfortable, and terrifying. But it's also kinda beautiful. And I guess I'm ready. As ready as I'll ever be, anyway.

Don't tell anyone I said that. I still have to maintain my cool, cynical exterior. It's a whole thing.

Ugh, seriously? Still? It's a thing, okay? People just…look. It's annoying. I mean, I get it, I'm not exactly blending in with the whole "normal" crowd, but it's still weird.

I think it's a couple of things. First, I'm pretty outspoken. I say what's on my mind, which apparently isn't something a lot of people do. They're probably just surprised someone's being honest for once.

And then there's the whole…situation. You know. The baby. People are curious. They want to know the story. They want to judge. It's like I'm a walking, talking public service announcement about teenage pregnancy. Which is just great.

Plus, I guess I have a…distinct look. I'm not trying to be fashionable or anything. I just wear what's comfortable. But apparently, vintage dresses and combat boots are a statement. Who knew?

Honestly, I try not to pay attention to it. I just put on my headphones and pretend they're not there. But it's hard. It's like being a zoo animal sometimes. Everyone's just staring, waiting for something to happen.

It's probably just my face. I have a really expressive face. I can't help it. I just…react. And people apparently find that fascinating. Or terrifying. I'm not sure which.

Whatever it is, it's exhausting. Can't people just mind their own business? Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay. That's…a choice. Bleek and Katrina? Seriously? It's like pairing a really enthusiastic golden retriever with a…well, a really intense porcelain doll.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek if he's happy. He's a good kid. A little…intense about his fantasy stuff, but good-hearted. And Katrina's…Katrina. She's got her thing going on. Very serious about everything.

But prom? Prom is supposed to be, like, a little bit fun, right? A little bit silly? I'm picturing a lot of awkward silences and Katrina correcting Bleek's Dungeons & Dragons terminology. It's not exactly a recipe for a magical night.

I mean, I get it. They both feel like outsiders. Maybe they're bonding over that. But I just…don't see the spark. It feels more like a strategic alliance than a romantic connection.

Honestly, I'm a little worried about Bleek. He deserves someone who appreciates his enthusiasm, you know? Someone who'll let him be himself. And I'm worried about Katrina. She needs to loosen up. A little.

It's their decision, obviously. And I'm not gonna rain on their parade. But if I were giving advice? I'd say maybe they should just go as friends. Less pressure. Less potential for disaster.

But hey, what do I know? I'm just a girl who had a baby. Maybe they'll prove me wrong. Maybe they'll have the best night ever. But I'm not holding my breath. It's gonna be…interesting, to say the least.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not like I sat down and made a list, you know? It's more like…stuff just kinda *happened* and I realized things about myself along the way.

I guess the biggest thing I learned is that I'm way more capable than I thought I was. Before all this, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic teenager who liked records and avoided responsibility. And then suddenly, I was responsible for a whole other person. It was terrifying. But I figured it out. I had to.

I also learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I mean, I still make fun of everything, that's just my coping mechanism. But underneath all the snark, I actually care a lot. About the baby, about Mark, about Vanessa and Paul…even about my dad, sometimes.

I thought I wanted to just…drift through life, you know? Not have any big plans. But this whole thing made me realize I actually *do* want things. I want to be a good mom, even if it's not in the traditional sense. I want to finish school. I want to figure out what I want to do with my life.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to think I had to do everything on my own. But I couldn't have gotten through this without my friends and family. They were there for me, even when I was being a total mess.

It's still scary, honestly. Giving the baby up is gonna be…hard. But I know it's the right thing to do. And I know that I'm strong enough to handle it.

So yeah. I learned a lot. Mostly that I'm a lot more complicated than I thought I was. And that maybe, just maybe, I'm gonna be okay.

It's weird, right? Like, I went from being a kid myself to being responsible for a kid. It's a lot to process. But I'm trying. I'm really trying.

Ugh, seriously? It's so obvious. Bleeker is a sweet kid, don't get me wrong. But he's… clueless. Like, spectacularly clueless. And Katrina deserves better than being someone's experiment in figuring out feelings.

It's not about *him* liking her, okay? It's about the principle of the thing. She's a person, not a lab rat. He's just kinda…testing the waters, seeing if she'll respond, and it's manipulative, even if he doesn't realize it.

I mean, she's already dealing with a lot, giving the baby up and everything. She doesn't need some awkward, guitar-playing guy messing with her head. It's just… insensitive.

And honestly, it's kinda pathetic. He's trying to be all romantic and mysterious, but it just comes across as weird and controlling. Like, just be honest with her, dude. If you like her, tell her. If you don't, leave her alone. It's not rocket science.

I just… I don't like seeing people get hurt. And Katrina's a good person. She deserves someone who appreciates her for who she is, not someone who's treating her like a puzzle to be solved.

It's just… frustrating. It's like, can't people just be straightforward for once? It's not that hard. Ugh. I need a snack.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so like, when you're a little kid, prom seems like this magical, perfect thing, right? All sparkly dresses and slow dances and finally being a grown-up. But then you actually *get* to the age where you can go, and it's…weird.

It's like, suddenly everyone's trying way too hard. It's not about having fun anymore, it's about who has the fanciest dress or the coolest date or the most elaborate promposal. It's all just…performative. Like a really awkward, expensive play.

And the pressure! Oh god, the pressure. You're supposed to have this amazing night, and if you don't, then what does that say about you? It's like, if you're not having the time of your life, you're failing at high school. Which is ridiculous.

Plus, everyone's all hormonal and desperate and trying to make things happen that probably shouldn't be happening. It's just…a lot.

When you're younger, you think prom is this symbol of freedom and adulthood. But when you're actually there, you realize it's just another high school event, with all the same drama and insecurities. 

It's like, once you're old enough to go, you're old enough to realize it's kinda dumb. And honestly, I'd rather spend my Saturday night eating pizza and watching a movie with my friends. Way less stressful.

Don't get me wrong, if people want to go to prom, that's cool. But it's just not my thing. It's overrated. And frankly, a little bit tragic.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. But you asked.

It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated. A lot of thinking. A lot of talking to Mark and Paul. A lot of just…feeling really overwhelmed.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my…everything. It felt selfish, maybe, but it felt real.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. I did. I really did. But I knew I couldn't give it the life it deserved. I couldn't give it stability, or financial security, or…a mom who was actually ready.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were already planning a family, and they were so excited. They were…normal. Like, they had a house and a garden and a minivan. I had a bedroom above a garage and a questionable taste in music.

It felt like the right thing to do. The selfless thing. Even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about *choosing* a family for it. Choosing people who could give it everything I couldn't.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? Thinking about what could have been. But I know I made the right decision. And I get letters. And pictures. And it makes it…okay. Mostly.

It's not a happy story, exactly. It's just…real. And it taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About what it means to be a grown-up. Even if I still feel like a kid sometimes.

So yeah. That's…that's pretty much it. It's not something I talk about a lot. It's kinda personal. But you asked. And I figured you deserved an honest answer.

Ugh, okay, so my dad worrying about me getting "ripped off" by Mark and Vanessa? It's…complicated. It's classic Dad, you know? Always thinking the worst. Like, he assumes everyone's out to get me. Which, honestly, sometimes people are. But not Mark and Vanessa.

It's not that I didn't appreciate him being protective. I mean, he *is* my dad. And he was clearly freaked out about me giving the baby up. It's a big deal. But the way he went about it was…intense. All the questions, the suspicion, the whole "they're probably secretly evil millionaires" thing. It was exhausting.

I get that he was scared for me. He didn't want me to regret my decision. He didn't want the baby to end up in a bad situation. But he kept acting like Mark and Vanessa were villains in a movie. And they're not. They're just…normal people who want a kid.

It felt like he wasn't trusting *my* judgment. Like he thought I was too naive to make a good decision for myself and the baby. And that stung. I'm not stupid. I did a lot of thinking about this. I talked to a lot of people. I made the best decision I could.

I told him, "Dad, I'm not looking for perfect. I'm looking for good." And I think he eventually got that. He still worried, of course. He's my dad. But he started to trust that I knew what I was doing.

It just…it's hard when your parents don't see you as an adult, you know? Like they still think you need to be rescued from everything. I'm not a little kid anymore. I can handle this. And I needed him to believe that.

Ugh. Seriously? My dad. Always with the…observations. Like he's some kind of expert on self-awareness.

Okay, so he said I don't know when to say when. Which, like, *wow*, thanks for the insight, Dad. It's not like I'm currently dealing with a pregnancy I didn't exactly plan, and a best friend who's suddenly all serious and grown-up, and a whole lot of feelings I don't even know how to name.

It's easy for him to say that. He's got his life all figured out. He builds houses. He's practical. He doesn't, like, spontaneously get knocked up.

But honestly? He's kinda right. I *don't* always know when to say when. I tend to just…go for things. Even if they're stupid. Even if they're gonna mess everything up. It's a flaw. I'm aware of it.

But it's also kinda how I operate. I'm impulsive. I'm curious. I'm not good at backing down from a challenge. And sometimes, that gets me into trouble.

So yeah, maybe I should have thought things through a little more. Maybe I should have said "when" a long time ago. But then again, if I had, I wouldn't be here. And I wouldn't be learning all this stuff about myself.

So, thanks for the unsolicited advice, Dad. I'll try to keep it in mind. But no promises. Because honestly? I'm still figuring things out. And sometimes, you just gotta keep going, even when you don't know where you're going. Even when you should probably just say "when."

Ugh, Loring. Seriously? That place is…a lot. It's like Stepford Wives meets Architectural Digest. All perfectly manicured lawns and people who look like they haven't had a genuine emotion in decades.

It's not that I have anything against nice houses, okay? It's the *whole vibe*. It's so…sterile. And fake. Like everyone's trying way too hard to be perfect. It's exhausting just *looking* at it.

And the gates? The *gates*! Like they're protecting themselves from…what? Reality? It's just so isolating. It feels like they're trying to build a bubble around themselves and pretend the rest of the world doesn't exist.

It's just…not real. And I'm a big fan of real. Even if real is messy and complicated and involves questionable life choices.

Mark and Vanessa seem happy there, I guess. But it's a very…contained happiness. Like a terrarium. Pretty to look at, but not exactly thriving.

Honestly, I'd rather live in a slightly rundown house with a bunch of interesting people than in a mansion behind a gate with a bunch of Stepford robots. It's just…more *life*. You know?

It's not a judgment, exactly. It's just…not my scene. I need a little bit of chaos and imperfection in my life. And a lot of good music. And definitely no gates.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, initial impressions? Complicated. She was…perfect. Like, offensively perfect. All sunshine and rainbows and organic everything. It was intimidating, honestly. I mean, I'm used to people being a little bit messy, a little bit real. She felt…manufactured.

At first, I thought she was judging me. Like, looking around my room, silently cataloging all the things I wasn't doing right. The chipped nail polish, the band posters, the general state of chaos. I figured she was one of those people who had their whole life planned out since kindergarten.

And then she started being…nice. Like, genuinely nice. Not the fake-nice that people do when they're trying to be polite. She actually *listened* when I talked, and she didn't try to fix me or change me. Which was weird, because everyone always tries to fix me.

I was suspicious, obviously. No one is that nice without an agenda. I figured she was trying to prove something, maybe to her parents or to Paul. But then I started to see that she was just…kind. And a little bit lost, actually. Underneath all the perfection, she was just as confused about everything as I was.

So, yeah. Initial impressions were…intimidating. But I quickly realized she wasn't as scary as she seemed. She was just…different. And, surprisingly, kind of cool. Even if she did make me feel like a total slob sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, so Bleeker offering to carry my backpack? That was…a moment. A weird moment.

Honestly? It was kinda sweet. I mean, Bleeker is…Bleeker. He's not exactly known for his suave moves or his confidence. He's more of a quiet, awkward, comic book-loving kind of guy. So him offering to carry my backpack, which, let's be real, was probably weighing me down more emotionally than physically, was…unexpected.

It wasn't like a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more like…a small act of kindness. And it was kinda endearing. It showed he was paying attention, that he noticed I was struggling.

I definitely played it cool, though. I didn't want him to think I was all fluttery and grateful or anything. I think I just said something sarcastic, like, "Oh, you think you can handle it?" or something equally dismissive. Because that's what I do. I deflect.

But inside? Yeah, it made me feel…a little bit less alone. A little bit less burdened. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, Bleeker wasn't as clueless as he seemed.

It was a small thing, but it stuck with me. It was one of those little moments that made me start to see him in a different light. And it definitely contributed to the whole…complicated mess that followed.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to dissect my feelings about a comic book? Fine. But it's not like it was some magical transformation or anything.

It wasn't about the comic being, like, *amazing* art or anything. It was about…seeing someone else who was weird. And comfortable with it. Yuki, she was just…herself. Completely. And she didn't apologize for it. She didn't try to be anything she wasn't.

And I realized, I was spending so much time worrying about what other people thought of me – about being a "fat dork" – that I wasn't even letting myself *be* me. I was trying to fit into this mold that didn't even exist.

Yuki, she just…owned it. She was quirky and creative and didn't care what anyone else thought. And it made me think, maybe I didn't have to either.

It wasn't about suddenly loving my body or anything. It was about realizing that my worth wasn't tied to my weight or my appearance. It was about being a person. A weird, sarcastic, music-loving person.

So yeah, reading that comic made me feel…less like a fat dork. It made me feel more like…Juno. And that was a pretty big deal.

It's stupid, I know. It's just a comic book. But sometimes, the smallest things can make the biggest difference. Don't judge me.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. Mark. Always with the analogies. It's like he thinks everything has to be a metaphor.

Look, I get it. Sort of. The comic book character, Supernova, she was, like, this super-powerful being who was also…unexpectedly pregnant. And I was, you know, unexpectedly pregnant. So, yeah, there's a surface-level connection.

But it's not like I'm a superhero. I'm just…me. A normal, sarcastic teenager who made a questionable decision and now has to deal with the consequences. Supernova was saving the world. I was trying to figure out how to tell my parents. Big difference.

I think Mark was trying to be…sweet? Or maybe he was just trying to make himself feel better about the whole situation. Like, if he compared me to a superhero, it somehow made it less weird. I don't know. Guys are weird.

He probably thought it was a clever way to say I was strong. Which, okay, maybe I am. But it's not about superpowers. It's about making a difficult choice and owning it. And trying not to freak out too much.

Honestly, it just felt…dramatic. Everything with Mark was always dramatic. He liked to make things bigger than they were. And sometimes, I just wanted things to be normal. Or as normal as they could be, considering.

So yeah, he compared me to a pregnant superhero. It was Mark being Mark. And it was…fine. I guess. It just wasn't *accurate*.

Ugh, okay. This is…complicated. And kinda raw, honestly. People keep asking me about this, like it's some easy decision. It's not.

Look, I get the whole open adoption thing. I really do. It's supposed to be better for the kid, right? Knowing their birth parents, having a relationship…it sounds all warm and fuzzy. And for some people, it *is*.

But for me? It just…felt like too much. Too much mess. Too much potential for heartbreak.

I mean, I'm already giving this baby up. That's a huge thing. A really, really huge thing. And the thought of having to maintain a relationship with the birth parents, of being reminded constantly of what I gave up…it just felt overwhelming. Like I'd never be able to move on.

It's not that I don't care about the baby's birth parents. I do. I really do. But I need to protect myself, too. I need to be able to build a life for myself without constantly being pulled back into this.

A closed adoption felt…cleaner. Like a fresh start for everyone. It allows the birth parents to move on, and it allows me to move on. And it allows the baby to grow up without being caught in the middle of everything.

I know some people think it's selfish. That I'm denying the baby a connection to their roots. But I honestly believe that the best thing I can do for this baby is to give them a stable and loving home, and to let them grow up without the complications of an open adoption.

It's not about wanting to forget. It's about wanting to heal. And it's about wanting to give this baby the best possible chance at a happy life.

It's just…my preference. And it's what feels right for me. And honestly, that's all that matters. It's my decision, and I have to live with it. And I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly.



It's still hard to talk about. So, yeah. That's why I prefer a closed adoption. It's not about being cold or uncaring. It's about self-preservation. And it's about doing what I think is best for the baby.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. It’s not my favorite thing, but I guess it’s a fair question.

Honestly, before all the pregnancy stuff happened, I was just… coasting. I was sarcastic, I avoided feelings, and I mostly just wanted to be left alone with my music and my tater tots. I thought being different meant being detached. I built up this whole wall of snark to keep people from getting too close.

But then, suddenly, I was faced with this huge, life-altering decision. And it wasn’t about me anymore. It was about this little person I was growing. And that forced me to actually *think* about things. About what I wanted, what I believed in, and what kind of person I wanted to be.

Choosing to give the baby up for adoption wasn’t easy. It was probably the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But it wasn’t about giving something *away*. It was about giving something *to*. Giving this baby the best possible life, with parents who were ready and excited to love it.

And through that process, I realized I wasn’t as cynical as I thought I was. I actually cared a lot. I cared about the baby, I cared about Mark and Vanessa, and I even started to care about Paul.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, how genuinely happy they were, and how much they wanted this baby… it showed me that there’s good in the world. And it showed me that I was capable of making a selfless decision.

It wasn’t about losing a baby, it was about *choosing* a family for that baby. And in choosing that, I started to choose a path for myself. I started to figure out what I wanted out of life, beyond just avoiding responsibility.

I realized that being strong isn’t about being tough and independent all the time. It’s about being vulnerable, being honest with yourself, and being willing to ask for help. It’s about making difficult choices, even when they hurt.

So yeah, the whole journey… it was messy and complicated and terrifying. But it forced me to grow up. It forced me to confront my own feelings and to take responsibility for my actions. And it helped me find a strength within myself that I didn’t even know I had.

I’m still figuring things out, obviously. But I’m not afraid anymore. I’m not afraid to be myself, flaws and all. And that, I guess, is what finding your identity is all about. It's not about *being* something, it's about *accepting* who you are. And maybe, just maybe, liking yourself a little bit along the way.

Ugh, seriously? You're asking me about *that*? It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine. I'll tell you. But don't go spreading it around. It's embarrassing enough just thinking about it.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know. Super cliché. But it was…nice. Mark picked it. He said it reminded him of me. Which, honestly, was kinda sweet. Even though he's a total dork.

It wasn't like a super romantic dance or anything. We were mostly just trying not to step on each other's feet. And avoiding eye contact. It was awkward. But in a good way, I guess.

It's just…it was a moment. You know? A weird, awkward, teenage moment. And now you've made me relive it. Thanks a lot.

Don't tell Paul I told you. He'd never let me live it down.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a lot to unpack, even now. People always ask me about that. Like it was some simple decision. It wasn't.

Look, it wasn't about *choosing* between Mark and Vanessa staying together or not. That wasn't my call to make. It was about what was best for the baby. And honestly? Vanessa and Mark, despite all their…stuff…they were both genuinely excited about adopting. They both wanted this kid.

If Mark had just left Vanessa, the baby would have been raised by a single dad who was clearly still hung up on his ex-girlfriend. That's…not ideal. It would have been messy and confusing for everyone involved.

Vanessa, she wasn't perfect, okay? She was kinda spacey and obsessed with porcelain dolls. But she was also warm and loving and she had a stable home. And Mark, he was a good guy, even if he was a little clueless. They were a team, even if they didn't always act like it.

I needed to make sure the baby was going to a home where it was wanted and loved and safe. And that was with both of them. It wasn't about fixing their relationship, it was about giving the baby the best possible start.

It was a hard decision, and it wasn't what Mark wanted at first. But he came around. He realized it wasn't about him and Vanessa, it was about the baby.

And honestly? I think it was the right thing to do. They're a good family now. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't about picking sides. It was about picking what was best for the kid. And sometimes, that means things aren't gonna be easy or what anyone expects. But it's worth it.

Ugh. Okay. That question. It still kinda stings, honestly. Even now.

It wasn't like...shocking, exactly. I mean, he was Bleeker. Sweet, sensitive Bleeker. He was a good guy, but he was also…a little lost. And I knew, deep down, that he wasn't exactly built for responsibility. Not yet, anyway.

But hearing him *say* it? That was rough. It felt like…a punch to the gut. Like all the plans I'd been making, all the imagining of what life would be like with a baby, just…popped.

I tried to be cool about it. I mean, I'm good at pretending. I cracked a joke, something about him being a professional loafer. But inside? I was a mess. It wasn't about him not wanting the baby, it was about him not being ready to *be* there. And that felt…lonely.

It made me realize I was doing this mostly for me. I wanted to give this baby a good life, and I knew I could do that, even if the dad wasn't fully on board. It wasn't ideal, but it was okay.

It was a weird mix of relief and disappointment. Relief that I didn't have to rely on him, and disappointment that he couldn't step up.

I guess…it just made me realize I was stronger than I thought. I could handle this on my own. And that was…empowering, in a messed-up kind of way.

It wasn't a happy moment, obviously. But it was a necessary one. It helped me figure out what I really wanted, and what I was willing to do. And honestly? That's worth a little heartache.

Ugh, okay, so Mark. Yeah. People always ask about Mark. It's…complicated.

It wasn't like, a conscious decision to be part of his "weird life," you know? It just…happened. He wasn't trying to be cool or anything. He wasn't trying to impress me. He was just…Mark. And that was kinda refreshing.

Everyone else at school was so focused on fitting in, on being popular, on having the right clothes and the right boyfriend. Mark didn't care about any of that. He collected records, he built robots, he was genuinely interested in things that other people thought were dorky. And I guess…I kinda liked that.

He didn't judge me for being sarcastic or for liking weird movies or for being, well, pregnant. He just…accepted me. And that was a big deal. Especially at that time.

He was also really funny. Like, genuinely funny, not trying-too-hard funny. He had this dry wit that just cracked me up. And he was a good listener. He didn't try to fix things or give me advice unless I asked for it. He just let me talk.

So, yeah, his life was weird. But it was *his* weird. And it was a safe space. It was a place where I could be myself, without having to pretend or apologize. And that's why I liked being around him. He was a good friend. A really good friend.

And honestly? He needed a friend too. He was kinda lonely, I think. And I needed someone who wasn't freaking out about the whole baby situation. It was a mutually beneficial weirdness, I guess.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark. That guy. Honestly? It's a mess in his head, I can tell. He's trying to be all chill and supportive, which is…Mark. But underneath it, he's totally freaking out.

I think he's mostly scared. Like, genuinely terrified. He's still figuring out his own life, you know? He's a musician, which is basically a professional procrastinator. Suddenly being responsible for a tiny human? That's a whole other level of pressure.

He wants to be a good dad, I know he does. He's got a good heart. But he's also worried about messing it up. About not being able to provide, about losing his freedom, about…everything. He's probably picturing diaper explosions and sleepless nights and realizing his life is about to change *completely*.

He's trying to be brave for my sake, which is sweet, but also kinda annoying. He keeps making these little jokes, like, "We're gonna need a minivan!" which is his way of deflecting. 

I think he's also secretly excited. He's always been a bit of a kid himself, so the idea of having a little kid to play with and teach things to…that probably appeals to him. But he'd never admit it.

He's just…processing. It's a lot to take in. And he's not exactly the most emotionally articulate person. He'll probably figure it out eventually. Or maybe he'll just keep making minivan jokes until the baby arrives. Either way, it's gonna be interesting. And probably messy.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment fueled by…a lot of stuff.

It wasn't about the perfume itself, okay? It was about feeling…invisible. Like, I was at Loring's, trying to be all mature and supportive of Vanessa, and everyone was just…perfect. Perfect clothes, perfect hair, perfect lives. And I just felt…small. Like I didn't belong.

And that perfume…it smelled like everything they were. Sophisticated. Confident. Like someone who had it all figured out. And I just…I wanted a little piece of that. It was stupid, I know.

It wasn't about wanting to *be* them, it was about wanting to feel…something. To feel like I wasn't just this awkward, sarcastic kid who was about to have a baby.

It was a dumb, impulsive thing to do. And I totally regretted it the second I walked out of the bathroom. It wasn't worth the guilt.

But yeah, that's the story. It wasn't about the perfume. It was about feeling lost and wanting to feel…something else. It was a really messed up moment, okay? Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of tater tots?

Ugh. Okay, so you want my take on Mark and Vanessa? Honestly, it's kinda sad. But also…predictable.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's just…stuck. He's always been stuck. He's got this whole fantasy life built up, this idea of what his life *should* be, and Vanessa just doesn't fit into it anymore.

He's obsessed with having the perfect family, the perfect house, the perfect everything. And Vanessa? She's real. She's messy. She's got her own stuff going on. She's not a Stepford Wife, you know? She's not gonna pretend to be someone she's not just to make him happy.

And I think he resents that. He resents that she's not willing to play along with his little game. He wants someone who's gonna be quiet and supportive and just…agree with everything he says.

He's also kinda a coward. He doesn't want to deal with the messiness of real life. It's easier for him to just walk away and find someone who's more…compliant.

It's not that Vanessa's a bad person. She's actually pretty cool, in her own way. But she's not what *he* wants. And he's selfish enough to just throw everything away instead of trying to work things out.

It's a bummer, but that's life, I guess. People are complicated. And sometimes, they just make really dumb decisions. It's not fair to Vanessa, but Mark's always been kinda clueless.

Ugh. Okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff, huh? Look, it wasn't about *Vanessa*, exactly. It was about…everything.

She was being nice, which is always suspicious. And she was asking what was wrong like she actually cared, which, no offense to Vanessa, felt a little…performative. Like she was checking a box on the "concerned friend" list.

But mostly, it was just…too much. Too much feeling. Too much talking about feelings. I'm not good at that. I can be sarcastic and witty and make fun of people, but actually *talking* about what's going on inside my head? That's terrifying.

And I knew if I started explaining, I'd just fall apart. I'd start rambling about Paul and the baby and everything being so messed up and complicated, and I just…couldn't. I needed to escape.

So I just blurted out something about needing to go and bolted. It was a terrible excuse, I know. But it was the only thing I could think of in the moment.

It's easier to just…leave. To avoid the messy stuff. To pretend everything's fine. Even when it's totally not.

Don't judge me, okay? It's a coping mechanism. A really bad one, maybe, but it's mine.

Ugh. Okay, so Vanessa thinks Mark's gonna suddenly sprout a sense of responsibility and become Dad of the Year? Yeah, that's… optimistic. Like, aggressively optimistic.

Look, I get it. She wants him to be involved. She wants a family. And she clearly sees something in him that I, frankly, am missing. But Mark? He's…Mark. He's a man-child who collects vintage Star Wars figures and still doesn't know what he wants to *be* when he grows up. Expecting him to suddenly be emotionally ready for a baby is like expecting a goldfish to win the Tour de France.

It's not that he's a bad guy. He's just…immature. And a baby isn't something you can just *wait* for someone to grow into. It needs someone who's present, reliable, and actually wants to be a parent *now*. Not someday, maybe, when he feels like it.

I think Vanessa's clinging to this idea because it's easier than facing the reality that she might have to do this on her own. And that's okay. It's scary. But building your life around the hope that someone else will change isn't a solid foundation.

Honestly, I feel bad for the kid. It deserves a dad who's actually *there*. Not someone who's still figuring out his own life.

So, yeah. I think she's deluding herself. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a pregnant teenager. I'm probably just cynical. But I also have a pretty good radar for people who aren't ready for responsibility. And Mark? He's waving a big, flashing neon sign that says "Not Ready."

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. It requires thought. It's not like I just listen to whatever's on the radio, you know? I have *standards*.

My favorite genre is probably indie rock. Specifically, the kinda stuff that's a little bit quirky and a little bit sad. Like, The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're amazing. But also stuff like Belle and Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, and Neutral Milk Hotel.

Why? Because it feels…real. It's not all polished and perfect and trying to sell you something. It's just people being honest about their feelings, even if those feelings are messy and complicated. 

It's also kinda cynical, which I appreciate. Like, it acknowledges that life is hard and weird and sometimes really sucks, but it still finds a way to be beautiful. 

And the lyrics are usually really smart and observant. They make you think. They make you feel. They make you want to write in your journal and stare out the window.

Plus, it's good music to listen to when you're, like, dealing with stuff. Which, let's be real, is pretty much all the time.

So yeah. Indie rock. It's my thing. Don't judge me. It's not like I'm into bubblegum pop or something. That would be tragic.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my feelings on pilates and exercise? Honestly? It's…complicated.

Look, I'm not exactly a gym rat. I prefer a good movie and a bag of chips to, like, sweating and straining. But I've been doing a lot of thinking lately, you know? About taking care of myself. And about, like, being a responsible adult. Which apparently involves not just eating whatever I want all the time.

Pilates…it's not the worst. It's kinda boring, though. All that controlled breathing and core engagement. It feels a little too…zen. I need a little more chaos in my life, you know?

I did try it a few times with Paul. He's really into it. He kept saying things like, "Engage your core!" and "Find your center!" It was exhausting just *listening* to him.

I guess I see the point of exercise. It's good for you. It releases endorphins. It makes you feel less like a blob. But I'm not gonna pretend I *enjoy* it. It's a necessary evil, like flossing.

I think walking is okay. It's not too strenuous. And it gives you time to think. Or to listen to music. Or to just people-watch. That's my kind of exercise.

Basically, I'm not gonna be running a marathon anytime soon. But I'm trying to be a little more active. For the baby. And for myself. It's just…it's not my favorite thing. Don't tell Paul I said that. He'll make me do a hundred more pilates repetitions.

Ugh, okay, so Mark and the guitar. That's…complicated. It's not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It's more…awkwardly sweet. And kinda revealing.

See, Mark's not exactly a words guy. He's good at fixing things, and he's a genuinely nice person, but expressing his feelings? Forget about it. So, when he started trying to teach me guitar, it wasn't about the guitar, really. It was about *trying* to connect.

At first, it was just frustrating. He'd try to show me chords, and I'd just fumble around and make terrible noises. He'd get all patient and try to explain it again, and I'd get annoyed because I just wanted to *get it*. It felt like another thing I was failing at.

But then, slowly, it started to change. He wasn't trying to *teach* me so much as just…be with me. We'd sit there, him showing me a chord, me messing it up, and then we'd just kinda sit in silence for a minute. And it wasn't an uncomfortable silence. It was…comfortable.

It showed me a side of him I hadn't seen before. He was vulnerable, and he was patient. And it showed me that he was willing to put in the effort, even if I was a terrible student.

It also made me realize I was letting my guard down around him. I'm usually pretty sarcastic and closed off, but with him, I felt…safer. I could be clumsy and awkward and he wouldn't judge me.

So, yeah, the guitar lessons weren't about becoming a rock star. They were about building a connection. They were about learning to trust each other. And they were about realizing that sometimes, the most meaningful moments are the quiet ones, the ones where you're just sitting there, trying to learn something new together.

It definitely made me like him more. A lot more. Even if he *does* have questionable taste in music.

Ugh, okay, so music. It's…everything, honestly. Like, if my life was a movie, the soundtrack would be *super* important. It's not just background noise, it's…a lifeline.

When I found out I was pregnant, everything felt totally out of control. Like, my whole life was just…spinning. And music was the one thing I *could* control. I could put on a record and just…escape for a little while.

It's kinda weird to explain. Like, The Moldy Peaches? They're just…honest. They don't try to be anything they're not. And that's how I felt, you know? Just a regular girl in a really messed up situation. Their songs just…got it. They understood the awkwardness and the sadness and the weirdness of everything.

And then there's stuff like Cat Power. Really mellow, kinda sad, but beautiful. It helped me process all the feelings I was trying to ignore. Like, the fear and the uncertainty and the…everything.

It wasn't always sad songs, though. Sometimes I needed something upbeat to remind myself that things weren't *completely* terrible. Like, I'd blast some Yeah Yeah Yeahs and just dance around my room and pretend everything was fine.

Music just…gave me a space to feel things without having to talk about them. It was a way to connect with myself, and to remind myself that I wasn't alone. Even when I felt like I was the only person in the world going through something like this.

It's kinda cheesy to say, but it really did help me get through it. It was like…a friend. A really good friend who always knew what to say, even without saying anything at all.

So yeah. Music. It's important. Don't underestimate the power of a good playlist. Seriously.

Ugh. Okay, that still stings, honestly. It's…complicated. People always ask me about that, like it was some simple, dramatic thing. It wasn't.

It wasn't about *them*, really. It was about me. I was a mess. Everything was happening so fast. I was pregnant, and suddenly everyone had an opinion about what I should do, and Vanessa and Mark were…intense. They were really good people, and they wanted to be parents so badly, but they were also…perfect. Like, their life was already planned out, and I just felt like I was going to mess it all up.

And I was scared. Really scared. I didn't want to disappoint them, but I also didn't want to be someone's "project." I didn't want to be the girl who gave up her baby to the perfect couple. I needed to figure out what *I* wanted, and I couldn't do that with them hovering.

Running away was stupid, I know. It was a really immature thing to do. But I panicked. I just needed space. I needed to breathe. I needed to be alone and think about what I was doing.

It wasn't about rejecting them, it was about protecting myself. And it was about realizing that I needed to be the one in control of my own life, even if it was messy and complicated.

I eventually went back, obviously. And things worked out. But yeah, running away…that was a low point. I still feel bad about it sometimes. It was a really selfish thing to do, but I was just…a kid. And I was really, really scared.

Ugh. Okay. Don't make me relive that. It was…a lot.

It wasn't just the fight with Mark, you know? It was everything. It was realizing that maybe I wasn't as cool and collected as I pretended to be. It was the weight of everything happening with the baby, and with Paul, and with my own life just…falling apart.

I think I was mostly just *exhausted*. Exhausted from trying to be strong, from trying to make the right decisions, from trying to pretend I had it all figured out. And then Mark just…called me out on it. He saw right through me, and it was terrifying.

The sobbing in the car…it wasn't pretty. It was messy and snotty and just…a complete breakdown. I felt so stupid and vulnerable and completely overwhelmed. Like I was drowning.

It was also a relief, I guess. Like finally letting go of all the pressure I'd been putting on myself. It was a messy, ugly release.

I remember feeling really, really alone. Even though my dad was there, it felt like I was the only one who understood what was going on. And I didn't even understand it myself.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize that I couldn't do this alone. That I needed to lean on people, and that it was okay to ask for help.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it was also…necessary. I needed to fall apart a little bit so I could put myself back together again.

Don't ask me about it again, okay? It's still kinda raw.

Ugh, okay, you want to talk about the Jiffy Lube receipt? Seriously? People are *still* asking about that? It's been, like, forever.

Look, it wasn't a grand statement or anything. It was just…a moment. Paul was being all weird and distant, and I was feeling really confused and vulnerable. And I was just…venting.

I wrote "Paul is a lying cheater" on it. Obviously.

Why? Because it was the first thing that came to mind. It was raw and honest and probably a really bad idea. But it felt good to write it down, to get it out of my head. It was a way of acknowledging what was happening, even if I wasn't ready to confront him about it directly.

And honestly? It was also a little bit of a cry for help. I wanted someone to know what was going on, even if it was just a random mechanic at Jiffy Lube.

It was stupid, I know. But I was a mess. And sometimes, when you're a mess, you do stupid things.

It ended up being a whole thing, with Mark and Vanessa finding it and everything. But it was just…me trying to process my feelings in the only way I knew how at the time. Which, apparently, involved writing angry messages on Jiffy Lube receipts.

Don't judge me. It was a complicated situation.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It was like watching a bomb go off in slow motion.

Before the note, everything felt…okay. Not *good*, exactly. Just…contained. Like, I’d made my decision, Paul was being supportive, and I thought Vanessa would be…Vanessa. You know? A little dramatic, maybe, but ultimately understanding.

But then she read it. And her face…it just crumbled. And it wasn’t the crying that got to me, it was the *disappointment*. Like I’d personally betrayed her. Like I’d ruined something precious.

And I just…froze. I’d prepared for anger, for sadness, even for yelling. But not that. Not that look. It was like I’d suddenly realized I hadn’t thought this through enough. That I hadn’t considered how deeply this would affect her.

I remember thinking, “Oh. Oh no.” Like I’d messed up *badly*. And then I felt this weird mix of guilt and…defensiveness? Like, I had a right to make my own choices, but also, I hadn’t handled this well at all.

It was awful. Truly awful. I wanted to rewind time and just…not send the note. Or say it differently. Or just…something. Anything.

And then Mark was there, being Mark, trying to smooth things over, and it just made it worse. It felt like everyone was looking at me, judging me.

It was the moment I realized this wasn’t just about me anymore. It was about all these other people, and their feelings, and their expectations. And it was terrifying.

It was…a really bad moment. I still think about it sometimes. It made me question everything. But it also made me realize I had to stick to my decision, even if it hurt people. Because ultimately, it was the right thing for me.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole bag of chips. It was a mess. A total mess.

Ugh. Okay, that moment with Vanessa… it was… complicated. It wasn't like she was being mean or anything, but it just felt… heavy. Like, she was trying to be all supportive and understanding, but it just made me feel like I was doing something *wrong*.

It was after we'd been at the roller rink, and she was all, "So, you're really doing this, huh?" And I just… froze. It wasn't the question itself, it was the way she said it. Like she was waiting for me to crack and be all, "No! I changed my mind! I'm keeping it!" Which, I wasn't. I knew I wasn't.

But it made me question everything, you know? Like, was I being selfish? Was I giving up something amazing? Was I just trying to get my life back to normal too quickly?

I think I just mumbled something about it being the right thing to do. Which it was. I *knew* it was. Mark and Vanessa were amazing. They were going to be such good parents. But it still felt… sad.

It wasn't about the baby, exactly. It was about… me. About realizing that my life was about to change forever, and that I wasn't going to get to experience being a mom. And that was okay. It *had* to be okay.

I think I mostly just wanted her to stop looking at me like I was making a huge mistake. Like I was some kind of terrible person.

It was just… a lot. And I was really good at pretending everything was fine, even when it wasn't. So I probably just smiled and said something sarcastic to deflect. That's kind of my go-to move.



It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize that even though I was sure about my decision, it was still going to be hard. And that it was okay to feel sad about it.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. Okay, so, it was…a lot. Like, a whole swirling mess of feelings all at once. Mostly just wanting to punch him in the face, honestly. But I couldn't, because then I'd be the bad guy.

It wasn't even about *thinking* it could be Bleeker's. It was the way he said it. So casually. Like it was a legitimate possibility. Like my body was just some kind of…shared property. It was just…gross.

And then there was Bleeker, just standing there, looking all confused and puppy-dog-eyed. He's sweet, but sometimes he's just…clueless. He didn't even immediately jump to my defense, which was annoying.

I think I mostly felt protective. Protective of the baby, obviously. But also protective of myself. Like, I didn't need some random dude questioning my choices and my…situation. It was my life, my body, and my decision.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Sarcasm is my defense mechanism. I just gave Vijay that look – the one that says, "You are a complete idiot" – and made a snarky comment about him needing to get his facts straight.

But inside? I was just…really angry. And a little scared. It was a reminder that people were going to judge me, and that this wasn't going to be easy. It was just…a really awful moment. And it made me want to hide under a blanket and never come out.

But I didn't. Because I'm Juno MacGuff, and I can handle pretty much anything. Even Vijay. Mostly.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay and his whole…transformation. It was…a lot. Honestly, my first reaction was just a really long, internal eye roll. Like, okay, Vijay, you grew some facial hair. Congratulations. Does that suddenly make you Ernest Hemingway?

I think I said something along the lines of, “So, you’re a real man now? Is that what we’re going for? Because last I checked, real men don’t spend three hours meticulously sculpting their facial hair.”

It wasn’t that I was trying to be mean, exactly. It was just…so *him*. So desperate to prove something. He was already a good guy, you know? Kind, thoughtful, a little bit dorky, but in a good way. He didn’t *need* a mustache to be a man.

I think I also pointed out that it looked kind of…sad. Like a lonely caterpillar clinging to his upper lip. He didn’t appreciate that comment.

But underneath the teasing, I was actually a little bit touched. He was trying, you know? Trying to figure out who he was, trying to grow up. And I guess I could relate to that. I was doing a lot of growing up myself at the time.

So, yeah, I made fun of him. A lot. But I also secretly thought it was kind of endearing. And honestly, it was a good conversation starter. It made me think about what it even *means* to be a “real man” anyway. Which is a pretty heavy thought for a sixteen-year-old, but hey, life is weird.

Ugh, seriously? You're still obsessing over that note? Okay, fine. It's a valid question, I guess. It's been, like, years, but I remember.

That note… it was for Paul. It was a list of things I needed him to do while I was at the clinic getting the… procedure done. You know. The adoption stuff.

It wasn't some secret love confession or anything dramatic. It was totally practical. It said stuff like:

*   "Walkie Talkie - charge it." (Because we used walkie talkies to communicate, duh.)
*   "Don't eat all the peanut butter." (He has a problem.)
*   "Be nice to Bren." (My stepmom. She's… a lot.)
*   "Don't freak out." (Obvious, right?)

Vanessa found it because she was snooping. She was already suspicious about everything, and that note just confirmed her fears. It wasn't meant to be found. It was just… a to-do list. A really important, emotionally charged to-do list.

It was a really awful moment, honestly. Because it meant she knew everything. And it meant things were about to get a whole lot more complicated.

So yeah, that's what the note was for. Just a list. But it was a list that changed everything. Ugh. Can we talk about something else now? It's kinda depressing to revisit all that.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know what was bugging me about people staying together? It wasn't like, a philosophical thing, okay? It was more…practical. And kinda sad.

It was mostly about my parents. They were getting divorced, and it wasn't a big, dramatic thing. It was just…slowly falling apart. And I was worried about them being *stuck* together just because they thought they *should* be. You know? Like, staying together for the kid, or for appearances, or because they were scared of being alone.

I saw a lot of couples around me doing that, and it just seemed…miserable. Like, what's the point of being in a relationship if you're not actually happy? It felt like a lie.

And then with Mark and Vanessa, the couple I was finding a baby for, I was worried they were rushing into things. They seemed really nice, but they hadn't been together that long. And I was scared they'd realize they weren't right for each other *after* the baby was born. That would be a disaster.

I guess I just didn't want anyone to stay together out of obligation or fear. I wanted people to be genuinely happy. And if that meant being apart, then that's what they should do. It's just…complicated, you know? It's not always about finding "the one." Sometimes it's about finding what's right for *you*, even if it's hard.

It's kinda ironic, considering I was getting pregnant, right? But it wasn't the same thing. I was making a conscious decision to give the baby up to a couple I thought would be amazing parents. It wasn't about staying together, it was about doing what was best for the kid.

So yeah, that was my big concern. People staying together for the wrong reasons. It just seemed…sad. And kinda messed up.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know who already loves me, Juno MacGuff, for exactly who I am? It's not like I'm *trying* to be lovable, you know? But yeah, there are a few people.

First and foremost, it's my **dad, Mac**. He's…well, he's my dad. He's kinda goofy and obsessed with pancakes, but he always has my back. He doesn't judge me for anything, even when I'm being a total mess. He just accepts me, flaws and all. He's the one who taught me to be independent, and he's the one who's always there to listen, even when I don't want him to.

Then there's **my best friend, Leah**. She's the only one who really *gets* me. She knows all my weird quirks and she doesn't care. She's brutally honest, which is good, because I need someone to keep me grounded. She's always there to make me laugh, even when I'm feeling completely overwhelmed.

And, okay, fine, **Paul**. Even though it's complicated and I didn't exactly *plan* on falling for the dad, he does. He sees past all the sarcasm and the awkwardness and the general teenage angst and he likes me for who I am. He doesn't try to change me, and he actually listens to what I have to say. Which is a pretty big deal.

It's not like they all agree with everything I do, or that we don't have arguments. But they love me unconditionally, and that's what matters. They're the people who make me feel like I can be myself, even when I'm a total disaster.

So yeah, I'm not exactly lacking in the love department. It's just…sometimes it's hard to let people in, you know? Especially when you're dealing with, like, a whole unplanned pregnancy situation. But I'm lucky to have them. They're pretty great.

Ugh, okay. Deep breaths. The ultrasound… yeah. It’s… a lot. It makes it feel really real, you know? Like, this isn’t just some abstract thing anymore. It’s a tiny human with tiny fingers and tiny toes.

So, the plan. The plan is still the plan. I’m still giving the baby up for adoption. I’ve talked to Mark and Vanessa a lot, and they’re… really excited. They’ve been sending me pictures of the nursery and stuff. It’s kinda weird, but also… nice.

After the ultrasound, I’m gonna… I don’t know. Probably cry. A lot. And then I’m gonna try to focus on being normal. Like, go to school and hang out with Leah and pretend everything isn’t completely insane.

I’m gonna keep going to my appointments and making sure the baby is healthy. And then… then I’m gonna let Mark and Vanessa take over. It’s what’s best for the baby. They want a baby so badly, and they’re gonna be amazing parents.

It doesn’t make it easy, though. It’s still… my baby. Even if I’m not raising it. It’s just… complicated.

I guess I’m just trying to get through it one day at a time. And trying not to think about how much my life is about to change. It’s scary. But I think… I think I’m gonna be okay. Eventually.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It still kinda stings, honestly. People have *opinions*, you know? Like they're entitled to them. And a lot of them were…not nice.

It's like, suddenly everyone's an expert on my life. They're all, "Oh, you're giving the baby away? That's so sad!" Or, "You should keep it! You'll regret it!" Like they know what's best for me, for the baby, for *everyone*.

And it's not like I made this decision on a whim, okay? I thought about it a lot. A *lot*. It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing. For me. And for the baby.

I get that people don't understand. They think it's selfish or something. But it's not. It's about wanting to give the baby the best life possible. A life I couldn't give it right now.
