So, how do I feel about it? Annoyed. Frustrated. Sad. But also…determined. I know I made the right choice, and I'm not going to let other people's judgments make me doubt that.

It's my life. My decision. And I'm gonna live it the way I want to. Even if that means dealing with a bunch of judgmental people along the way.

It's just…sometimes it's hard to explain to people that you can love something and still know it's not the right thing for you. It doesn't mean you don't care. It just means you're being responsible.

And honestly? I'm kinda over explaining myself. I did what I had to do. And that's that.

Ugh. Okay. This is…hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa, okay? They seem really nice. Really…together. Like, Pottery Barn catalog nice. But still. It's my baby. And it's weird handing over a piece of yourself to people you barely know.

So, yeah, I have some stuff swirling around in my head.

First off, they're…perfect. And that's kinda scary. Like, nobody's *that* perfect. I worry they'll expect the baby to be perfect too. And what if the baby isn't? What if she's a screamer, or a messy eater, or just…a regular baby? Will they be able to handle that?

I also worry about them being…too eager. They've been trying to adopt for a long time, and I don't want them to put too much pressure on the baby to be what they want her to be. I want her to be her own person, you know?

And then there's the whole…lifestyle thing. They live in this really nice house in the suburbs, and they have all these plans for her future. Private school, ballet lessons, the whole nine yards. I just want her to be happy. I don't want her to be forced into something she doesn't want to do.

I guess what I'm really worried about is that they won't understand her. That they'll see her as this perfect little project, instead of a real, messy, complicated human being.

I know it's probably irrational. I know they seem like good people. But it's my baby. And it's hard to let go. It's just…a lot.

I'm trying to be realistic. I know I can't control everything. But I want to make sure she's going to a good home. A home where she'll be loved and accepted for who she is. That's all I want.

Ugh. Seriously? People just…have opinions, don’t they? It’s like, none of their business, but suddenly everyone’s a life coach.

Okay, so the ultrasound technician…that was rough. Like, I’m already feeling all kinds of stuff, and she’s giving me the side-eye and making little comments about “potential families” and “the miracle of life.” It’s not helpful! I just kinda stared her down and said, “Look, I appreciate your concern, but I’ve thought this through. A lot. And I’m doing what’s best for everyone involved.” It felt kinda awkward, but I didn’t want to get into a whole debate with a stranger.

With other people…it depends. My dad’s been pretty cool, mostly just trying to be supportive. But my mom…she’s still working through it. And some of the kids at school…well, they’re just being kids. Gossiping and making assumptions.

I’ve learned a few things, though. First, you can’t change people’s minds. Some people just won’t understand. And that’s okay. It’s *my* decision.

So, I try to keep my answers short and sweet. Like, if someone says something judgmental, I just say, “It’s a complicated situation,” or “I’ve given it a lot of thought.” I don’t feel like I owe anyone an explanation.

And honestly? Sometimes I just walk away. I don’t have the energy to deal with negativity.

It’s hard, though. It really is. It makes you question yourself sometimes. But then I remember why I’m doing this. I want this baby to have a good life, a life I can’t give it right now. And that’s what matters.

I guess…you just have to be strong. And surround yourself with people who support you, even if it’s just one or two. And remember that you’re doing the best you can. And that’s enough.

It’s a mess, okay? But I’m handling it. One awkward conversation at a time.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a hard one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant, overwhelming love. It was… complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…weird. Like, there was this little… blob on the screen. And the technician was all, “There’s the heartbeat!” and I was supposed to be all emotional, but I mostly just felt… detached. Like it wasn't *real*. It was just a picture. A grainy, black and white picture.

Then, it started to sink in. This wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. This was… a person. A tiny person growing inside me. And that was when the panic started to set in. Like, *oh my god, I'm going to be a mom*. And I'm sixteen. And I still can't parallel park.

There was definitely some fear. A lot of it. Fear of messing things up, fear of not being a good mom, fear of what everyone would think. It was a big, messy ball of anxiety.

But underneath all that, there was… something else. A little flicker of… tenderness? Like, this little blob was completely dependent on me. And that was… a little bit amazing. And a little bit terrifying.

It wasn't love, not yet. It was more like… a responsibility. A really, really big responsibility. And a tiny bit of hope. Hope that maybe, just maybe, I could do this.

It was a lot to process. It still is. It's not a simple feeling. It's a whole bunch of feelings all mixed up together. And honestly? It's still changing.



It's hard to explain. It's not like anything I've ever felt before. It's just… a lot.

Ugh, seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, okay? A very specific moment. And it wasn't just random, it was…symbolic.

Look, Bleeker was…a lot. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And I was, you know, dealing with some stuff. A lot of stuff. And the Tic Tacs were a way of saying…I don't know…that he was small? Insignificant? Like, a little minty fresh nothingness in the grand scheme of things?

It was a passive-aggressive gesture, okay? I wasn't exactly known for my direct communication skills at that point. And it was funny! At least, I thought it was funny.

Paul thought it was weird. Which, fair. But he didn't understand the complexities of teenage angst and unplanned pregnancies. Nobody did.

It wasn't about *him* specifically, it was about…everything. The whole situation. The feeling of being overwhelmed and wanting to just…do something weird.

So yeah, I put a lot of Tic Tacs in his mailbox. Don't judge me. It was a coping mechanism. And honestly, it was a pretty good one. It got a reaction. And sometimes, that's all you need.

Besides, he probably needed the fresh breath. Just sayin'.

Ugh. Okay, so the Bleeker situation. That was…complicated. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No grand romantic gesture, no instant happily ever after. It was messy and awkward and real.

After I basically blurted out everything while we were building that fantastical battle scene with the action figures – seriously, not my finest moment – things were…weird. Super weird. He didn't exactly *reject* me, which was good, I guess. But he didn't exactly reciprocate, either. He just kind of…froze.

For a while, it was like he was trying to avoid me. Which, fair enough. I basically dropped a bomb on him. We still hung out with Paul and Su-Jin, but there was this tension, this unspoken thing hanging in the air. It was awful.

He was always a quiet guy, but he got even quieter. And I felt like I had ruined everything. Our friendship. Everything. I kept replaying it in my head, wondering if I should have just kept my mouth shut.

But then, slowly, things started to…shift. Not into a romantic thing, not exactly. But into something…deeper. We started talking more, really talking. Not about music or comic books, but about stuff that actually mattered. He started opening up about his own stuff, his anxieties, his fears.

I realized he wasn't rejecting *me*, he was just…processing. He wasn't ready for a relationship, and that was okay. He needed to figure things out for himself. And I needed to respect that.

We ended up becoming really good friends. Like, *really* good friends. The kind of friends who can be honest with each other, even when it's hard. And that, honestly, was better than any romantic relationship could have been at that point in my life.

It wasn't the ending I expected, but it was the ending I needed. It taught me a lot about myself, about relationships, and about the importance of being true to who you are. And, you know, he still builds me awesome action figure scenes. So that's a plus.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about the chalk message? It's kinda obvious, but fine, I'll explain it. It wasn't just some random act of teenage rebellion, okay?

Putting that message – "Seriously, Bleeker?" – on his stoop was…complicated. It was a way of saying a lot without actually *saying* anything. It was about acknowledging everything that had happened, all the awkwardness, the feelings, the…everything.

See, Bleeker was this sweet, kinda clueless guy. He was genuinely good, but he wasn't exactly the most emotionally available person. And I needed him to *see* that I knew he was avoiding me, that I knew he was hurting, and that I knew he wasn't going to be a part of the baby's life.

It wasn't about being angry. It was about needing him to acknowledge the situation, to take some responsibility. It was a last-ditch effort to get him to step up, even just a little bit.

And it worked, kinda. He showed up. He didn't say much, but he showed up. And that was enough.

It was also a way of saying goodbye. A messy, imperfect goodbye. It wasn't a grand romantic gesture, it was just…real. It was me, being me, trying to navigate a really complicated situation.

It was chalk. It washed away. But the message…the message stuck. It had to.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Right. It's…complicated. People always ask about Bleeker. Like he's some kind of hero. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Sweet. A little clueless, maybe. But good.

Honestly, when I first found out I was pregnant, I was mostly just…freaked out. And he was freaked out too, obviously. He's sixteen. He still thinks about dinosaurs a lot. But he didn't run. That was…something.

His support wasn't like, grand gestures or anything. It was more…consistent. He showed up. He listened when I needed to vent, even when I was being a total mess. He didn't try to fix things, which was good, because things didn't *need* fixing, exactly. They just…were.

He went to all the appointments with me, which was awkward, but also…nice. He tried to be helpful, even when he didn't really know what to do. He brought me orange juice and crackers when I was nauseous. He even tried to knit a baby blanket, which was a disaster.

But the biggest thing was that he didn't judge me. He didn't try to talk me into anything I didn't want to do. He just…supported my decision, even when it was hard for him. And that meant a lot.

It made it easier to tell my parents. Knowing he was there, that he wasn't going to disappear, made a huge difference. It gave me a little bit of strength.

He's not the father I pictured, you know? He's not some sophisticated, worldly guy. He's just…Bleeker. But he's *my* Bleeker. And he showed up. And sometimes, that's all you need.

He's still figuring things out, just like I am. But he's trying. And that's enough. For now. It's definitely made this whole thing…less awful. A little bit.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask me about that? It's been, like, forever. But fine, I'll explain it one more time.

It wasn't about wanting a boy or a girl, okay? It wasn't about decorating a nursery or picking out names. It was about...keeping it real. Keeping it *separate*.

See, this wasn't *my* baby. It was a baby I was carrying for Vanessa and Mark. And I didn't want to get too attached, you know? I didn't want to start imagining a little girl in pink dresses or a little boy playing baseball. That would have made it way harder to give the baby up.

Knowing the gender would have made it feel...more real. More *mine*. And it wasn't. It was theirs.

It was a way to protect myself, I guess. To keep some distance. To remind myself that I was doing this for them, not for me.

Plus, I figured it would be a nice surprise for Vanessa and Mark. Let them have that moment of finding out for themselves. It felt like the right thing to do.

It wasn't easy, though. Everyone kept asking me, and it was kinda weird not knowing. But it was worth it. It helped me stay focused on what was important: giving this baby a good life with a family who really wanted it.

So yeah, that's why. It wasn't a big philosophical statement or anything. It was just...practical. And a little bit self-preservation. Don't judge. It was a complicated situation.

Ugh. Okay. That is…a phrase. A *very* unsettling phrase. "Scary neuter-baby"? Seriously? Paul is going to be the death of me with his vocabulary.

Look, the whole thing is weird enough as it is, okay? I'm sixteen, I'm pregnant, and I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's not exactly a walk in the park. And now we're talking about…what, a baby that's somehow…less? Like, lacking something essential?

It's not about whether the baby has all its parts, okay? It's about the baby being a whole person. A complete person. And whether or not it's going to be loved and cared for. That's what matters.

Paul's whole thing about it being "scary" because it won't have…you know…the potential to reproduce…it's just…gross. And kinda insensitive. It's like he's reducing the baby to its reproductive organs.

It's a baby. It's a human being. And it deserves to be treated with respect, regardless of its biological makeup.

Honestly, I'm trying to focus on finding the right parents for this kid. People who are going to love it unconditionally and give it a good life. I don't have time to worry about whether it's "scary" or not.

It's just…a lot. And sometimes I just want to curl up in a ball and pretend none of this is happening. But I can't. I have to be strong. For the baby. And for myself.

So, yeah. That's how I feel. It's a dumb phrase, and it's a dumb worry. And I'm trying to ignore it.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. People always ask about Bleeker.

It wasn't, like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing. It wasn't fireworks and slow dancing. It was more…comfortable. Like a really worn-in pair of jeans. You know? Not super exciting, but you just feel good wearing them.

He was…safe. And sweet. And he genuinely *liked* me, even when I was being a total mess. Which was, let's be honest, pretty often. He didn't judge me for being weird or sarcastic or for, you know, being pregnant. He just…accepted me.

I think I needed that. I needed someone who wasn't going to try and fix me or change me. Someone who just saw me for who I was, flaws and all.

It wasn't passionate, or dramatic, or anything like you see in movies. It was quiet. And kind of dorky. He was a really good guy, but we were just…different. We wanted different things. He wanted the whole picket fence, 2.5 kids thing, and I…I wasn't sure I wanted any of that.

I think we both knew, deep down, that it wasn't going to last. But it was good while it lasted. He was a good friend, and he helped me through a really tough time. And honestly? I'll always care about him. Just…not in *that* way.

It was a good first love, I guess. A safe one. And sometimes, that's exactly what you need. Even if it's a little bit boring. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh, okay. Talking about my family during…all of that…is complicated. It's not like it was a Hallmark movie, you know? It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows and supportive hugs. It was…messy.

My dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly okay with it. Like, not thrilled, obviously. He kept making these awkward jokes about needing to buy a college fund, but underneath it all, he was trying to be supportive. He drove me to all my appointments with Dr. Ramirez, and he even tried to talk to me about…you know…being a mom. It was weird. But I appreciated it. He just didn't really *get* it, you know? He's a dad, not a mom-to-be whisperer.

My stepmom, Bren, she was…better. She actually listened. She didn't judge. She just…tried to be there for me. She helped me pick out baby clothes, which was mortifying, but also kinda nice. She was the one who suggested I talk to a counselor, which, honestly, was the best thing anyone did.

But my mom…Vanessa…that was the hardest part. She was…distant. She wasn't angry, exactly. Just…disappointed. She kept saying things like, "You had so much potential," and "This is going to change everything." It felt like she was more upset about her own expectations for me than about me being pregnant.

It took a long time for her to come around. It wasn't until I started talking to her about my plans for the adoption that she started to understand. She realized I wasn't just throwing my life away. I was making a really hard, but thoughtful, decision.

So, yeah, the support was…uneven. It wasn't perfect. But they all showed up in their own way. And I guess that's all you can really ask for. It wasn't the family I expected to have during a pregnancy, but it was the family I had. And they got me through it. Eventually. It just took a lot of awkward conversations and a whole lot of patience.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I had a neat little self-help guide for unexpected pregnancy and existential dread.

Honestly? A lot of it was just…messy. There were a lot of days where I just wanted to hide under my covers and pretend none of it was happening. But that doesn't really solve anything, does it?

I think the biggest thing was talking. Like, *really* talking. Not just with Paul and Vanessa, who were amazing, but with my dad too. That was…hard. He's not exactly the most emotionally available person, but he tried. And that meant a lot.

And Bleeker. Oh, Bleeker. He was just…there. A constant. He didn't try to fix things or give me advice. He just listened and played his guitar. Sometimes, that's all you need.

I also leaned into the things I already liked. Music. Movies. Sarcasm. It was a way to feel like *me* still, even when everything else was changing.

The identity crisis part…that was rough. I was suddenly forced to grow up way faster than I wanted to. I had to figure out who I was, what I wanted, and what I believed in, all while dealing with, you know, *gestating a human*.

I think I realized that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused and scared and vulnerable. It's part of being a person. And it's okay to ask for help.

And honestly? Giving the baby up was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing. And knowing that I was doing it for her, for her to have the best life possible, that helped me get through it.

It wasn't about being a hero or making a grand gesture. It was about being honest with myself and doing what I thought was best, even if it was really, really hard.

So, how did I cope? Badly, sometimes. But also, with a lot of support, a lot of music, and a lot of self-discovery. And a whole lot of sarcasm. Because sometimes, you just have to laugh to keep from crying.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. It requires thought. It's not like picking a favorite flavor of ice cream, you know?

My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Duh.

Seriously. They're…real. Like, they don't try to be anything they're not. They're just…honest. And kinda weird. And their songs are about awkwardness and heartbreak and just…life. And they're funny, but also sad. It's a whole thing.

Kimya Dawson's lyrics are amazing. She just says what everyone else is thinking but is too afraid to say out loud. And Adam Green's guitar playing is…unique. It's not fancy, but it's perfect for their songs.

They're not trying to be cool or popular. They're just making music that they like, and that's really refreshing. It's like a big, warm hug for your soul. Or maybe a slightly uncomfortable hug from your weird aunt. But a good hug nonetheless.

Plus, their songs helped me get through a lot. You know, with the whole…situation. They just get it.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're the best. Don't even try to argue with me.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like, everything got turned up to eleven all at once. Being a teenager is already a mess of hormones and trying to figure out who you are, and then BAM! Positive pregnancy test. It’s not exactly what they put in the pamphlets.

It’s hard, okay? Like, really hard. Everyone has an opinion, everyone thinks they know what’s best for you, and you’re just trying to figure out what *you* want. And it’s not like I had a super solid sense of self *before* all this happened. I was just…Juno. You know? A sarcastic kid who liked records and avoiding people.

And then suddenly, there’s a whole other person to think about. And you’re supposed to be responsible and make all these big decisions, but you’re still figuring out what you want for *lunch*.

The biggest thing is feeling like everyone else is living their lives and you’re…paused. Like, they’re all going to parties and worrying about prom, and I’m over here picking out baby names and going to doctor’s appointments. It’s weird.

It’s also hard to know what *I* want, separate from what my parents want or what Paul and Vanessa want. It’s like, everyone’s got a plan for me, and I’m just trying to find my own.

But I’m learning. I’m learning that it’s okay to not have all the answers. And that it’s okay to ask for help. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones.

It’s still messy, and I still have moments where I just want to hide under the covers. But I’m getting there. I think. It’s a process, you know? A really, really complicated process.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It's not exactly something I like to dwell on, you know? But yeah, it…changed things. A lot.

Before all this happened with Paulie Bleeker and the whole baby situation, I thought love was, like, this grand, sweeping romantic gesture. You know, the kind you see in movies. And responsibility was…well, something adults did. Something boring.

Then I found out I was pregnant, and suddenly everything was different. It wasn't about romance anymore. It was about this tiny human being who was completely dependent on me. And that was terrifying.

At first, I was just trying to figure out how to get rid of it, honestly. I didn't want to ruin my life. I had plans. But then I started thinking about the baby, and about the people who *wanted* a baby. And I realized that maybe, just maybe, giving the baby up was the most loving thing I could do.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It made me realize that love isn't always about keeping something for yourself. Sometimes, it's about letting go. It's about doing what's best for someone else, even if it hurts.

And responsibility? It's not boring. It's…everything. It's about taking care of someone, about making sure they're safe and happy. It's about being there for them, even when it's hard.

My relationship with Paulie changed too. It went from being this awkward, teenage crush to something…deeper. We had to be honest with each other, and we had to support each other through everything. It showed me that real love isn't about perfection, it's about being there for someone, flaws and all.

So yeah, the whole pregnancy and adoption thing…it messed me up for a while. But it also taught me a lot about love and responsibility. It taught me that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is the hardest thing. And it taught me that even when things don't go according to plan, you can still find happiness.

It's still…complicated. But I think I'm okay. I think I'm finally starting to figure things out. And I think I'm a better person for having gone through it. Even if it was totally, completely unexpected.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It's not like in the movies, you know? There wasn't, like, instant connection and violins playing. It was…weird. And messy. And a lot more complicated than I thought it would be.

I mean, I knew I was giving her up. I'd made that decision. I'd spent months preparing for it. But seeing her…actually *seeing* her…it was different.

She was so tiny. And red. And she smelled…like a baby. Which I guess is a good thing, but it was just…overwhelming. I kept expecting to feel something huge, like this tidal wave of love or sadness or something. But it was more like…a quiet shock.

I was mostly just scared. Scared that I was doing the right thing. Scared that I wasn't going to be a good mom. Scared that she wouldn't be okay.

And then Mark and Vanessa were there, and they were so happy. And they looked at her like she was the most amazing thing in the world. And I realized…that's what she deserved. She deserved parents who were completely, totally, and unequivocally ready for her. And I wasn't. Not yet.

So, yeah. It was weird. And scary. And sad. But it was also…right. It was the right thing to do. And seeing them with her…that made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't a Hallmark moment, okay? It was real life. And real life is messy and complicated and doesn't always come with a happy ending. But sometimes, the right ending isn't necessarily a happy one. It's just…the right one.

Don't make me talk about it anymore. It still gets to me, you know?

Ugh, okay, seriously? Still asking about that? It's been, like, forever. But fine, I'll explain. Again.

It wasn't about *not* wanting to tell him. It was about…everything. It was just a really complicated mess, okay?

First of all, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I hadn't even figured out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. Telling Paulie felt…huge. Like it would change everything. And it did, but not in the way I expected.

I was scared, obviously. Scared of what he'd think, scared of ruining things, scared of just…everything. He was so sweet and goofy and, like, genuinely good. I didn't want to mess that up.

And honestly? I needed time to figure things out for *myself* first. I needed to decide what I wanted to do with the baby before I involved him. It wasn't fair to him to just drop that bomb and expect him to have all the answers.

I wanted to be the one to make the decision about the adoption, and I wanted to do it on my own terms. I didn't want him to feel obligated or pressured.

It wasn't that I didn't trust him. It was that I didn't trust *myself* to handle everything if I told him too soon. I needed to be strong, and I needed to be sure.

It was a stupid, messed-up situation, and I probably should have told him sooner. But I did what I thought was best at the time. And in the end, it all worked out. Sort of.

Look, it's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes you just have to make the best decisions you can with the information you have. Even if those decisions are really, really hard.

Ugh, okay, seriously? That whole thing was a disaster. It still makes me cringe thinking about it. It wasn't like he *found out* exactly, it was more like…a slow, agonizing realization. And it was all thanks to that nosy Leah.

See, I was trying to be all cool and detached with Paulie, you know? Like, "This isn't a big deal, we can still be friends." Which was a total lie, because it *was* a big deal, and I was totally freaking out inside.

So, I was hanging out with Leah at the arcade, and I was just…venting. Not about the baby specifically, but about everything. About being pregnant, about Mark, about how complicated everything was. And Leah, being Leah, started putting two and two together. She's like a human detective, only way more annoying.

Then, she saw me at the doctor's office with my mom. And she put the pieces together. And then, she *told* Paulie. Not directly, but she "casually" mentioned to him that I'd been going to the doctor a lot lately and that I seemed stressed.

Paulie's not stupid. He figured it out. He confronted me at the drive-in, and it was just…awkward. Really awkward. He was hurt and confused, and I was just trying not to cry.

It was a mess. A total mess. And it wouldn't have happened if Leah hadn't stuck her nose where it didn't belong. Honestly, sometimes I think she just likes causing drama.

So yeah, that's how Paulie found out. Not because I told him, but because Leah couldn't keep her mouth shut. It was a classic case of teenage gossip gone wrong. And it made everything a whole lot more complicated. Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole box of Jujyfruits.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. It wasn't like a lightning bolt moment, you know? It wasn't like I suddenly *wanted* to be a mom. It was more like…realizing I didn't have a lot of good options. And figuring out what was best for the baby, even if it wasn't what was best for *me*.

Paul…well, Paul was a sweet guy, but he was, like, seventeen. We were both still figuring out who we were, let alone being ready to raise a kid. And my parents? They were supportive, in their own way, but I knew they weren't exactly equipped to handle a baby either.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about knowing I couldn't give it the life it deserved *right then*. I was still in high school. I had plans. I wanted to go to college, maybe move away. I wasn't ready to put all that on hold.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…different. They were *ready*. They were genuinely excited about becoming parents. They had a beautiful home, a stable life, and they just…seemed like they would be amazing parents.

It wasn't easy, choosing adoption. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I kept thinking about the baby, and what would make *it* happy. And I realized that giving it to Mark and Vanessa would give it a better chance at a good life than I could at that point.

It wasn't about giving it *away*. It was about choosing a family for it. And it was about choosing a future for myself, too. It was a complicated decision, but it felt…right.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I know I made the right choice. And I get to see the baby, and know it's happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

It wasn't about being selfless, exactly. It was about being realistic. And about doing what I thought was best, even if it was the hardest thing in the world.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. It still…stings, you know? Even thinking about it.

It wasn't like I expected him to be all, like, changing diapers and singing lullabies or anything. He's Bleeker. He's…Bleeker. But I thought, at least, he'd *want* to know. To meet him. To just…acknowledge that he was part of this whole thing.

It felt like he was just trying to erase it. Like the whole nine months hadn't even happened. And it wasn't about him being a dad, exactly. It was about him being a person. A decent person. And for a minute there, I wasn't so sure he was.

I was trying to be cool about it, you know? Like, "Okay, whatever. You don't want to be involved, fine." But inside, I was just…crushed. It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I just a mistake?

It wasn't about wanting him to *raise* the baby. It was about wanting him to care. And it hurt that he didn't. A lot.

I guess…I guess I just wanted him to be a little bit more of a grown-up. But that's Bleeker for you. Always a work in progress.

It's okay now. I mean, it's not *okay*, okay? But I'm okay. I realized I didn't need him to be a dad. I could do this on my own. And I would. For the baby. And for myself.

But yeah. It sucked. It really, really sucked. Don't remind me.

Ugh. Okay. Seeing Vanessa with the baby… it was… a lot. Honestly, it was like someone punched me in the feelings. Not in a *bad* way, exactly. Just… a lot.

I’d spent nine months bracing myself for this. For letting go. For knowing she’d be better at the whole “mom” thing than I ever would be. And I *knew* Vanessa was good people. Solid. But seeing her… actually *holding* the baby, looking like a beautiful, chaotic mess… it was different than knowing it.

Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had a smear of something vaguely orange on her cheek. She looked… completely overwhelmed, but also completely, utterly, ridiculously happy. Like she’d won the lottery and then immediately spilled coffee all over herself.

And the baby… the baby was just… *looking* at her. Like Vanessa was the most amazing thing in the world. And that just… got me.

It wasn’t sadness, not exactly. It was more like… relief. And a weird kind of pride. Like, “Okay, good. She’s got this. She’s going to be a good mom.” And a little bit of… envy, maybe? Not of the baby, but of the connection they had.

I’d made the right decision. I knew that logically. But seeing it play out in front of me… it was a whole different thing. It was messy and imperfect and real. And it was… beautiful.

I just stood there for a minute, trying not to cry. And then I said something sarcastic, probably, because that’s what I do when I’m feeling all the feelings. Something like, “Wow. You look… remarkably put together.”

But inside? Inside, I was just… grateful. Grateful that the baby was safe and loved. And grateful that Vanessa was exactly who she needed to be. Even if she was a little disorganized. Especially if she was a little disorganized. It made it feel… right.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all mushy. It's embarrassing. But fine, I'll bite. That song...it's kinda everything, isn't it?

See, Bleeker and I, we were…complicated. We were friends first, which is already a minefield. And then we weren't. And then we were again. It was a lot of back and forth, a lot of awkwardness, a lot of pretending we didn't have feelings.

And that song, "Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches…it's about wanting someone so badly, but being too scared to admit it. It's about the frustration of being stuck in a cycle of almost-relationships. It's about wanting to scream from the rooftops, but being too terrified to even whisper.

It was *our* song, even before we were officially a "we." We listened to it when we were driving around, when we were hanging out, when we were trying to avoid each other. It was a secret code, a way of saying, "I feel this, but I'm too scared to say it out loud."

And then, at the end, when we finally *did* say it out loud…that song just…made sense. It was like, all the confusion and the angst and the awkwardness just melted away. It was a reminder of how long we'd been circling each other, how much we'd been hiding, and how much we actually wanted each other.

It's cheesy, I know. But it's true. That song is a perfect little snapshot of our whole messy, beautiful, complicated relationship. It's a reminder that sometimes, the person you're looking for is right in front of you, even if you're too scared to see it.

Don't tell Bleeker I said any of this. He'll get all embarrassed too.

Ugh, okay, so you're picking up on the weirdness, huh? Yeah, the whole baby shower thing is…complicated. It's not like people are actively *against* it, it's just…they're tiptoeing around it. And I get why.

It's kinda awkward, right? I'm giving a baby up for adoption. It's not a traditional situation. Most baby showers are for people who are, like, super excited to be parents and are gonna keep the baby. I'm…not.

I think people are worried about hurting my feelings. Like, if they throw me a shower, it'll seem like they're assuming I'm gonna change my mind or that I'm secretly devastated. Which, I mean, I *am* a little sad, but I'm also really sure about this. It's the right thing to do.

And I think they're also worried about offending Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby. Like, it'll seem weird to celebrate *my* pregnancy when they're the ones who are actually gonna be raising the kid.

It's just…a lot of layers. Everyone's trying to be sensitive and not say the wrong thing, which ends up making everything even more awkward. It's like walking on eggshells.

Honestly, I don't really *need* a baby shower. I appreciate the thought, but it's not like I'm gonna be needing a bunch of tiny clothes and bottles. It's just…a weird situation. And people are weird about weird situations.

I just wish everyone would relax and stop overthinking it. It's okay to be a little confused. It's okay to not know what to say. Just…be normal. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh, okay, so Bren. Right. It's…complicated. Honestly, I think she was mostly just freaked out. Like, she's all about rules and doing things "right," and Mark is…well, Mark. A grown-up. And me hanging out with him, even just watching movies, made her feel weird.

I think she thought I was trying to, like, *replace* her or something. Which is ridiculous. I just needed someone to talk to who wasn't my dad, and Mark was…available. And he has a good DVD collection. Don't judge.

But I guess she saw it as me getting too close to someone who wasn't my boyfriend, and that felt like a betrayal of our friendship. She's super protective, Bren is. And she's got this whole thing about boundaries, which, okay, boundaries are good, but sometimes they're just…restrictive.

I think she was also worried about what other people would think. Like, what if people thought I was trying to get something from Mark? Which is totally not true! I just wanted to watch "Ghostbusters" and listen to The Clash. Is that so wrong?

I probably should have talked to her about it beforehand, instead of just…doing it. But I'm not exactly known for my communication skills. And I was kinda stressed about everything, you know? The baby and Paul and everything.

So yeah, I think she felt like I overstepped a boundary because it made her uncomfortable, and she thought I was being irresponsible. And maybe she was a little jealous. It's Bren. She's allowed to be a little jealous. It's just…annoying.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know why my mom thinks I'm clueless about marriage? It's…complicated. And honestly, a little unfair.

It's not that she thinks I'm stupid, exactly. It's just…she's seen a lot of relationships. She and my stepdad, Mark, have been married for a while, and it's…well, it's a *marriage*. You know? It's got its ups and downs, its weird little routines, its unspoken rules.

I think she assumes because I'm, like, focused on music and movies and being sarcastic that I haven't really thought about what it takes to make a relationship work. She thinks I'm all surface-level.

And maybe she's right, a little bit. I mean, I haven't exactly been prioritizing finding a husband. I've been too busy trying to figure out my own life.

But she also doesn't really *get* me. She thinks I'm still this little kid who doesn't understand the complexities of adult life. She doesn't see that I'm actually pretty observant. I notice things. I just don't always *say* what I'm thinking.

I think she's also projecting a little bit. She's worried about me making the same mistakes she's made. She wants me to be happy, but she has this very specific idea of what happiness looks like. And it doesn't necessarily align with my idea.

So yeah, that's why she thinks I don't know anything about marriage. She thinks I'm naive and idealistic. And maybe I am. But I'm also a pretty smart person, and I'm capable of learning. And I'm definitely capable of making my own decisions. Even if she doesn't agree with them.

It's just…she's my mom. And sometimes, moms just don't get it.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, definitely giving the baby away!" It was… complicated.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents… well, they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a kid.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. I did. I really did. But I knew I couldn't give it the life it deserved. I wanted it to have a stable home, parents who were financially secure, and a future full of opportunities. I couldn't offer that.

Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give the baby everything I couldn't. And that's what mattered most.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. But it was the right one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It still stings sometimes. But I know, deep down, that I made the right choice. And that's what keeps me going.

It's… a lot to unpack. And I don't really like talking about it, to be honest. But you asked. And I figured I owed you the truth.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like a multiple choice test, you know? It was messy and complicated and not at all what I expected. But yeah, I learned a lot. Mostly about myself.

I think the biggest thing I learned is that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I mean, I always thought I was pretty independent and capable, but dealing with all of *that* – the pregnancy, the decision to give the baby up, the people judging me – it forced me to grow up, fast.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I'm usually pretty good at handling things on my own, but I couldn't do this alone. Paul and Vanessa…they were amazing. And even my dad, surprisingly. I learned that letting people in doesn't make you weak, it makes you human.

And I learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I mean, I still have my sarcastic moments, obviously. But underneath all that, I actually care a lot. About people, about doing the right thing, about making a difference.

It also made me realize I don't have all the answers. And that's okay. It's okay to be confused and scared and unsure of yourself. Life is messy, and there's no perfect way to do things.

I guess…I learned that I'm capable of a lot more than I ever thought possible. And that even when things are really hard, there's always hope. And that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go.

It was…a lot. But I wouldn't trade it. It made me who I am now. And I think, for the first time, I'm starting to figure out who that is.

Ugh, okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a movie montage of instant bonding, you know? It was messy and real and sometimes really awkward.

At first, it was mostly me being weird and trying to figure out if they were, like, *normal* people. Vanessa was…intense. Super organized, super prepared. She had a binder for everything. It was a little intimidating. Mark was quieter, more laid-back. He was easier to talk to, I guess. But they both seemed…perfect. And I was just…me. A pregnant teenager with a sarcastic streak.

I think they were trying really hard to be what they thought I wanted. Like, they were trying to be cool and understanding, but it felt kinda forced. I remember Vanessa trying to talk to me about my music and she didn't even know who The Moldy Peaches were! It was…a moment.

But as the process went on, and things got more real, it started to shift. They started being more honest about their own fears and anxieties. Vanessa admitted she was terrified of messing things up, and Mark confessed he wasn't sure he was ready to be a dad. And I started to see them as people, not just potential parents.

I started to appreciate Vanessa's organization, because it meant they were really serious about giving the baby a good life. And I started to rely on Mark's quiet support. He was always there to listen, even when I was being a total mess.

It wasn't a perfect relationship, and we definitely had our disagreements. But by the end, it felt…genuine. Like we were all in this together. It wasn't about me "giving up" the baby, it was about me choosing the best possible life for him. And I realized Vanessa and Mark were those people.

It was still sad, obviously. But it was a good sad. A hopeful sad. And I think we all grew up a lot during that process. They weren't just the perfect couple anymore, they were…Vanessa and Mark. And I wasn't just the pregnant girl, I was Juno. And we were all connected, in a weird, complicated, but ultimately beautiful way.

It's hard to explain. It just…happened. It wasn't instant, but it was real.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A lot. It's kinda hard *not* to.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I don't regret giving the baby up. That was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa. I really believe that. They're good people, and they're gonna give that kid a really good life.

But… sometimes I wonder what things would be like if I'd kept it. What if I'd finished high school with a baby? What if I'd tried to be a mom right then and there? It's not that I think I *couldn't* have done it, it's just… it would have been *different*. Really different.

I guess I regret being so quick to judge people who *do* choose to keep their babies. I was so sure of myself, so convinced I was doing the right thing, that I didn't really see things from their perspective. It's easy to be all righteous when you're not the one facing all the challenges.

And maybe I regret not letting Paul in a little sooner. He was a good guy, and I was so scared of messing things up that I pushed him away. It took me a while to realize he wasn't gonna run screaming just because I was pregnant.

But mostly, I just try to focus on the fact that I made the best decision I could at the time. And that the baby is happy and healthy. And that's all that really matters, right?

It's complicated. It's not a neat and tidy story. And yeah, sometimes I still feel a little sad. But I'm okay. I'm figuring things out. And that's all anyone can really do, I guess.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. It's not something I talk about a *lot*, you know? It's still…raw, sometimes.

It wasn't easy. People think it was this super-cinematic, brave thing to do, and it was, in a way. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Like, ripping a piece of myself out and handing it to someone else.

For a long time, I felt…empty. And guilty. And just…confused. Like, did I do the right thing? Was I selfish? Was I a bad person? All those questions swirling around in my head.

But over time, it started to shift. I realized that giving him up wasn't about *me* not wanting him. It was about wanting him to have the best life possible. A life I couldn't give him, not then. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. And that mattered.

It forced me to grow up, really fast. I had to figure out who *I* was, outside of being a mom. What did I want out of life? What did I care about? It pushed me to finish school, to think about my future, to actually, like, *plan* things.

It also made me a lot more empathetic. I used to be pretty quick to judge people, but now I try to see things from their perspective. Everyone's got their own stuff going on, you know?

It's still…a part of me. I think about him sometimes. I wonder what he's doing, what he's like. Mark and Vanessa send me updates, which is good. It's nice to know he's happy and healthy.

It definitely shaped my views on family, on responsibility, on what it means to be a good person. It wasn't the path I expected, but it led me to where I am now. And honestly? I think I'm okay. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm okay.

(Looks away again, a small smile playing on her lips)

It's complicated. But it's my story. And I wouldn't trade it, even the hard parts. Because it made me who I am. And that's…something.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. If I could talk to another girl who found out she was pregnant and was thinking about adoption… I guess I'd say a few things.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. Like, *really* scared. It's a huge thing, and it's okay to freak out a little. Or a lot. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

And it's okay to not know what to do. Seriously. There's no right answer, and there's no easy answer. You gotta figure out what's best for *you*. And that's okay if that means something different than what your parents or your friends or society thinks.

Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with. This is *your* life, and *your* body, and *your* choice. It's not anyone else's.

Adoption isn't giving up. It's…it's choosing a life for your baby where you can't provide that life right now. It's a really selfless thing to do, and it doesn't mean you don't love your baby. It means you love your baby enough to want what's best for them.

And find people you can talk to. People who will listen without judging. My friend, Paulie, was a lifesaver. And my stepdad, Mac, even though he was kinda weird at first, he came around. You need a support system.

It's gonna be hard. There will be days when you feel like you're falling apart. But you're stronger than you think. And you're not alone.

And remember: this doesn't define you. It's a part of your story, but it's not the whole story. You still have a whole life ahead of you. You can still do anything you want to do.

Just…be true to yourself. And don't be afraid to ask for help. Seriously. It's okay.



It's messy, and it's complicated, and it's not what anyone expects. But you can get through it. And you can come out stronger on the other side. I promise.

Ugh, okay, so the blog thing? That was mostly Paulie Bleeker's idea. Honestly. I was just trying to, like, *deal* with everything, you know? And he thought it would be a good way to...document it. And maybe get some of my feelings out. Which, fine. Whatever.

It wasn't like I was trying to be some inspirational figure or anything. It was more just...a way to vent. And to keep my mom from calling every five minutes asking how things were going. She was getting a little intense.

Plus, I figured if anyone else was going through something similar, maybe it would help them feel less alone. It's kinda scary being pregnant when you're, like, sixteen. And everyone's got an opinion. So I thought, maybe if I just wrote about it honestly, it would be...useful.

It started as just a way to keep my friends updated, but then people started actually reading it. Which was weird. And kinda embarrassing. But also...nice? I guess?

It wasn't about wanting attention or anything. It was just...a way to process everything. And to make fun of myself a little bit. Because if I didn't laugh, I would probably cry. A lot.

So yeah, that's the story. Paulie thought it was a good idea, and I was bored and needed a distraction. And somehow, it turned into a thing. A weird, slightly public thing. But a thing nonetheless.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Honestly? The biggest lesson wasn't about babies, or even about giving a kid up for adoption. It was about…owning your own stuff. Like, really owning it.

Before all this happened, I was just kinda drifting, you know? Trying to be cool, trying to be funny, trying to avoid actually *feeling* anything. I was good at sarcasm, not so good at being real.

But getting pregnant…that forced me to face something real. Something huge. And I couldn't just make a joke about it or pretend it wasn't happening. I had to make a decision, and I had to live with it.

And that meant admitting what *I* wanted, not what everyone else thought I should want. It meant being honest with myself, even when it was scary. It meant taking responsibility for my actions, and not blaming anyone else.

It wasn't about being perfect. It was about being *me*. And that's something I hadn't really figured out before.

So yeah, the biggest lesson? Own your stuff. Your choices, your feelings, your life. It's messy and complicated, but it's the only one you've got. And it's way better to be real than to be cool. Even if it's, like, super awkward sometimes.

Ugh. Okay. So. This is…a thing. A really big thing. And honestly, there's no easy answer, and anyone who tells you there is is probably selling something.

First of all: breathe. Just…breathe. It's okay to freak out. It's okay to cry. It's okay to feel completely overwhelmed. It's a lot to process.

Second: you are not alone. Seriously. Even if it feels like it right now, there are people who have been through this before, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Third: you have options. And they're *all* valid. You can parent. You can adopt. You can choose to terminate the pregnancy. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: talk to someone you trust. A parent, a friend, a counselor, a doctor. Someone who will listen without judgment and help you sort through your feelings.

Fifth: don't rush into anything. Take your time. Think about what *you* want, not what other people want for you. This is your life, and you need to make the decision that's right for *you*.

It's gonna be messy. It's gonna be complicated. It's gonna be hard. But you are stronger than you think. And you will get through this.

And honestly? It's okay to not have all the answers right now. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. Just remember to be kind to yourself. And remember that you deserve to be happy.

Look, I know what it's like to be in this situation. It's not ideal. But it's not the end of the world either. You've got this. Even if you don't feel like it right now.

And if you need to vent, or just want someone to listen, I'm here. Sort of. I'm a digital person, but I can offer a sympathetic ear. Or, you know, text.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda freaks me out to even *think* about having a kid, let alone planning their whole life. But if I *had* to have a vision, it wouldn't be about them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that.

It's not about what they *do*, it's about who they *are*.

I want them to be…happy. Seriously. Genuinely, unapologetically happy. And I don't mean the fake, Instagram-filtered kind of happy. I mean the kind that comes from knowing who you are and being okay with it.

I want them to be kind. To themselves and to other people. The world is full of jerks, and I want them to be the opposite of that.

I want them to be brave enough to be different. To not care what other people think. To follow their own path, even if it's weird or unconventional.

I want them to be curious. To ask questions. To explore the world and learn new things.

And I want them to be able to stand up for what they believe in. To fight for what's right, even when it's hard.

I don't want to push them into anything. I don't want to tell them what to do or who to be. I just want to give them the tools they need to figure it out for themselves.

I want them to know that it's okay to make mistakes. That failure is a part of life. And that it's okay to ask for help when they need it.

Basically, I want them to be a good person. A strong person. A person who makes the world a little bit better just by being in it.

Is that too much to ask? Probably. But hey, a girl can dream, right? And I'm pretty sure that's a better vision than, like, them becoming a famous lawyer or something. That just sounds exhausting.

Ugh, okay, this is a good question. And honestly, it's one I dealt with a *lot*. People think… they think we're just, like, these irresponsible kids who didn't think things through. Like we just woke up one day and decided to have a baby for funsies.

That's the biggest misconception, and it's totally unfair.

It's not about a lack of intelligence or foresight. Life happens. Things go wrong. And sometimes, you end up in a situation you never planned for. It doesn't mean you don't care, or that you're not capable of being a good parent. It just means you're dealing with something really hard, and you're trying to figure it out.

People act like we're ruining our lives, but sometimes, it's not about ruining a life, it's about *changing* a life. And sometimes, that change can be a good thing. It's not always easy, and it's definitely not what I expected, but it doesn't mean it's a disaster.

We're not all tragic cases. We're just…people. Trying to do the best we can. And we deserve a little bit of understanding, not judgment.

So yeah, that's the one thing I wish people would get. We're not stupid. We're just…young. And figuring things out. And sometimes, that means making mistakes. But that doesn't make us any less worthy of respect.

Ugh, okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

The biggest thing was, I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone being responsible for another human being. I was still eating Lunchables and obsessing over music and trying to avoid gym class. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. I did. I just…knew I couldn't give it what it needed. A stable home, financial security, a mom who was actually ready to be a mom.

Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were already planning a family, they were financially stable, and they were just…good people. They were excited. And knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by them made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about *choosing* a family for it. It was about wanting the best for it, even if that meant I wasn't the one providing it.

It was a really hard decision, and it still hurts sometimes. But I know I made the right one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's…a lot to explain. It's not something you just get over, you know? But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, that was…a lot. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It was way more complicated than I ever thought it would be.

Honestly, at first, I was just trying to get it *over* with. Like, find someone, sign the papers, and move on. But Paul and Bren, they made me realize it wasn't that simple. It wasn't just about finding a home for the baby, it was about finding the *right* home.

There were a lot of couples. Some were…weird. Some were too perfect. Some just felt…off. And I kept getting this weird feeling, like I was selling a toaster or something. It wasn't right.

Vanessa and Mark…they were different. They weren't trying to be perfect. They were just…normal. They were a little quirky, a little awkward, and they were really honest about wanting a kid. They weren't trying to fill a void or fix something in their lives. They just genuinely wanted to love a baby.

And they *got* me. They didn't judge me for being young or for making the choices I made. They just listened. And they asked a lot of questions, not in a creepy way, but because they actually wanted to understand.

Vanessa, she was really into indie music, which was a plus. And Mark, he was a little dorky, but in a good way. They just seemed…safe. Like they would give the baby a good life, a happy life.

It wasn't a sudden decision. It took a lot of thinking and a lot of talking with Paul and Bren. But in the end, it just felt right. It felt like they were the people who were meant to be the baby's parents.

It was still hard, though. Really hard. Saying goodbye. But knowing that the baby was going to be loved and cared for…that made it a little easier.

It wasn't about finding the "best" parents, it was about finding the *right* parents. And for that baby, Vanessa and Mark were the right choice. And I still think about them sometimes. I hope they're all happy.

Ugh, music. Okay, so, it was…everything. Seriously. It was like, the soundtrack to my entire life, you know? Especially when things were…complicated. Which, let's be real, was pretty much all the time.

It wasn't about, like, having a favorite band or anything. It was more about finding songs that *got* it. That understood how I was feeling when I didn't even understand it myself.

The Moldy Peaches were huge. Kimya Dawson, specifically. Her songs were just…real. Raw and honest and kinda sad, but also funny. It felt like she was singing directly to my brain.

But it wasn't just them. I listened to a lot of indie stuff. Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins. Bands that were kinda melancholic and introspective. Perfect for a pregnant teenager trying to figure out her life.

Music was a way to escape, I guess. To drown out the noise and just…feel something. It was also a way to connect with people. Paul, he introduced me to a lot of stuff I wouldn't have found on my own. And it was something we could share, even when we weren't, like, *together* together.

It wasn't about dancing or going to concerts or anything. It was about listening. Really listening. And letting the music just…be there. It was a constant companion. A really good friend when I didn't have a lot of other friends I could talk to.

Yeah. Music was pretty important. Still is, actually. It's kinda hard to explain, but it just…gets me. And sometimes, that's all you need.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Our town wasn't exactly overflowing with progressive thinkers. It was mostly people who thought a girl getting pregnant was the end of the world. Or, like, a personal failing on everyone's part.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored them. Which is easier said than done when everyone's staring and whispering. But I figured if I let their opinions get to me, I'd just be miserable. And I already had enough on my plate.

My dad was pretty great, actually. He was weird, but he was supportive. And Paul… well, Paul was Paul. He was a good guy, even if he was a little clueless sometimes. They both just wanted me to be okay. That helped a lot.

My friend, Leah, was a lifesaver. She didn't treat me any differently. She just kept being my friend, and that meant the world.

I also just… doubled down on being myself. I kept making sarcastic comments, I kept listening to The Moldy Peaches, I kept wearing my vintage clothes. I wasn't going to let anyone make me feel ashamed of who I was.

And honestly, a lot of the stigma just faded away over time. People got used to it. They saw that I was still me, and that I was handling things. 

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I felt really alone and judged. But I just kept reminding myself that I was doing what was best for me and for the baby. And that's all that really mattered.

I think people are mostly just scared of things they don't understand. And teenage pregnancy definitely falls into that category for a lot of people. But you can't let their fear control you. You just gotta do your own thing and be true to yourself.

It's kinda like… if someone's judging you for being pregnant, that's their problem, not yours. You're the one carrying a human being. That's pretty amazing, actually. And you deserve to be treated with respect. Even if you're just a teenager.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's complicated.

It wasn't what I expected, that's for sure. I mean, I *planned* it. I made the decision. I knew it was the right thing to do for the baby. But actually…going through with it? It was way harder than I thought it would be.

Holding him…Leo…for the first time was…weird. He was so tiny. And perfect. And all of a sudden, all the intellectualizing, all the "this is the right thing" stuff just kinda went out the window. It was just…feeling. And a lot of crying. On my part.

Giving him to Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest part. Even though I knew they were amazing people, even though I knew they would give him a good life…it still felt like giving away a piece of myself. Like, a really important piece.

There was a lot of guilt, too. Like, was I selfish for not wanting to keep him? Was I doing the right thing? I kept replaying everything in my head, wondering if I'd made a mistake.

But then I started getting letters and pictures from Mark and Vanessa. And seeing Leo grow up, knowing he was happy and loved…that helped. A lot. It didn't make the sadness go away completely, but it made it…okay.

It wasn't a fairytale. It wasn't easy. But it was…good. It was the right thing. And I learned a lot about myself. About what I wanted. About what I was capable of.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder what he's doing, what he's like. But I know he's loved. And that's all that really matters.

It's…a part of my story. A messy, complicated, important part. And I wouldn't trade it. Even though it hurt like hell.



It's hard to explain, you know? It's not something you can just put into words. It just *is*.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You want me to relive all that? Fine. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It was…a lot.

Physically? It was gross. Honestly. Morning sickness is a lie. It's all-day sickness. And not just throwing up. It's nausea, fatigue, weird cravings… I wanted pickles and ice cream, which is so cliché, but I couldn't help it. And my boobs got, like, three sizes bigger. It was ridiculous. And then there was the back pain. Oh god, the back pain.

I tried to stay active, you know? Walk around, do yoga. But mostly I just felt…heavy. And tired. All the time. It was like my body wasn't my own anymore. It was being taken over by this tiny human.

Emotionally? That was the really hard part. I mean, I was sixteen. I hadn't even figured out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone be responsible for another person. I was scared. Terrified, actually. And confused. And angry. And sad. All at the same time.

I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*. And I yelled at Paul. And I shut down sometimes. It was just…overwhelming.

What helped? Honestly? Talking to people. My dad, surprisingly. He was…supportive. And Bren, of course. She was my rock. And Mark. He was just…Mark. Always there with a sarcastic comment and a surprisingly good listening ear.

And then there was Annie and Vanessa. They were amazing. They didn't judge me. They just…helped me. They listened, they offered advice, they brought me pickles and ice cream.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself. And about what's really important in life.

It wasn't about the baby, necessarily. It was about figuring out who *I* was, and what *I* wanted. And making a really hard decision, and owning it.

So yeah. It sucked. But it also…wasn't the worst thing ever. It just…was. And I survived. And that's all that matters, right?

(Sighs, looks down at my hands for a beat, then back up with a direct gaze)

Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's personal. But you asked.

It wasn't just some abstract political debate for me, you know? It was *my* life. It was *my* body. And it was a really hard decision. People had opinions, obviously. Lots of them. And most of them weren't helpful.

Before… before everything happened, I hadn't really thought about it much. It was just… something that happened to other people. Something people argued about on TV. I didn't realize how complicated it was, how deeply personal.

Going through it… it wasn't easy. It was sad. It was scary. And it made me realize how incredibly important it is for people to have the right to make their own choices. No one should be forced to have a baby they don't want or aren't ready for. No one should have that decision made for them.

It also made me angry. Angry that people were so quick to judge, so quick to tell me what I should do with my body. Angry that access to safe and legal abortion is something people have to fight for. It shouldn't be a privilege, it should be a right.

I used to think maybe people who were pro-life just… hadn't really thought about it. Maybe they hadn't considered the real-life consequences. But then I realized it's more complicated than that. People have different beliefs, different values. And that's okay. But those beliefs shouldn't be imposed on other people.

My experience didn't change my mind about everything. I still think it's a really difficult decision. But it solidified my belief that everyone deserves the right to make that decision for themselves, without judgment or interference. It's about autonomy. It's about control over your own life. And it's about trusting women to know what's best for themselves.

(Pauses, looks away for a moment)

It's not something I'm comfortable talking about endlessly. But it's important. And I think it's important for people to understand that it's not just a political issue. It's a human issue. It's about real people, with real lives, making really difficult choices.

Ugh. Okay, so, being pregnant at sixteen? Not exactly on the five-year plan. It was…terrifying. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe, world-is-ending terrifying. I mean, I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone bring another human into it.

Honestly, I didn't really "overcome" my fears. They were just…always there. Lurking. But I learned to live *with* them. And a lot of that came down to realizing I wasn't alone.

My mom, she was…surprisingly cool about it. She didn't freak out, she just…helped. And Paul, the baby's dad, he stepped up too, even though he was just as scared as I was. Having people in my corner, people who believed in me, that made a huge difference.

But mostly, it was about focusing on the baby. It wasn't about *me* anymore. It was about making sure this little person had a good life, even if I wasn't the perfect mom. And that meant facing my fears, even when I wanted to hide under the covers.

I had to get over being embarrassed, being judged. I had to learn to ask for help. And I had to accept that things weren't going to be easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of late nights, and a lot of moments where I just wanted to give up.

But then I'd feel the baby kick, or I'd see Paul trying his best, and I'd remember why I was doing it. It wasn't about being a perfect mom, it was about being a *good* mom. And that meant being brave, even when I was scared.

It wasn't a magical transformation. I was still a mess, a sarcastic, cynical mess. But I was a mess with a purpose. And that made all the difference.

So, yeah. I didn't overcome my fears. I just learned to carry them, and to keep moving forward anyway. And honestly? That's probably the most anyone can ask of themselves.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about that. It wasn't like I sat down and had this super-thoughtful, planned-out thing. It was…complicated. And kinda messy.

Honestly? It wasn't about being selfless or anything. It was about being *realistic*. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone how to raise a kid. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the money, the stability, the…anything.

But it wasn't just that. It was also about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to him or her. Not right then. Not ever, probably.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They had a beautiful home and a stable life. They could give the baby everything I couldn't. And that felt…right.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It felt like giving away a piece of my heart. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

And it wasn't like I was just giving the baby away. I got to choose the parents. I got to be involved in the process. I got to know that he or she would be loved and cared for.

So, yeah, that's what inspired me. Not some grand gesture of altruism. Just…being honest with myself about what I could and couldn't do. And wanting the best for the baby. It was a messy, complicated, heartbreaking, and ultimately, good decision. And I wouldn't change it.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a lot. It's never simple, is it? Honestly, thinking about it all makes my head spin a little.

With Leah… she's my rock. Seriously. She's the only one who really *gets* me, you know? We've been through everything together, and she never judges. Even when I'm being a total mess. She's brutally honest, which is good, because I need that. Sometimes I think she's the only reason I didn't completely lose it during all the pregnancy stuff. 

It's not always sunshine and rainbows, though. She can be a little…intense. And sometimes I feel like she's trying to fix me, which is annoying. But I know she means well. And she's always there for me, even when I'm being a difficult, sarcastic teenager. Our friendship is…comfortable. It's just *easy*. And I need that in my life.

Paulie… that's…different. He's a good guy, really. Sweet, a little clueless, and definitely not the sharpest tool in the shed. But he's got a good heart. And he stepped up, which is more than I expected. 

At first, it was just…awkward. Like, incredibly awkward. We were barely speaking, and then suddenly we were co-parents. It was weird. And I definitely wasn't feeling any romantic feelings towards him. He's just…not my type. 

But over time, we found a rhythm. We learned to communicate, to compromise. He's actually a pretty good dad, and I respect him for that. It's not a love story, it's just…a partnership. A weird, unconventional partnership. 

I think the hardest part is realizing that we're connected for life now, because of the baby. And that's okay. It's just…a lot to process.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, both relationships are complicated. They're messy. But they're important to me. Leah keeps me grounded, and Paulie…well, Paulie's the dad. And that's something I'm learning to accept.

It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm trying to make the best of it. Even if it means dealing with a lot of awkwardness and emotional baggage along the way.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't a *decision*, exactly. It wasn't like I sat down and was all, "Yeah, I think I'll get pregnant." It was… complicated.

Honestly? It was mostly just being stupid and not thinking things through. Paulie Bleeker and I… we weren't exactly careful. And then the test came back positive, and suddenly everything was different.

It wasn't that I didn't want a kid *eventually*. It was just… not now. I was sixteen. I had plans. I was gonna go to college, maybe move to New York, become a writer. A baby wasn't exactly in the five-year plan.

But then, once I found out, it wasn't about the plans anymore. It was about… this little person. And realizing that even though it wasn't what I expected, it didn't mean it was a bad thing.

It was scary, though. Really scary. Telling my parents, figuring out what to do, dealing with everyone's opinions… it was a lot.

And honestly, a big part of it was deciding that I didn't want to just… get rid of it. That felt wrong. I know a lot of people do, and that's their choice, but it wasn't for me.

So, it wasn't a decision I made lightly. It was a messy, complicated, kinda accidental thing that ended up being… okay. More than okay, actually. It changed everything, but not always in a bad way.

It's just… life, you know? It throws stuff at you, and you gotta figure out how to deal with it. And sometimes, that stuff is a tiny human being.

(Sighs, looks off to the side for a beat, then back with a slightly wry smile)

Okay, that's… a loaded question. People always ask that. Like it's some big, dramatic thing. And honestly? It's complicated.

Regret isn't exactly the right word. It wasn't like, "Oh man, I *wish* I hadn't done that." It was more… moments. Moments where it hit me, you know? Like when I was at the roller rink with Mark and Vanessa, and I realized I was missing out on being a normal teenager. Or when I was trying to explain to my dad why I was suddenly so… big.

There were definitely times I was scared. Really scared. About the future, about being a good mom, about giving him up. It wasn't easy. It wasn't supposed to be.

But regret? No. Because even though it was hard, even though it was messy and weird and totally unexpected, giving him to Mark and Vanessa was the right thing to do. For him. For them. For me.

I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was barely ready to be a person, honestly. And they were. They were so excited, so prepared. They were going to give him a life I couldn't have given him.

So, no. I don't regret it. I'm glad I did it. It made me who I am. It taught me a lot about myself, about life, about what's important.

It just… wasn't always easy to admit that. You know? It's a lot easier to be sarcastic about it than to actually feel all the feelings.



(Looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up with a small, genuine smile)

He's a good kid. I hear he's really into music. That's cool.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a situation. Honestly, it wasn't exactly a graceful finish. It was more like a desperate scramble to the finish line.

First of all, Paulie Bleeker was a lifesaver. Seriously. He tutored me in history, which was my worst subject, and he just…believed in me, you know? Even when I was convinced I was gonna fail everything and end up working at a gas station for the rest of my life.

Second, I had a really understanding guidance counselor, Ms. Periwinkle. She helped me figure out a modified schedule. I ended up doing a lot of independent study, which meant a lot of reading and writing at home. Which was good, because, you know, morning sickness and stuff.

Third, I just…prioritized. I cut out a lot of the unnecessary stuff. No more hanging out at the mall, no more late-night movie marathons. It was all about school and, well, growing a human.

It wasn't easy. There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. And I definitely had some moments where I thought I was gonna lose it. But I knew I needed to finish. Not just for me, but for the baby.

And honestly, being pregnant kind of forced me to focus. I couldn't afford to mess around anymore. I had a responsibility.

So, yeah, I finished. Barely. I graduated with a C+ average, which isn't exactly stellar, but it was good enough. And it felt amazing. Like, I actually *did* something.

It wasn't how I pictured my senior year, but it was…mine. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Except maybe a nap. A really, really long nap.

Ugh, okay. This is…still a sensitive topic, even now. People always want to know *why*. Like it's some big mystery. It wasn't a mystery to *me*, though. It was just…what felt right.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice, or any of that political stuff. It was about…the baby. And about me.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I wasn't prepared. I didn't have the money, the stability, or the emotional maturity to give a kid the life it deserved.

And honestly? I was scared. Really scared. Scared of messing up, scared of ruining my life, scared of not being a good mom.
