Abortion…it felt…wrong. Not morally wrong, necessarily. Just…wrong for *me*. I couldn't shake the feeling that it wasn't the right thing to do. It felt too…final.

Adoption felt like…giving the baby a chance. A chance at a good life with parents who were ready and willing to love and care for it. It felt like a selfless act, even though it was also incredibly selfish for me to not have to deal with raising a kid right then. It was complicated.

Mark was really supportive, actually. He didn't push me either way. He just wanted me to be okay. And Vanessa and Mark, the couple who adopted the baby…they were amazing. They were so excited and so prepared. Knowing that my baby was going to a loving home made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was the right one. For me. For the baby. And I still think about it sometimes. But I don't regret it.



It's my story, and it's not something I talk about a lot. But you asked, so I told you. It's not a simple answer, and it's not something anyone else can decide for you. It just…was.

Okay, look. That's a really good question. And honestly, it's kinda ridiculous that it even *needs* to be asked. Like, seriously?

I've, uh, had some experience with non-traditional family stuff, obviously. And what I learned is that it's not about the *structure* of the family, it's about the *love* and support that's inside it.

A kid needs to feel safe, wanted, and like they have people who are gonna be there for them, no matter what. It doesn't matter if those people are a mom and a dad, two moms, two dads, a single parent, or a whole village of weirdos. As long as they're providing that love and support, the kid's gonna be okay. More than okay, actually. They can thrive.

I mean, look at me. My mom is…my mom. And she's amazing. And she did a pretty good job raising me, even if she was a little bit…eccentric. And I turned out alright, didn't I? Mostly.

So yeah, I absolutely believe a child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. It's not about fitting into some perfect little box. It's about finding a family that loves and supports you for who you are. And that's what really matters.

Honestly, anyone who thinks otherwise is just stuck in the past. And that's kinda sad.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me do this. Self-reflection is…not my strong suit. But fine. If I *have* to pick one thing… it's probably that I build walls. Like, really good, impenetrable walls.

I'm good at being sarcastic and deflecting and making jokes, right? It's a defense mechanism. It keeps people at arm's length. And it's useful, sometimes. It protects me from getting hurt.

But it also means I don't always let people *in*. I don't always let myself be vulnerable. I push people away before they can push me away, you know? It's a preemptive strike.

It made things complicated with Paulie Bleeker, obviously. I was so busy trying to be cool and detached that I almost missed out on something really good. And it's something I'm still working on, honestly. Letting people see the real me, the messy, insecure me.

It's just…easier to be funny than to be honest. But I'm learning that honesty is way more important. Even if it's terrifying.

So yeah. Building walls. That's my biggest flaw. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, Mark. That's…complicated. It's not like he was a *bad* guy, you know? Just…not the guy for me. And honestly, it kinda messed with my head for a while.

Before Mark, I had this whole thing figured out. Or, I thought I did. I was all cynical and independent and convinced I didn't *need* anyone. Like, relationships were just…drama. And I was avoiding drama at all costs.

But then Mark came along, and he was…sweet. And funny. And he actually *listened* to me. And for a minute, I thought, "Okay, maybe this isn't so bad."

But then I realized he wanted a different life than I did. He wanted the white picket fence and the 2.5 kids and the whole suburban thing. And I…didn't. I wasn't ready for that. And I realized that wanting different things isn't a character flaw. It just *is*.

So, it changed my perspective in a couple of ways. First, it made me realize that it's okay to want things. It's okay to want a partner, but it's also okay to want to be independent. It's not an either/or situation.

And second, it made me realize that a good relationship isn't about changing someone. It's about finding someone who accepts you for who you are, flaws and all. And who wants the same things as you.

It was a messy, awkward, kinda heartbreaking experience. But I think I needed it. It helped me figure out what I really wanted, and what I wasn't willing to compromise on.

It didn't make me all sunshine and rainbows about relationships, though. I'm still a little cynical. But now, I'm a little more open to the possibility of finding someone who gets me. Someone who doesn't want to change me. Someone who just…gets it.

It was a good lesson, I guess. Even if it was a really uncomfortable one.

Ugh, okay. That's…a big question. It's still kinda raw, even now. But if someone was in a position like I was…here's what I'd say.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Like, really scared. It's a huge thing, and it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to freak out a little. Or a lot. Just…don't let the fear paralyze you.

Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it. There are people who care about you, and there are people who have been through similar things. Reach out to them. Talk to them. Don't bottle it up. My best friend, Leah, was a lifesaver. And Paul…well, Paul was surprisingly okay with everything.

Third: **it's okay to choose what's right for *you*.** Even if it's not what everyone else thinks you should do. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into something you're not comfortable with. It's your call, and you have to live with it.

Fourth: **don't be afraid to ask for help.** Whether it's from your family, your friends, a counselor, or a social worker. There are resources available, and you don't have to go through this alone.

Fifth: **it's okay to feel all the feelings.** Sadness, anger, confusion, relief…it's all valid. Don't try to suppress your emotions. Let yourself feel them, and process them.

And finally: **you are stronger than you think.** You're going to get through this. It's going to be hard, but you're going to get through it. And you're going to come out on the other side a stronger, more resilient person.

It's not gonna be a fairytale. It's gonna be messy and complicated and sometimes really, really hard. But you can do it. And you deserve to be happy.

Just…breathe. And remember that you're not alone. And that it's okay to ask for help. Seriously. Don't be a hero. It's overrated.

Ugh, okay, talking about my dad. It's…complicated. It wasn't always sunshine and rainbows, you know? At first, he was just…Dad. The guy who made pancakes and told bad jokes. And then I got pregnant, and suddenly he was like, super serious and protective. Which was nice, I guess, but also kinda suffocating. He was all, "We need a plan!" and "What are your options?" and I was just like, "Whoa, slow down, dude."

For a while, it felt like he was disappointed in me. Not that he *said* it, but I could just *feel* it. Like I'd messed up his perfect little life plan. And I was already feeling pretty messed up myself, so that didn't help.

But then, things started to shift. He started actually *listening* to me, instead of just telling me what to do. He started helping me with stuff, like, really helping, not just offering to pay for things. He even came with me to some of the doctor's appointments, which was…surprisingly nice.

He started to see that I wasn't just some irresponsible kid. I was actually thinking things through, and I was determined to do the right thing, even if it wasn't the easiest thing.

And I started to see him differently too. I realized he wasn't trying to control me, he was just scared. He was scared for me, and he was scared for the baby. He just didn't know how to show it in a way that didn't feel…overbearing.

Now? We're good. We're really good. We still bicker sometimes, and he still tells terrible jokes, but there's a lot more understanding between us. He's actually a pretty cool guy, when you get to know him. He's still my dad, but he's also…a friend, I guess.

It took a while, and it took a lot of awkward conversations and uncomfortable silences, but we got there. And I'm really grateful for that. He's a good dad. Even if he doesn't always know it.

It's weird, you know? Life throws you curveballs, and sometimes those curveballs actually bring you closer to the people you love.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the writing thing. It's not like I *tried* to develop them, you know? It just…happened. I guess.

Honestly, I think a lot of it came from being bored. Like, seriously bored. Small town, not a lot to do. So I started writing in my notebook, mostly just observations. Like, what people were wearing at the grocery store, or the weird things my dad would say. Just stuff.

And I read a lot. Not like, assigned reading for school. I read stuff I *wanted* to read. Kurt Vonnegut, mostly. And Sylvia Plath. Dark stuff. But good. It kinda showed me you could say things in a different way. You didn't have to write like everyone else.

Mr. Shepherd, my English teacher, he helped too. He didn't try to change my voice or anything. He just kinda…encouraged me to keep writing. He said I had a knack for dialogue. Which, I guess, is good. I mean, I'm pretty good at listening to people. And then just, like, writing down what they say. But making it sound…real.

I think a lot of it is just paying attention. To the world around you, and to the people in it. And then trying to find the right words to describe it. It's not about being fancy or using big words. It's about being honest. And a little bit funny, if you can pull it off.

So, yeah. Boredom, good books, and a teacher who didn't suck. That's pretty much it. It's not rocket science. It's just…writing. And a lot of thinking. And probably a little bit of teenage angst. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? There was a lot of side-eye, a lot of whispers, and a lot of people acting like I'd personally offended them. It sucked.

Honestly, the first thing I did was just…brace myself. I knew it was coming. Small towns are good at that. Judging. It's like a hobby.

But I also had a really good support system. My dad, surprisingly, was pretty cool about it. He was just…quietly supportive. And Paul, obviously. He didn't run away screaming, which was a plus. And my best friend, Leah, she was amazing. She didn't treat me like I was broken or anything. She just…was there.

I think what helped me the most was just…owning it. I wasn't gonna apologize for being pregnant. It happened. It was my life. And I was gonna deal with it on my own terms. I didn't need anyone's permission or approval.

I also learned to tune out the noise. People are gonna talk, no matter what you do. So I just focused on what was important: taking care of myself and the baby.

And honestly, a little bit of sarcasm helped. If someone was being particularly judgmental, I'd just give them a withering look and say something like, "Oh, I'm sorry, did my reproductive choices inconvenience you?" It usually shut them up.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I felt really alone and scared. But I just kept reminding myself that I was strong, and I could handle it. And I did.

It's not a glamorous story, but it's my story. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. It made me who I am. And that's gotta count for something, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. One I don't usually let myself dwell on, honestly. But yeah. Sometimes.

Look, being brutally honest is kinda my default setting. It's easier than pretending to feel something I don't, or saying what people want to hear. It's just…me. And it usually works out, you know? People appreciate the realness.

But there have been times…times when my mouth just ran away with me, and I said something I shouldn't have. Something that hurt someone's feelings. Or made a situation way more awkward than it needed to be.

Like, with Mark. I was *so* determined to be honest about not wanting a traditional relationship, and I think I kinda just…blasted him with it. It wasn't exactly gentle. And I think that hurt him, even if he didn't show it.

And even with my dad…sometimes I wish I'd been a little more tactful. A little less…Juno.

So, do I regret it? Not the *principle* of being honest. I still think it's important. But I regret the times when I let my honesty turn into just being…mean. Or insensitive.

I'm learning. Slowly. That there's a difference between being honest and being a jerk. And that sometimes, a little bit of kindness goes a long way.

It's a work in progress, okay? I'm still figuring things out. And sometimes, my mouth just gets me into trouble. But hey, at least I'm authentic. Right?

*shrugs*

Don't tell anyone I said all this. It's embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big one. Seriously. It's like, everyone has an opinion on what you should be doing with your life, especially when you're a teenager. And when you're pregnant? Forget about it. It's a total circus.

Honestly, I don't have a perfect answer. It's still something I'm figuring out. But here's what I've learned so far:

First of all, you gotta realize that most people are just…projecting. They're worried about what *they* think is right, or what *they* would do in your situation. It's not really about you. It's about them. Which doesn't make it easier, but it helps to remember.

Second, you gotta find your people. The ones who get you, who don't judge, who just…support you. For me, that was Paul and my dad. And even Leah, eventually. Those are the people you listen to. Everyone else? Background noise.

Third, you gotta be okay with being different. I'm not like most people. I like old movies and vinyl records and I say what's on my mind. And that's okay. You don't have to fit into anyone else's box.

And finally, you gotta trust your gut. Seriously. If something feels wrong, it probably is. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

It's not easy. There are gonna be times when you feel overwhelmed and confused and like everyone is against you. But you gotta remember who you are and what you want. And you gotta hold onto that, even when it's hard.

Because at the end of the day, you're the one who has to live with your choices. Not your parents, not your friends, not some random person at the grocery store. You.

So, just…be you. Even if it's weird. Especially if it's weird. Because weird is good. Weird is interesting. And weird is definitely better than being someone you're not.

And if anyone judges you for it? Well, that's their problem, not yours. Just shrug it off and keep moving. You got this.

Ugh, values. That sounds…intense. Like a school assignment. But okay, if I have to think about it…

I guess the biggest thing for me is **honesty**. Not just with other people, but with myself. It's easy to pretend you know what you're doing, even when you totally don't. But I try not to do that. I try to be real, even if it's awkward.

Then there's **independence**. I like being able to make my own decisions, even if they're bad ones. I don't want anyone telling me what to do or how to live my life. I gotta figure that out for myself.

And…okay, this is kinda cheesy, but **kindness**. I think it's important to be nice to people, even when they're being jerks. It doesn't mean you have to let them walk all over you, but just…showing a little bit of compassion. It makes the world a little less awful.

Also, **authenticity**. Being yourself, even if it's weird or unpopular. I don't want to be someone I'm not just to fit in.

And finally, **loyalty**. To the people who matter to me. My friends, my family…they're the ones who keep me grounded.

I don't know. Those are just…the things that feel important to me right now. They might change tomorrow. I'm still figuring things out, you know? It's all kinda messy. But those are the things I'm trying to live by.

Don't judge me. It's a work in progress.

Ugh. Okay, so, the whole thing was kinda a challenge, right? Like, finding out I was pregnant in the first place was…a lot. But I think the biggest challenge wasn't the morning sickness (though that was pretty brutal), or even telling my parents. It was…people treating me differently.

Like, suddenly everyone had an opinion. My mom was all overprotective, Paul was trying to be supportive but kinda clueless, and even people at school were staring. It was like I wasn't Juno anymore, I was just…a pregnant girl. And everyone was projecting their own stuff onto me.

People assuming I was irresponsible, or that my life was over, or that I was gonna be a terrible mom. It was just…exhausting. I mean, I knew it wasn't gonna be easy, but I didn't need everyone else reminding me of that constantly.

I just wanted to be treated like a normal person. I wanted people to see *me*, not just the baby. And it was hard to navigate that, you know? To figure out who was genuinely trying to help and who was just judging.

It made me really question myself, too. Like, was I doing the right thing? Was I strong enough to handle this? It was a lot of internal stuff, but it was definitely the hardest part. It wasn't the physical stuff, it was the emotional stuff.

So yeah, people treating me differently. That was the biggest challenge. It made me realize how much judgment there is in the world, and how important it is to just be yourself, even when everyone else is trying to tell you who you should be.

(Sighs, fiddles with a charm bracelet)

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not like I walked around before thinking life was all sunshine and rainbows, you know? I was pretty cynical, even for sixteen. But having a kid…it just…shifts everything.

Before, it was all about *me*. My music, my friends, figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. It was selfish, I guess. Not in a bad way, just…normal for a teenager. And then suddenly, there's this tiny human who completely depends on you for *everything*. It's terrifying and amazing all at the same time.

It makes you realize how small you are, and how big the world is. And how much responsibility you have. It's not just about your own happiness anymore. It's about creating a good life for this little person.

I used to roll my eyes at people who talked about "the meaning of life." Now? I kinda get it. It's not some grand philosophical thing. It's about love, and connection, and making sure this kid grows up knowing they're worthy and loved.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still me. I still like my music and my sarcastic comments. But everything feels…more important now. More real.

It's also made me appreciate my own parents more. I used to think they were just…there. Now I see all the sacrifices they made, and all the love they poured into raising me.

It's hard. It's really, really hard. But it's also the best thing that's ever happened to me. It's like…it gave me a purpose. And it made me realize that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still beauty in the world.

(Looks down, smiles softly)

Yeah. It changed everything. In a good way. Mostly. It's still messy. But good.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that guy. He's a real jerk. He shows up at the *worst* times, usually when you're already kinda freaking out about something else.

Honestly? I don't have some super profound answer. It doesn't just magically disappear. But I've learned a few things.

First, I try to recognize it *as* self-doubt. Like, "Oh, hey, it's that voice again, telling me I'm gonna mess everything up." Just naming it kinda takes some of its power away.

Then, I usually try to talk myself down. Not like, "Everything's fine!" because that's a lie. More like, "Okay, this is scary, but you've handled scary stuff before. You're a pretty resourceful person, even if you don't always feel like it."

And I talk to people. Bleah, I know, talking about feelings. But seriously, venting to Paul or even just having someone tell me I'm not completely insane helps. It's good to have people who will call you on your BS, too.

Sometimes, I just distract myself. Put on some music, watch a movie, go for a walk. Just get my brain to focus on something else for a while.

And honestly? Sometimes I just let myself feel it. Like, okay, I'm doubting myself. It sucks. But it's okay to not be perfect. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to not have all the answers.

It's a process, you know? It doesn't just go away. But you get better at dealing with it. You learn to recognize the voice, and you learn to tell it to shut up. Or at least, to turn down the volume.

It's kinda like learning to ride a bike. You fall a lot at first, but eventually, you get the hang of it. And even when you fall, you get back up and try again.

So yeah. That's how I deal with it. Mostly by being a sarcastic, slightly cynical teenager who's trying to figure things out. It's not pretty, but it works for me.

Ugh, okay, that's… a good question. It's not something I think about a lot, honestly. I'm pretty good at being self-sufficient, you know? Like, I can handle things. I *have* to handle things.

But… it's actually really important. I just don't like to admit it.

Before all this… the baby thing… I kinda kept people at arm's length. I had Paul, and he was cool, but I didn't really *need* a whole bunch of friends. I was okay on my own.

But then… everything happened. And suddenly, I needed people. I needed my mom, even though she's… my mom. I needed Paul to not be a total flake. And I needed Leah to just… be there.

It's like, I thought I could do everything myself, but I couldn't. I needed someone to talk to, someone to help me figure things out, someone to just… listen.

And it wasn't just about the baby stuff, either. It was about… feeling less alone. Feeling like someone understood what I was going through.

So yeah, community and social support are important. Maybe even *really* important. I just… I don't like to rely on people. It makes me feel vulnerable. But it's also… nice.

It's like, you can build a fort all by yourself, but it's way more fun when you have someone to help you build it. And it's way stronger, too.

So, yeah. Important. Definitely important. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, that's a heavy question. Seriously. It's not like, "Oh, learn to knit!" or "Always carry lip balm!" It's...bigger than that.

I think the most important lesson I learned wasn't about babies, or even about giving a baby up for adoption. It was about…owning your own life. Like, really owning it.

Before all this happened, I was just kinda drifting, you know? Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was sarcastic and cynical and used humor as a shield. And I was kinda scared to actually *feel* things.

But going through the pregnancy, and making the decision to give the baby up, forced me to grow up. It forced me to look at myself and figure out what I really wanted, not what other people expected of me.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it taught me that it's okay to be scared, and it's okay to make difficult choices. And it's okay to not have all the answers.

And it taught me that you're the only one who can decide what's right for you. No one else can do that.

So, yeah. Owning your own life. That's the big lesson. And it's something I'm still working on, honestly. But I'm getting there.

It's kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. And sometimes, cheesy is okay.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Honestly? I don't know. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. That feels…suffocating.

But yeah, I *like* writing. I mean, I like being able to, like, get my thoughts out of my head and onto paper. It's better than just stewing in my own angst, you know? And Mr. Shepherd, my English teacher, he actually thinks I'm good at it. Which is…weird. He's kinda intense.

I don't know if I want to be a *professional* writer, though. That sounds…stressful. Like, having to come up with ideas on demand and meet deadlines and stuff. I'm more of a write-when-I-feel-like-it kind of person.

I think I might just keep it as a hobby. A way to, like, process things. Maybe I'll write stories or poems or something. Or maybe I'll just keep writing sarcastic essays in my head.

It's not like I'm going to be a doctor or a lawyer or anything. So, yeah, maybe. Maybe I'll write. But don't hold me to it. I change my mind like, every five minutes.

Right now, I'm just trying to figure out what I'm doing with my life, you know? And that's hard enough without adding a career path into the mix. So, we'll see. Maybe. Probably not. Who knows?

Ugh, okay, the baby name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly stressful process, actually. It wasn't like I had a list of names ready to go or anything. It had to be…right, you know? Not too weird, not too common. And definitely not something I'd regret yelling across a playground.

So, it started with Paul and I just throwing out random names. Like, "Bartholomew?" Seriously, Paul suggested Bartholomew. I vetoed that immediately. Then there was "Atticus," which was taken, obviously. Everyone names their kid Atticus now.

Then, Mark – you know, the music guy – he suggested "Phoenix." Which was…a little much. I mean, I like The Phoenix, but a baby named Phoenix? Too dramatic.

Honestly, it was my dad who kind of steered us in the right direction. He was just flipping through a magazine and saw an article about a little girl named Hazel. And he said, "Hazel. That's a nice name."

And it just…stuck. It felt right. It's classic, but not *too* classic. It's a little bit quirky, but not in a weird way. And it just sounded good with the last name.

So, yeah. Hazel. It wasn't some grand, elaborate story. It was just…a name that felt right. Sometimes the simplest things are the best, I guess.

It's kinda weird to think about, though. Like, that's her name. That's the name I'll be calling her for the rest of my life. It's a big responsibility, naming a person. But I think we made a good choice. I hope so, anyway.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, confusing, and sometimes kinda terrifying rollercoaster. And I didn't have a manual for it, which didn't help.

Honestly? I mostly just tried to pretend I was fine. Which, looking back, was a terrible strategy. I was all sarcastic and detached, trying to act like it wasn't a big deal. Like, "Yeah, I'm giving the baby up. No biggie." But inside, I was a mess.

There was a lot of crying. A lot of eating junk food. A lot of listening to The Moldy Peaches and feeling really, really sad.

Paul and Vanessa were…amazing. They were so supportive and understanding. They didn't try to tell me how to feel, they just…listened. And they let me be angry and confused and scared.

But it was still hard. It was hard knowing that I was making the right decision, but it didn't make it *feel* right. It was hard imagining the baby with another family. It was hard dealing with people's opinions and judgments.

What really helped, I think, was talking to Mark. He was the only one who really understood what I was going through. He didn't try to fix things, he just…got it.

And eventually, I realized that giving the baby up wasn't about giving *up* on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. And that meant letting someone else raise it.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? But I've come to terms with it. And I know that I made the right choice.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it also taught me a lot about myself and about what really matters in life.

So, how did I cope? Badly, at first. Then, with a lot of help from the people I love. And eventually, by accepting that it was okay to feel all the feelings, even the really messy ones.

It's still…a work in progress, honestly. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, music. It's kinda important, right? Like, a soundtrack to life and all that. So, lemme lay it out for you. I'm not into anything super mainstream. Like, no Britney Spears, okay? No offense to Britney.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They're just...real. And kinda weird. And they make me feel things.

But I also listen to a lot of indie stuff. Belle and Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins. You know, stuff that's a little bit melancholy but also kinda hopeful.

I like singer-songwriters too. Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan. People who actually *say* something with their music.

And I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, early 60s stuff. The Beach Boys, The Supremes. It's just...happy.

Basically, I like music that's honest and a little bit quirky. I don't really care if it's popular or not. As long as it makes me feel something, I'm good.

Oh, and I'm not a fan of country. Just putting that out there. No offense to anyone who likes country. It's just...not my thing.

So yeah. That's my musical taste in a nutshell. It's kinda all over the place, but that's me. A little bit all over the place.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. It's…complicated. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just…a lot.

Mark and Vanessa were…perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. Their house was all Pottery Barn and organic snacks and everything was color-coordinated. It smelled like lavender and responsibility. Which, don't get me wrong, is nice. But it wasn't *me*.

My house is…messy. And loud. And we eat a lot of tater tots. It's real. Their house felt…staged. Like a magazine spread.

And they were so…prepared. They had the nursery all decorated, and they'd read all the baby books, and they had a whole schedule planned out. Which is good, I guess. But it felt like they were preparing for a doll, not a real, messy, unpredictable baby.

Vanessa was really nice, don't get me wrong. She was just…intense. She kept asking me about my plans for the future and if I was sure about this. It felt like an interview. And Mark was…quiet. He seemed nice, but he mostly just let Vanessa do the talking.

It wasn't that I didn't think they'd be good parents. They clearly would be. They just weren't…*us*. They weren't my parents. And it was weird to think about my baby growing up in that house, with that lifestyle.

It made me realize that finding the right parents wasn't just about finding people who were financially stable and responsible. It was about finding people who would love my baby for who they were, flaws and all. And who would let them be a little bit messy and imperfect.

So, yeah. It was a nice house. But it wasn't *home*. Not for my baby. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, so the whole garage band thing… that was mostly Paulie’s idea, honestly. He’s just…enthusiastic. About everything. But I definitely helped steer it in a less…embarrassing direction.

It started because he was all bummed out about not being able to go to the prom with me, right? And he was trying to, like, win me back with grand gestures. Which is sweet, I guess, but also kinda intense.

So he’s like, “Let’s start a band! It’ll be romantic!” And I was all, “Romantic? Playing music in a garage? That’s your idea of romance?” But then I thought, well, it’s better than him writing me a poem or something.

The original idea was to do, like, a super-serious indie rock thing. All angsty lyrics and dramatic guitar solos. Which, no offense to Paulie, but he’s not exactly Kurt Cobain.

So I was like, “Okay, we need to tone it down. Let’s do something…ironic. Something that’s intentionally bad.” And that’s when we started doing covers of really cheesy songs. Like, 80s power ballads and stuff.

It was actually kinda fun. And it was a good way to hang out with Sean and Lisha, too. They’re both pretty cool.

So yeah, it wasn’t really *my* idea, but I definitely helped shape it into something that wasn’t completely awful. It was a distraction, I guess. From everything else that was going on. And it was a good way to spend time with people I cared about.

Plus, it gave me something to make fun of Paulie about. Which is always a bonus.

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. And a really important one. If you're going through that, first of all, just breathe. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel *everything*.

Look, I know what it's like. It's not how you planned things, right? It throws everything into chaos. And everyone has an opinion, which is the worst.

Here's what I learned, and what I wish someone had just told me straight up:

*   **You are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like it, but you're not. There are other girls going through this, and there are people who want to help.
*   **It's okay to not know what you want to do.** You don't have to have all the answers right now. Take your time. Think about what's best for *you*.
*   **Talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone you feel safe with. Don't try to go through this alone.
*   **Don't let anyone pressure you.** This is *your* decision. Don't let anyone tell you what you should do.
*   **Consider all your options.** There are a lot of choices, and they're all valid. Adoption, parenting, whatever feels right for you.
*   **It doesn't have to ruin your life.** It's going to be hard, no doubt about it. But you can still finish school, pursue your dreams, and have a good life.
*   **You are stronger than you think.** This is a really tough situation, but you can get through it.

And honestly? It's okay to be angry. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to be scared. Just don't let those feelings consume you.

There are resources out there. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, and local support groups can all provide help and guidance.

You're not a bad person. You're not a failure. You're just a girl facing a really difficult situation. And you deserve support, compassion, and the chance to make the best decision for yourself.

Don't give up on yourself. You've got this. Even when it feels like you don't.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about my favorite shirt? It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about fashion or anything. But fine.

It's this old, faded band tee. It's for The Moldy Peaches, obviously. It's kinda stretched out and has a couple of holes, but I don't care. It's super soft because I've washed it like a million times. 

It's dark blue, and the print is all cracked and worn. It's not, like, a *stylish* shirt. It's just…comfortable. And it reminds me of stuff. Good stuff. And it's not trying too hard, you know? 

I usually wear it with jeans and Converse. Pretty standard. I'm not really into anything fancy. It's just…me.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be all sarcastic and aloof, not talking about my favorite t-shirt. Jeez.

Ugh, aspirations. That's a heavy word. It makes me feel like I'm supposed to have some grand plan for my life, which, honestly, I don't. Not yet, anyway.

But yeah, okay, if you're asking... I guess I do have some things I'm thinking about. It's not like, "I want to be a doctor and save the world" or anything. It's more... smaller.

I'm kinda good at writing, you know? Like, writing songs and stuff. I don't know if I'd ever be a professional songwriter or anything, but I'd like to keep doing it. Maybe even get better at it.

And I definitely want to go to college. Not because my parents want me to, or because I think I *have* to, but because I want to learn more stuff. I don't know what I want to study yet, maybe film or something. Or maybe just a bunch of random classes.

I also want to travel. See places that aren't just this town. I want to see the ocean, and mountains, and just... different things.

But mostly, I just want to be okay. I want to figure out who I am, and what I want out of life, without messing everything up too badly. And I want to be happy. Is that too much to ask?

It's not a very exciting plan, I guess. But it's mine. And right now, that's enough.

I'm still figuring things out, okay? I'm sixteen. I'm allowed to not have all the answers. It's kinda the point.

Ugh. Okay, the pre-adoption counseling. Right. It was…a lot. Honestly? It felt kinda weird at first. Like, people were asking me all these questions about my feelings, and my future, and what I wanted for the baby. And I was just trying to get through it, you know? It wasn't like I was *excited* about the counseling, it was just something I had to do.

It wasn't that the counselors were bad or anything. They were nice enough. But it felt…clinical. Like I was a case study or something. And they kept asking me if I was *sure* I wanted to do this. Which, like, duh. I was pretty sure. But it made me feel like they didn't trust me to make the right decision.

But then, after a few sessions, it started to…help. They made me think about things I hadn't really thought about before. Like, what kind of family I wanted for the baby. And what I wanted the baby to know about me. And it helped me feel a little less scared, I guess.

It was also good to talk to other people who were in the same situation. It made me feel less alone.

So, yeah. It was awkward and uncomfortable at times, but ultimately, I think it was a good thing. It helped me prepare for what was coming, and it helped me feel more confident in my decision. It wasn't my favorite part of the whole process, but I'm glad I did it.

It just…felt like a lot of people were trying to tell me how to feel, when really, I just needed to figure it out for myself. You know?

Ugh, that's a…complicated question. Control. It's a funny thing to even *think* about when you're, like, sixteen and pregnant.

Honestly? No. Not really. I mean, I made the decision to go through with the adoption, and I got to pick the couple, Mark and Vanessa. That felt like *some* control. But it wasn't like I was calling all the shots. There were social workers involved, and lawyers, and a whole lot of paperwork. And everyone had their own opinions about what was best.

It felt more like…steering, maybe? Like I was trying to guide things in the direction I wanted, but there were a lot of forces pulling me in different directions. I wanted Vanessa and Mark to be happy, and I wanted the baby to have a good life. So I tried to be open to their suggestions and their needs.

But it was *my* body, and it was *my* baby. And that felt…important. I needed to feel like I had a say in what happened. I needed to feel like I wasn't just being pushed around.

So, did I have complete control? No. But did I have enough control to feel like I was making the right decision? Yeah. I think so. It was messy and confusing and scary, but ultimately, I felt like I was the one in charge of my own story. Even if it wasn't exactly the story I expected.

It's hard to explain. It's just…it wasn't black and white. It was a lot of gray. And a lot of feelings. And a lot of trying to do the best thing, even when it was the hardest thing.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay. That's… a loaded question. And I get asked it a lot, even now. It's not like it's something you just *forget* about, you know?

Honestly? It's complicated. There are days… days where I wonder what things would be like if I'd kept him. If I'd figured it out. If Paul hadn't… well, you know.

But then I remember how completely unprepared I was. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give him the life he deserved. Not then.

Mark and Vanessa… they were amazing. They gave him a stable, loving home. They wanted him. They were ready for him. And that was the most important thing.

So, would I make the same decision?

(Pauses, looks thoughtful)

Yeah. Yeah, I think I would. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and it still hurts sometimes. But it was the right thing. For him. And for me.

It wasn't about giving him *away*. It was about giving him a *chance*. A good chance. And I'm okay with that. I really am.

(A small, sad smile)

It doesn't make it easy, though. It never will. But it was the right thing. And that's all that matters, I guess.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept saying, "Oh, you're so selfless!" and I was like, "Yeah, well, try not crying into a box of cereal every morning."

It was weird. Like, I *wanted* to do it. I knew it was the right thing for the baby. But that didn't make it easy. It felt like… a hole. A really weird, empty hole.

I think the hardest part was the waiting. Waiting for the birth, waiting for the right family, waiting for everything to be final. It was just… suspended animation. And then, after, it was like, "Okay, now what?"

I leaned on a lot of things. Paul, obviously. He was a good listener, even when I was being a total mess. And my dad. He's not always the most… emotionally available, but he tried. He really did.

I also wrote a lot. Just… journaling. Getting all the messy feelings out of my head and onto paper. It helped. A little.

And music. Always music. Bleach was on repeat for a while. Don't judge.

Honestly, it took a long time to feel… okay. It wasn't like flipping a switch. It was more like slowly, gradually, learning to live with the sadness and the relief and the weird mix of everything else.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that it wasn't a failure. It wasn't giving up. It was making a really hard, brave decision. And that it was okay to grieve. It was okay to feel sad. It didn't mean I didn't love the baby. It just meant I was human.

It still comes up sometimes. A random song, or a baby in a stroller, or just… a feeling. But it doesn't hurt as much anymore. It's more like… a quiet ache. And I know that I did the right thing. And that's gotta count for something, right?

It's complicated. It really is. But I got through it. And you can get through whatever you're going through too. Just… be kind to yourself. And listen to some good music. That always helps.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's not like they were *bad* people, Mark and Vanessa were…intense. And they had a very specific idea of what they wanted. Which, honestly, is kinda weird when you're talking about a baby.

The biggest thing was…expectations. They had this whole nursery set up before I even told them I was keeping the baby. Like, they were already planning his life. And they wanted everything to be…perfect. Organic everything, Montessori toys, classical music only. It was a lot.

There were definitely moments where I felt like they were more interested in the *idea* of a baby than the actual baby. Like, they were collecting a perfect child, not welcoming a real person.

And Vanessa…she was really focused on the whole "natural birth" thing. Which, okay, good for her. But I was sixteen and just trying to get through it. I didn't really care about birthing plans.

We had a few arguments, mostly about what I should eat and how much weight I was gaining. They kept offering me kale smoothies. Kale smoothies! Like, seriously?

It wasn't that they were trying to be mean, they were just…overwhelmed and anxious. They'd been trying to adopt for a long time, and they were so desperate to be parents. But it was hard to feel like I had any control over the situation.

Paul and Bren were amazing, though. They helped me navigate all that stuff. They reminded me that I was the one making the decision, and that I needed to do what was best for me and the baby.

It was complicated. It wasn't easy. But in the end, I think we all came to a good place. They were good people, and they ended up being great parents to him. But yeah, there were definitely some bumps along the way. It's not a Hallmark movie, you know? It's real life.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a complicated one. It still kinda stings, honestly, even thinking about it now. It wasn't an easy decision, and it definitely wasn't something I took lightly.

Look, Paul was…sweet. He was a good guy. But he was also…not ready. He was still figuring out his own life, you know? He was a musician, and that's awesome, but it's not exactly a stable career path. And he wasn't really equipped to be a dad, not then.

It wasn't about him being a bad person. It was about what was best for the baby. I wanted the baby to have parents who were fully committed and financially stable and emotionally ready. And Paul just wasn't there yet.

It was hard telling him, though. Really hard. He was hurt, and I felt terrible about that. But I knew I had to be honest. I had to protect the baby, and that meant making a tough decision.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…different. They were older, they were established, they were *ready*. They were the perfect parents for the baby. And I wanted the baby to have that.

So, yeah, it was a hard call. And I still sometimes wonder if I made the right one. But I truly believe that keeping Paul out of the process was the best thing for everyone involved, especially the baby. It wasn't about punishing him, it was about giving the baby the best possible start in life.

It's just…it's not always about what *feels* good, you know? Sometimes you have to do what's right, even if it's hard. And that's what I tried to do.

Ugh, okay. That's… a big question. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was… a process. A really messy, complicated process.

Honestly, it started with just being… scared. Like, *really* scared. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I just… wasn't.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything I couldn't give it. A stable home, financial security, parents who were actually prepared to be parents. 

I talked to my dad, and he was… surprisingly cool about it. He didn't try to tell me what to do, he just listened. And then I met Mark and Vanessa, and… they just seemed perfect. They were so excited, so ready. And I realized that they could give the baby a life I just couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

It's not a story with a happy ending, exactly. It's a story with a… complicated ending. But it's my story. And I wouldn't change it. Even though it still kinda sucks sometimes.

Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It wasn't a logical decision, it was a… gut feeling. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut. Even when it's telling you something you don't want to hear.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It's still… raw, you know?

Honestly? I didn't cope well at first. I pretended I was fine. I was all sarcastic and detached, making jokes about it. But inside? It was just… a mess. Like someone had ripped a hole in my chest.

I was angry. At myself, at the situation, at everything. And then I was sad. Really, really sad. Like, couldn't-get-out-of-bed sad. And then I was scared. Scared I'd made the wrong decision, scared I'd never be able to move on.

Paul helped. A lot. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* feel. He just… listened. And he let me be a mess. And he made me grilled cheese sandwiches. Which, honestly, were the best thing ever at the time.

Vanessa too. She was… surprisingly understanding. She didn't judge me, and she helped me see that I was doing what was best for the baby.

But mostly, I just… felt things. I let myself feel the sadness, the anger, the fear. I wrote in my journal. I listened to sad music. I watched a lot of movies. I just… let it all out.

It didn't magically get better overnight. It took a long time. And there are still days when I think about him, and it hurts. But I know I made the right decision. I wanted him to have a life I couldn't give him. And that's okay.

It's not about forgetting. It's about learning to live with the sadness and the love, and knowing that he's out there, being loved and cared for.

It's… complicated. And it's not something you just "get over." But you learn to live with it. And you learn to be okay. Eventually.

And honestly? It made me stronger. It made me realize what I was capable of. And it made me appreciate the people who were there for me.

So yeah. That's how I coped. Or, you know, *tried* to cope. It was messy and imperfect, but it was real.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a Hallmark movie, that's for sure. It wasn't bad, exactly, but it was…weird. And a little sad, if I'm being honest.

Mark and Vanessa were…nice. Really nice. Like, overly nice. They were *so* excited about the baby, which was good, I guess. But it also felt like they were already picturing this perfect little life for him, and I was just…the vessel.

I tried to be cool, you know? Like, "Oh, yeah, totally happy for you guys." But it was hard. It was *my* baby, even if I knew I couldn't keep him. And it felt strange letting them plan everything – the nursery, the name, the whole nine yards.

We met a few times before the birth. They brought me gifts, which was awkward. I felt like I was accepting presents for someone else's kid. And they asked a lot of questions. Not in a nosy way, but they wanted to know everything about my health, my family, my lifestyle. It felt like they were vetting me, making sure I was "worthy" of giving them their baby.

After I gave birth, things were…distant. They were really grateful, which was nice, but they mostly just focused on the baby. I got a thank-you card and a small gift, but it wasn't like we became best friends or anything.

I think they just wanted to move on and start their life as a family. And I understood that. I really did. But it still stung a little.

It wasn't a bad relationship, but it wasn't a *relationship*, you know? It was more like a transaction. And that's kind of sad.

I still think about them sometimes. I hope they're happy. And I hope the baby – *his* name is Henry, by the way – is happy too. But I don't think I'll ever really know. And that's okay. I guess.



It's just…complicated. Life is complicated.

Ugh. Okay. Yeah. That's… a big question. And honestly? It totally has. Like, massively. It's not something you just *get over*, you know?

Before everything happened with Paul, I was pretty… detached. I was sarcastic and cynical and I mostly just observed people. I didn't really let anyone in. I was good at keeping things at arm's length. I thought that was being smart.

But getting pregnant… it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It forced me to deal with real consequences and make really hard decisions. It forced me to actually *care* about something other than myself.

I had to think about another person, about what was best for the baby. And that changed everything. It made me realize I wasn't as tough or as independent as I thought I was. I needed help. I needed my friends, my family… even Paul.

It also made me realize what I *wanted*. I wanted a life where I could be a good mom, even if it wasn't the life I originally planned. And that meant making some sacrifices.

I'm still sarcastic, don't get me wrong. And I still observe people. But now I think I'm a little more… empathetic. A little more willing to let people in. A little less afraid to be vulnerable.

It's weird. It was a really scary and difficult experience, but it also made me… stronger, I guess. It made me figure out who I am and what I believe in.

So yeah. It definitely changed me. And I think, ultimately, it changed me for the better. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever gone through.

Ugh. Okay, that was…rough. Seriously. It was like, suddenly everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were asking for it. It was the worst.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that's impossible when people are staring at you in the grocery store or whispering behind your back at school. And the *notes*. Oh god, the notes. People leaving anonymous notes on my locker. It was awful.

Paul was really good about it, actually. He was like, "Let them talk. They're just jealous they don't have a baby." Which, okay, a little weird, but also kind of true.

But mostly, I just leaned on my friends. Leah and Renee were amazing. They just…didn't care what anyone else thought. They were just there for me, and that made a huge difference.

I also started just…owning it. Like, yeah, I'm pregnant. So what? It's not the end of the world. It's my life, and I'm gonna do what I need to do. I started being really sarcastic with people who tried to make me feel bad. Like, if someone gave me a pitying look, I'd just give them a really deadpan stare and say, "Oh, you think *this* is bad? You should see my shoe collection."

It didn't make the rumors go away completely, but it made them a lot less painful. And honestly, it made me feel a lot stronger.

It was a weird time. But I learned a lot about people. And about myself. And about the power of having good friends. And about the fact that people will always talk, no matter what you do. So you might as well just do what makes you happy.

And also, I just really wanted to get the baby out and be done with it all. That helped too.

(Sighs, looks down at my hands for a moment, then back up)

Okay. That's…that's the big question, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. It's not like I didn't think about keeping her. I did. A lot. Like, obsessively.

But honestly? I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I was barely keeping my own life together, you know? School, my dad, Paul…it was already a lot.

And it wasn't about not wanting her. It was about wanting her to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready for it, a life that I just…couldn't provide at that time. Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They could give her things I just couldn't.

It wasn't a selfish decision, even though a lot of people probably thought it was. It was the most selfless thing I could do. It was about putting her needs first.

I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my dreams. And I didn't want to resent her for that. I wanted her to be loved, unconditionally, by people who were ready to love her.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. For her. And for me.

(Looks away, a little vulnerable)

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's just…life. And sometimes, life means making really hard choices.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. And a hard one. Everyone kept asking me if I was sad, if I was gonna miss the baby, and yeah, those things were definitely there. But it wasn't really about *that*.

My biggest fear? It was that I'd messed everything up. Like, that I wasn't…good enough. That I wasn't mature enough to make the right decision. That I was being selfish, even though I knew giving the baby up was the best thing.

I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for a whole human life. And I was handing a baby over to…well, to perfect people. Mark and Vanessa. They had a house with a yard and a Pottery Barn catalog and everything. I was living in my dad's house, eating cereal for dinner.

I was terrified that they'd realize I was a screw-up and they'd regret choosing me. That they'd think I didn't care enough. That the baby would be better off without me, and I'd just…disappear from their lives and be a total failure.

It wasn't about losing the baby, it was about being judged. About being seen as incapable. About messing up something so important.

It sounds stupid when I say it out loud, but that was it. That was the thing that kept me up at night. Just…the fear of not being good enough.

But, you know, things worked out. And they were right. Mark and Vanessa *were* perfect. And they loved that baby. And I…I learned a lot. About myself, about life, about what really matters. But yeah. That was my biggest fear. Being a failure.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get asked a lot. It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. It wasn't some deep, meaningful thing, okay? It wasn't like, a symbol of his soul or anything.

Paul… he wasn't exactly a name-dropper. He didn't talk about his life much. And he didn't want his name out there with the adoption. He wanted to be a donor, a good guy, but he didn't want a lot of attention.

So, I needed a name for the adoption paperwork. Something…neutral. And I was flipping through the Yellow Pages – yeah, I know, old school – looking for a last name that wasn't super common. And I saw "Bleeker" under "Plumbers."

I know, it's ridiculous. A plumber. But it just…stuck. It sounded kinda cool, kinda unassuming. It didn't scream "father." It just…was.

I told Paul, and he shrugged. He didn't care. He just wanted to do the right thing.

So yeah, that's the story. My baby's father is named after a plumber in the Yellow Pages. Don't judge me. I was sixteen and pregnant. I wasn't exactly thinking things through with a lot of nuance. It just…felt right at the time.

It's a weird story, I know. But it's my story. And it's kinda perfect in its own weird way.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the music. It's not like I *set out* to be a punk rock kid, you know? It just…happened. It kinda found me.

I think it was the honesty, mostly. Everything else felt so fake. All the pop music on the radio, everyone trying to be something they weren't. It was just…ugh. But with punk, it was like, people were just saying what they thought, even if it was messy and angry and kinda depressing. It felt *real*.

And it wasn't about being perfect. It was about being raw and energetic and not caring what anyone else thought. Which, as a teenager, is a pretty appealing concept. Especially when you're feeling kinda lost and confused and like you don't really fit in.

The clothes were cool too, I guess. The ripped jeans and the band tees and the combat boots. It was a way to say, "I don't care about your rules." It was a uniform for outsiders.

But it wasn't just the music or the clothes. It was the whole attitude. The DIY ethic. The idea that you could create something yourself, even if you didn't have a lot of money or resources. It was empowering.

Plus, The Moldy Peaches are amazing. They're not exactly traditional punk, but they have that same kind of honesty and vulnerability. They just…get it.

So yeah, that's what drew me to it. It was a way to express myself, to connect with other people who felt the same way, and to just be myself, even if that meant being a little bit weird. It was a good outlet for all the stuff I was going through. And it was loud. Which was also good.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a heavy question. It's not something I usually just *talk* about, you know? But, alright. It definitely messed with my head, my parents' divorce. It wasn't like a screaming, fighting divorce, which maybe would have been easier to process. It was just…quietly falling apart. Like a slow leak.

And it made me really scared of commitment, honestly. Like, if *they* couldn't make it work, what chance did anyone have? I saw how much it hurt them, even though they tried to be civil. And I didn't want to put myself in that position.

With Paulie Bleeker…that was complicated. I really liked him, but I was also terrified of getting too close. I kept trying to push him away, to convince myself I didn't need anyone. It was a defense mechanism, I guess. I didn't want to end up like my parents, all sad and separate.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that you can only rely on yourself. Which is good, in some ways. But it also made it hard for me to ask for help, or to let anyone in.

I think, ultimately, it made me appreciate the good things in my life more. And it made me realize that relationships take work. They're not always easy, but they're worth fighting for.

It took me a while to figure that out, though. And it took a lot of therapy. Just kidding. (Sort of.)

It's still something I think about, you know? How my parents' choices affected me. But I'm trying to learn from their mistakes and build my own kind of family, whatever that looks like.

It's messy. Life is messy. But that's okay. It's real.

Ugh, okay, that's a…deep question. I don't usually *think* about my story being "special," you know? It just *was*. But if I had to break it down…

I think it's the messiness of it all. Like, it wasn't a perfect situation. It wasn't a fairytale. It was awkward and complicated and kinda scary. And I think a lot of people can relate to that.

I wasn't this super-mature, wise-beyond-my-years kid. I was just…me. A sarcastic, music-loving teenager who accidentally got pregnant. I didn't have all the answers. I was figuring things out as I went along. And I made mistakes. A lot of them.

I think it's also about the fact that I *chose* to give the baby up. That's not what everyone expects. It's not the "happy ending" people usually want to see. But it was the right decision for me, and for the baby. And I think that's important to show. That sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is choose what's best for everyone involved, even if it's hard.

And then there's Paulie Bleeker. He wasn't some perfect boyfriend. He was a sweet, awkward kid who just…got me. And he supported me, even when I was being a total mess.

So yeah, I think it's the combination of all those things. The messiness, the honesty, the unexpected choices, and the people who helped me along the way. It wasn't a perfect story, but it was *my* story. And I think that's what makes it special.

Plus, the soundtrack is pretty killer. Just sayin'.

Ugh, okay, friends. It's complicated, right? Like, people are mostly disappointing. But the good ones…they're worth it. Here's what I look for, I guess.

First off, **honesty.** Not like, brutally honest to the point of being a jerk, but someone who'll tell me the truth, even when it's not what I want to hear. I can handle it. Mostly.

Then there's **a good sense of humor.** Someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm being a total mess. And someone who *gets* my humor, which is, like, dry and sarcastic. You gotta be able to handle that.

**Loyalty** is big. I need someone who's got my back, you know? Someone who won't talk behind my back or ditch me when things get tough.

And honestly? **Someone who doesn't judge.** I make a lot of questionable decisions. It's just a fact. I need someone who can accept me for who I am, flaws and all.

Also, **being a good listener.** I don't always *say* what's going on, so someone who can read between the lines and actually listen is important.

And finally, **shared interests are cool, but not essential.** It's more about just…vibing with someone. Having a connection. Being able to sit in silence and not feel awkward.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves, and who accepts me for being me. It's a high bar, I know. But that's what I'm looking for.

It's not about having a million friends. It's about having a few good ones. And those are hard to find.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it's been all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's definitely shaken things up.

With my parents…it was rough at first. My dad just kinda shut down. He didn't say much, just looked…disappointed. Which, okay, fair enough. It wasn't exactly what he pictured for me. But it hurt. My mom was more…overwhelmed. Lots of questions, lots of worrying. They're coming around, though. They're trying. It's just…different now. There's this weird layer of awkwardness.

Paul…that was complicated. He was a good guy, but he wasn't ready. And honestly, I don't think he ever really *was* ready. It was hard to watch him struggle with it. It made me realize we weren't really on the same page about, like, life stuff. It was sad, but it was also…necessary.

But the biggest change has been with Leah. She's been amazing. Seriously. She's been my rock. She doesn't judge, she just…listens. And she's been so supportive of my decision to give the baby up. She gets it. She understands that this isn't about not wanting the baby, it's about wanting what's best for it.

It's made me realize who my real friends are. And it's made me appreciate the people who are willing to stick by me, even when things are messy and complicated.

It's also made me realize that relationships are…fragile. They can change in an instant. And you have to work at them. You have to be honest and open and willing to forgive.

So yeah, it's been a rollercoaster. But it's also been…a good thing, in a weird way. It's forced me to grow up and figure out what really matters. And it's shown me who I can really count on.

It's just…a lot. You know?

Ugh, okay, deep questions. It's not like I sit around and *think* about my worldview all the time, you know? But if you're making me analyze it... here's what I've figured out shapes how I see things.

First off, **honesty.** Like, brutal honesty. I don't really have the patience for BS. People should just say what they mean, even if it's awkward. It saves everyone a lot of time and trouble.

Then there's **independence.** I've always kinda had to figure things out on my own. I'm not really one for following the crowd or doing what's expected of me. I gotta do my own thing.

**Authenticity** is a big one. I think people should just be themselves, even if it's weird or unpopular. Trying to be someone you're not is exhausting and pointless.

I also believe in **taking responsibility for your actions.** Like, you mess up, you own it. No excuses. It's not always easy, but it's the right thing to do.

And, surprisingly, **compassion.** I try not to be a total cynic. Even though I make a lot of sarcastic comments, I actually do care about people. I think everyone deserves a little bit of kindness, even if they don't deserve it.

I guess, overall, I believe in being real, being true to yourself, and trying to do the right thing, even when it's hard. It's not always pretty, but it's what I'm going for.

It's kinda messy, I know. I'm still figuring things out. But those are the things that matter to me, I guess. Don't overthink it.

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment or anything. It took a lot of back and forth with Mark and Vanessa, and a lot of just…thinking.

We wanted something that wasn't too common, you know? Not like Brittany or Ashley. But also not, like, super weird and out there. We wanted something that felt…real. And kind of strong.

We went through a *ton* of names. Seriously. Mark suggested a bunch of sports names, which were immediately vetoed. Vanessa had a whole list of old-fashioned names that sounded like characters from a Dickens novel.

Then, Vanessa mentioned her grandmother’s name was Hazel. And I just…liked it. It sounded gentle, but also kind of earthy and grounded. And it reminded me of hazel eyes, which are pretty.

But it wasn't just the sound. Vanessa's grandmother was a really strong woman. She raised a bunch of kids during the Depression and always kept her family together. She was a survivor. And that felt…important. Like, we wanted our baby to have a name that represented strength and resilience.

So, Hazel it was. It felt right. It felt like a name that would fit her, no matter what. And it felt like a way to honor Vanessa's grandmother, which was important to both of us.

It's kinda weird to think about, you know? Picking a name for someone you haven't even met yet. But it felt like a good start. Like, we were already giving her something special.

It's a good name. I think she'll like it.

Ugh, okay, that's a big question. It's not like a pop quiz, right? But yeah, a lot happened. A *lot*. It wasn't just about growing a human, it was about…growing up, I guess.

I think the biggest thing I learned about myself is that I'm way stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. I mean, I always thought I was pretty independent and sarcastic and could handle things, but this was different. This was…real. And I made a really big decision, and I stuck to it, even when everyone else had an opinion. That took guts, I think.

I also learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I still think the world is kinda messed up, but I also saw a lot of good. Like, Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were so excited and so ready to be parents, and it made me feel good knowing that my kid was going to have a really loving home. And Paul and my dad…they were surprisingly supportive, even when they didn't totally get it.

About the world…I learned that people are complicated. There's no black and white, you know? Everyone's got their own stuff going on, and you gotta try to be understanding, even when it's hard. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do for someone is let them go. It doesn't mean you don't care, it just means you want what's best for them.

I also learned that life doesn't always go according to plan. And that's okay. You gotta be flexible and adapt and just…roll with it. Because if you try to control everything, you're gonna end up really stressed out.

It was messy and complicated and scary, but it was also…good. It made me think about things I never thought about before. It made me realize that I'm capable of a lot more than I thought I was. And it made me realize that even though I'm still figuring things out, I'm okay. I'm gonna be okay.

It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about making a really brave and selfless decision. And that's something I'm really proud of. Even if I don't always say it out loud.

Ugh. Okay, that's a heavy question. Looking back… yeah. There are definitely things. It wasn't all sunshine and witty banter, you know?

I think… I would have let myself *feel* more. I was so busy being sarcastic and trying to be strong and independent, I kinda shut down a lot of the scary stuff. The sadness, the confusion, the… everything. I think I needed to let myself be vulnerable a little more, instead of always trying to be the tough one.

And maybe I would have talked to my dad more. We were okay, but… I think I could have been more open with him. He was trying, you know? He just didn't always know *how* to talk about things.

I also probably would have spent less time worrying about what other people thought. Like, the whole school thing. I got so caught up in trying to be cool and not letting anyone know, I missed out on a lot. It would have been nice to just… be honest.

But honestly? I don't know if I would change anything major. Because everything that happened, even the bad stuff, made me who I am. And I'm… okay with who I am. I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm getting there.

It was a messy, complicated, weird experience. But it was *my* experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Except maybe a lifetime supply of cheese curls. But that's a different story.

So yeah. Maybe a little more feeling, a little more talking, a little less worrying. But overall? I think I did okay. For a sixteen-year-old who found out she was pregnant.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. A *lot*. Honestly? It kinda sucks. Especially when you've built something up in your head, you know? Like, you've got this whole picture of how things *should* be, and then…bam. Reality hits.

I guess the first thing I do is just…let myself be bummed out for a little bit. Like, wallow in it. Listen to sad music. Eat a whole bag of chips. Whatever. You gotta acknowledge the feeling, you can't just pretend it's not there.

But then, you gotta pull yourself together. And that's the hard part.

I try to remember that things rarely go exactly as planned. Like, *ever*. And sometimes, that's okay. Sometimes, things turn out even better than you expected. Or sometimes, they just turn out different. And different isn't always bad.

I also try to focus on what I *can* control. Like, I can't control what other people do, or what happens in the future. But I can control how I react to things. I can choose to be positive, or I can choose to be miserable. It's my choice.

And honestly? Talking about it helps. Venting to a friend, or just writing down my feelings. It makes it feel less overwhelming.

It's not like I have all the answers, okay? I'm still figuring things out. But I've learned that disappointment is just a part of life. You gotta roll with the punches, and try to find the silver lining. Even if it's a really small silver lining.

And sometimes, the silver lining is just knowing that you survived it. And that you're strong enough to keep going.

So yeah. That's how I deal with it. Mostly. Sometimes I just eat more chips. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, so talking about Leah is…complicated. It wasn't like a typical best-friend-forever kind of thing, you know? It was more…evolving. And messy.

At the beginning, Leah was just…there. She was my friend, yeah, but mostly because we were both kinda outsiders. We bonded over records and hating gym class and just generally being cynical about everything. She was the one who always had my back, even when I was being a total mess. She was the reliable one.

But then everything with Paul happened, and suddenly our friendship got…weird. She was super supportive about the pregnancy, which was good, but she also got really invested in the adoption process, like, *really* invested. It felt like she was trying to control everything, to make sure it went perfectly. And I started to feel suffocated.

It wasn't that she was trying to be mean or anything. She just…wanted everything to be okay. She was scared for me, I guess. But her way of showing it was to try and fix things, to plan everything out. And I'm not a "plan things out" kind of person.

The whole thing with Mark and the college application really blew up. I felt like she was judging me for wanting to have a life outside of the pregnancy, for wanting to still be a teenager. And she got all defensive and said I wasn't taking things seriously enough.

It was a really rough patch. We didn't talk for a while.

But then, at the end, when I was with Paul and everything was kinda settling down, she came around. She apologized for being overbearing and said she just wanted what was best for me. And I apologized for being a jerk.

It wasn't like we went back to exactly how things were before. It was different. More mature, I guess. We understood each other better. We realized that even though we had different ways of dealing with things, we still cared about each other.

It wasn't a perfect friendship, and it definitely wasn't always easy. But it was real. And in the end, that's what mattered. It evolved from just being convenient to being something…deeper. Something that could survive a little bit of messiness.

Ugh, okay, that's a loaded question. "Favorite" is a strong word. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? But if I had to pick something... it wasn't the morning sickness, definitely not the cravings, and absolutely not the weird body stuff.

It was... the feeling of something *real*. Like, before that, my life was just... floating. School, music, hanging out with Paulie and Leah. It was good, but it didn't feel like it *meant* anything, you know?

But then, suddenly, there was this little person growing inside me. And it was this tiny, secret thing that only I knew about. And it felt... important. Like, suddenly I had a purpose.

And I know that sounds super cheesy and dramatic, but it's true. It made me think about the future, and about what kind of person I wanted to be. And it made me realize that even though I wasn't ready to be a mom, I could still do something good.

So, yeah. The feeling of something real. That was probably my favorite part. Even if it was also the scariest part.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.
